IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene silencing enzymes PRC1, PRC2, and DNMT1 are essential for maintaining cellular identity, and defects in these enzymes are some of the leading causes of leukemias and cardiac diseases. We will use chemical biology and a structure-guided approach to develop new inhibitors and activators targeting PRC2. We will use an integrated structural and functional approach to uncover the molecular mechanisms that activate PRC1 and DNMT1 on chromatin, which will enable the development of new therapeutic avenues targeting these enzymes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We aim to establish a research program that develops optical imaging technologies that overcome the challenge of tissue scattering, to achieve large-scale 3D imaging of tissue morphogenesis. If successful, this work will enable, for the first time, joint morphological and molecular imaging of deep-tissue morphogenetic events across entire developing embryos at subcellular resolutions. Furthermore, this work will lay the foundation for future imaging technologies that enable investigations into in-vivo biological processes taking place within their natural tissue environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to remember one's features and monitor current states is fundamental for self-recognition, yet the mechanisms governing how neurons, circuits, and inter-regional functional connectivity in the brain accomplish visual self-recognition remain unknown. By taking advantage of a mouse model, our proposed study aims to demonstrate the most detailed functional map of the hippocampal-prefrontal cortical circuits that control visual self-recognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DEAD-box ATPases remodel RNA:protein assemblies in cells to control gene expression programs, and their dysregulation contributes to human diseases. We propose to develop an integrated approach to understanding how the function of DEAD-box proteins can be controlled with chemistry-based tools. By learning what determines the specificity and efficacy of chemical DEAD-box protein modulators, we will enable the design of powerful probes to study the roles of RNA in gene regulation and to test hypotheses for developing new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative Development of specific therapies for idiopathic renal disease has been hampered by poor stratification of disease entities and a lack of understanding of underlying disease mechanisms. Our published and preliminary findings highlight a novel and central role for the bone marrow immune system in the pathogenesis of renal disease. Thus, we aim to explore the bone marrow-kidney axis as a novel target that improves current patient stratification and provides targets for the eventual development of effective treatments.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because fibrillar adhesins are widely used by bacteria in infection and persistence, and as such are desirable targets for anti-virulence therapeutics. The project is relevant to the mission of NIGMS because our discoveries will increase our fundamental understanding of fibrillar adhesin structure and function and provide a roadmap for the study of structurally similar proteins, laying the groundwork for advances in therapeutics for a range of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma (ACC) is a salivary gland head and neck cancer with high recurrence rate and despite the significant biological and clinical variability, all patients are treated the same. There is no standard of care systemic therapies for patients with this orphan disease. This proposal is pertinent to public health because it will identify clinically significant, reliable, prognostic, and predictive DNA methylation biomarkers, which will address a clinical gap-specifically, the lack of biomarkers for prognostication, and to guide patient stratification for treatment selection in ACC. Thus, our proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human illness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is both relevant to public health and aligned with the National Institutes of Child Health and Human Development’s mission; we will test the efficacy of an intervention designed to improve maternal and infant health by empowering clinicians with skills to enhance patients’ access to continued gainful employment and accommodation to ensure a safe working environment during pregnancy. Data gathered during the randomized trial, including electronic health record review, patient survey and qualitative interviews will also be leveraged to support diverse medical students as they participate in a year-long mentored career development and obstetric health disparities research program. We will enhance diversity in biomedical research by conducting a rigorously designed trial in collaboration with a patient- and community-engaged multidisciplinary team while mentoring medical students poised to become the next generation of clinician scientists dedicated to eradicating health disparities in maternal and infant health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Many hormones act via the signaling protein Gsα, which is produced by the GNAS complex gene. Disruption of Gsα activity causes several human diseases due to impaired actions of multiple hormones, causing altered metabolism, derangements in serum calcium and phosphate levels, abnormal bone development, growth problems, and intellectual disability. To enhance our understanding of these disorders and, thus, improve their clinical management, we aim to elucidate the mechanisms regulating the production of Gsα from the GNAS gene in different hormone-responsive tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity increased sharply at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, and in response, the federal government took unprecedented steps to increase nutrition benefits (emergency allotments) for millions of low- income Americans through the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). A growing body of evidence suggests that food insecurity is associated with cardiovascular health, and so in this proposal, we will: (1) examine changes in food insecurity among low-income adults, including those with cardiometabolic risk factors, during and following the pandemic; (2) elucidate the pathways by which food insecurity impacts cardiometabolic health; and (3) estimate the spillover and health effects of SNAP benefits. To do so, we will leverage a natural experiment that occurred during the pandemic when US states de-implemented SNAP emergency allotments to estimate their impact on health care access and affordability, the prevalence, treatment, and control of cardiometabolic risk factors, and the incidence acute cardiovascular events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The primary goal of this project is to develop machine learning based computational models for predicting protein interactions in the context of immune receptors and their antigen recognition. Additionally, these models can gen- erate immune receptors that can be used in a wide range of applications such as therapeutics, diagnostics, and studying the molecular basis of antigen recognition. Most importantly, the project seeks to provide a generalized principles of effectively representing biological sequences such that this work can be extended to different types of protein interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Model It! project aims to significantly improve STEM education by transforming an emerging biomedical research-grade computational modeling and simulation technology into an interactive and engaging pedagogical gaming application for students in grades 5-8 after-school programs. By developing essential computational modeling and simulation skills, this project will equip the next generation of life science professionals with foundational competencies, promoting innovation in public health and biomedical research. The technology's widespread adoption will contribute to the development of a skilled workforce capable of addressing pressing public health challenges and advancing the field of systems biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) refers to a collection of clonal blood disorders characterized by ineffective production of mature blood cells by the hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow. Various genetic mutations, including those that participate in RNA processing, can corrupt the ability of bone marrow stem cells produce functional blood cells. In this proposal, we seek to understand the molecular causes and consequences of genomic instability caused by RNA splicing factor mutations, and to identify novel treatment options for MDS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) in youth with type 2 diabetes (T2D) dramatically increases the risk of early kidney failure and mortality and is increasing in prevalence, but preventive therapies are limited. Exposure to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) may increase DKD risk in youth with T2D and is associated with altered renal organic anion transporters, which actively reabsorb PFAS from urine, concentrate PFAS in proximal tubules, and potentially increasing PFAS nephrotoxicity and risk of DKD. In this first-of-its-kind study, we will leverage two longitudinal cohorts of youth with T2D to examine how organic anion transporters and exposure to PFAS affect DKD risk in youth and identify potential therapeutic targets and prevention approaches for mitigating PFAS associated nephrotoxicity in high-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Narrative The New Mexico Academic Science Education and Research Training K12 IRACDA Program prepares postdoctoral fellows to excel in all facets of academic life at institutions likely to have highly diverse student populations. Training is achieved through: (1) conduct of cutting-edge research with scientists at the University of New Mexico, (2) career development and skill-building activities, and (3) practical teaching experiences at one of three partnered Minority Serving Institutions in New Mexico. Ninety-eight percent of ASERT alumni are in biomedical research or education positions, where they make new discoveries and technological advances, improve healthcare, innovate teaching strategies, and motivate the next generation of students in research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: As a clinical scientist, I have led (as overall Principal Investigator) first-in-kind NCI-supported clinical trials evaluating circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) as a predictive biomarker for adjuvant chemotherapy in patients with early-stage colon cancer as well as trials testing novel immunotherapy combinations for patients with incurable gastrointestinal malignancies. My research interest focuses on use of the liquid biopsy to characterize genomic (ctDNA) and transcriptomic (extravesicle RNA) changes in association with treatment responses, using plasma samples that may overcome historical challenges of obtaining paired tumor biopsy samples from clinical trials. In seeking R50 funding, I propose to apply these learned experiences to develop other NCI-led clinical trials for colorectal cancer and anal cancer that, if successful, would validate the use of the liquid biopsy as tool valuable for the design of clinical trials aimed to eradicate minimal residual disease (as informed by a “ctDNA(+) status”) and improve survival outcomes for patients with gastrointestinal malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The nasal mucosa serves as the initial site of viral exposure and infection but the mechanism by which viruses penetrate this physical barrier and infect cells remains unclear. We propose that respiratory viruses hijack motile cilia for viral entry into the nasal cavity. This work will define mechanisms by which respiratory viruses enter the nasal mucosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Brachytherapy is a procedure to radiate a tumor internally through thin tubes called catheters inserted in the tissue and has been widely used to treat locally advanced cervical and endometrial cancers. For safe and complete radiation, placing the catheters in the tumor at optimal locations is crucial. In this project, we will develop a remotely-controlled manipulator that assists the clinician in placing the catheters in the patient in an imaging scanner while checking their locations using advanced shape-sensing technology and providing real-time quantitative evaluation of the implant quality during the implant procedure for better clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our application aims to apply advances in tissue engineering to address the need for the development of cancer metastasis model that can reflect in vivo biology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Half of adults aged 65 years or older with atrial fibrillation (AF) are not treated with oral anticoagulants (OAC) due to concerns for major bleeding. Even though the greatest need for left atrial appendage occlusion (LAAO) is in OAC-ineligible patients and patients with frailty, the randomized clinical trials of LAAO tested LAAO in OAC-eligible patients, did not measure frailty at baseline, and most likely excluded patients with frailty. The objective of the proposal is to address the evidence-practice gap by investigating utilization and the comparative effectiveness and safety of LAAO against therapeutic alternatives (i.e., OAC and non-use of OAC) and heterogeneous treatment effects by frailty status in medically complex routine population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The Infectious Disease and Basic Microbiological Mechanisms training program continues to train postdoctoral trainees as independent physician scientists (M.D. and M.D.-Ph.D.) and Ph.D. scientists able to recognize and answer clinically relevant questions in the fields of infectious diseases and microbiology. This training program is especially important now, as we witness the emergence of new infectious diseases and global pandemics, the continued challenges of illnesses due to antibiotic-resistant pathogens, and the development of revolutionary scientific technologies and approaches that have the potential to address these and other issues in the field.

PHR: Narrative. The metastatic niche is a site that promotes the homing and colonization of immune cells and cancer cells to solid organs, which is often the cause of mortality. We propose to develop nanoparticles the reprogram the function of innate immune cells to disrupt the metastatic niche and thereby enable the immune system to clear metastatic cancer cells from endogenous metastatic sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because facilitating accurate interpretation of fast voltammetric data is expected to help establish the precise role that specific neurochemicals play in regulating core brain processes and behavior. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to improve health and reduce the burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  One of the major vascular causes of death and disease in the USA is abnormal blood clots in the lung or feet, a condition called venous thromboembolism. Inheriting abnormal genes increases the risk of blood clots, but the genetic causes of abnormal blood clots are not well understood. We propose to study a new genetic pathway that increases the risk for abnormal blood clots, and our research may lead to improved risk prediction and new treatments to prevent and treat blood clots.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Health Relevance/Narrative: Liver cells from fetal liver can provide a unique regenerative cell source to generate new healthy tissue mass. We have identified the underlying mechanism and developed methods to produce similar growth- advantaged cells in vitro. Our studies will dissect the mechanism of cell competition/fitness and how it impacts chronic liver disease progression. Results from our proposed studies will provide new information for developing novel cell-based therapies in patients with liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Mice lacking the NADP(H) phosphatase, Nocturnin, are resistant to diet-induced obesity and hepatic steatosis on a high-fat diet, yet the mechanisms underlying this phenotype are unknown. In the experiments outlined in this proposal, we will subject adipose-, liver-, muscle-, and intestine-specific Nocturnin knock-out mice to a high- fat diet and analyze their adiposity and overall metabolic health. From these experiments, we will be able to both determine if loss of Nocturnin in a single tissue is sufficient to confer resistance to diet-induced obesity and better understand Nocturnin’s, and thus NADP(H)’s, tissue-specific impact on metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colorectal cancer is the second most deadly cancer worldwide and responsible for an alarming trend of rising incidence among younger adults. Cell state plasticity by way of impaired differentiation contributes to cancer initiation, molecular heterogeneity, and resistance to targeted therapies. The proposed research will utilize rigorous model systems and cutting-edge scientific tools to define key mechanisms underlying cell state plasticity and impaired differentiation, aiming to provide original conceptual insights and stimulate new strategies for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Integrating histology image data to predict spatial gene expression in large-scale spatial transcriptomics (ST) studies is a promising approach. This application aims to develop informatics tools to conduct such predictions and implement them in open-source software packages. With these tools, researchers can generate virtual ST data at single-cell resolution, enabling 3D ST tissue volume reconstruction, exploration of spatial gene expression variations in population-based studies, and the creation of prognostic models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This project will test the capability of a vestibular prosthesis (or implant) to improve cognitive function in patients with severe vestibular damage. We will measure how higher-level behaviors, including spatial orientation, navigation, and neuropsychologic function, are affected by long-term stimulation provided by the vestibular implant, and in parallel will study these behaviors in non-implanted patients with different degrees of vestibular impairment. The goal of these studies is to determine if the cognitive dysfunction experienced by patients with severe vestibular damage can be improved with prosthetic stimulation, findings which would expand the clinical utility of the vestibular implant while concomitantly improving understanding of the role of vestibular information in cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: People and parity are among the central tenets of public health efforts, and improving the design and implementation of NCI-sponsored clinical trials can directly improve patient access and survival. The work proposed in this R50 submission seeks to enhance the matching of NCI-sponsored trials and optimize resource allocation both locally and nationally, which will improve accrual and expedite successful trial completion. Increasing the speed at which we answer clinical questions in NCI- sponsored trials has direct impacts on enhancing health and lengthening life in gastrointestinal cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative. New evidence that the LGR5+ CSCs are not the sole driving force behind CRC progression and resistance to therapy took the community by surprise13 and suggested a more complex interplay between LGR5+ and LGR5- cells. We and others have recently uncovered the presence of a second stem cell population (OnFSCs) in CRC. Here, we aim to promptly assess their functional relevance in CRC evolution and define potentially targetable vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Over the past decade, alcohol consumption in the US has risen by 84% in women compared with 35% in men. Given that women experience accelerated health-related problems at lower consumption levels (“telescoping”), and there are no approved medications tailored to the unique needs of women, this presents a public health crisis. We propose a multicenter clinical trial, conducted using a remote platform, to examine whether guanfacine extended release (GXR; 3mg/d) versus placebo can reduce drinking in women with Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) by targeting biological and behavioral processes integral to compulsive drinking in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: SPECIFIC AIMS Current therapies for cystic fibrosis (CF) are insufficient for a large segment of American patients, particularly those harboring CFTR nonsense mutations (NMs). This gap in treatment options signifies a critical unmet medical need, as these mutations represent the most common genetic variants causing CF, yet remain largely unaddressed by existing therapies. To address this therapeutic void, we aim to develop a non-viral base-editing approach specifically designed to correct such mutations. Specific Aim 1: In Vitro Optimization and Characterization of RNA-Encoded ABE Systems This aim focuses on the refinement and characterization of RNA-encoded Adenine Base Editors (ABEs) for in vitro applications, targeting the G542X mutation in the CFTR gene associated with CF. Sub-aim 1.1 is devoted to the synthesis and optimization of chemically modified ABE mRNA to enhance its stability and cellular uptake. Sub-aim 1.2 aims to fine-tune guide RNA (gRNA) configurations to maximize base-editing efficacy while minimizing off-target risks. Sub-aim 1.3 explores the functional recovery of CFTR post-base editing. Utilizing the 16HBEge CFTR G542X cell line as our disease model, we will employ the second-generation PAM-less Cas9 variant, CE-8e-SpRY, which has shown superior performance in preliminary studies. Various methodologies, such as in vitro transcription, gel-based cleavage, and Ussing Chamber assays, will be implemented for comprehensive validation. Specific Aim 2: Development and Screening of LNPs for Pulmonary Delivery of ABE Systems The objective of this aim is to engineer optimized lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) for efficient pulmonary delivery of ABEs. To address key challenges like mucus barrier penetration and endosomal escape, our approach incorporates a high-throughput combinatorial synthesis (HTCS) platform for formulating a novel library of ionizable lipids. A two-tiered screening process will initially be performed in 2D human bronchial cell cultures, followed by ex vivo validation in air-liquid interface (ALI) 3D cultures. The most promising LNP candidates will undergo in vivo testing in murine models, offering a robust, iterative optimization process. Specific Aim 3: Efficacy and Safety Assessment of ABE LNPs in CFTR G542X Mouse Models The overarching objective of this aim is to rigorously evaluate the efficacy and safety of LNP-encapsulated ABEs in a CFTR G542X mouse model, which faithfully replicates the cardinal features of CF. Leveraging the targeted lung delivery of LNPs, we expect to mitigate the risks of off-target effects compared to systemic delivery. Sub- aim 3.1 focuses on the re-optimization of gRNA sequences for mouse primary lung epithelial cells, evaluating both A>G editing efficiency and edit purity. Sub-aim 3.2 involves intratracheal administration of optimized ABE LNPs at variable dosages, assessing therapeutic impact through nasal potential difference (NPD) and genomic analyses. Sub-aim 3.3 will undertake exhaustive molecular scrutiny of potential off-target editing events, utilizing whole-genome sequencing for definitive verification. Anticipated outcomes include the restoration of functional CFTR protein in over 10% of treated mice with minimal off-target events. In the near term, our research endeavors to offer a transformative base-editing treatment for CF patients harboring the G542X mutation. In the long run, this strategy could extend its applicability to approximately 12% of all inherited diseases caused by NMs, many of which are currently without effective treatments. This would constitute a significant advance in gene therapy for CF, filling a critical gap in patient care while also pioneering techniques in RNA and genome editor delivery systems. Upon successful completion of this research, future work will involve the further optimization of LNP-carrying RNA-encoded ABEs for stability in nebulizers, enhancing the translatability of our approach and potentially catalyzing substantial advancements in American health sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We inform evidence-based policies to address inequities and improve public health when resources are scarce and specifically inform the impact of policies that target early access by geographic vs. individual- level health, social vulnerability, and race by using a large randomized experiment that took place when vaccines were extremely scarce to estimate inequities in vaccine takeup among patients age ≥65 that persist given randomized early access. We quantify the potential equity impacts of further public health policies that go beyond targeting greater numbers of invitations by quantifying how much of the inequities that persist given randomized early access can be explained by various mechanisms that operate through health behaviors, health conditions, and social and environmental factors available in our rich population-level data, which we plan to disseminate. We inform the potential for vaccine distribution policies to affect current and future inequities in health and economic wellbeing by adapting a well founded framework from economics to characterize how the composition of the vaccinated population changes by health, social vulnerability, and race as the share vaccinated expands with randomization and by relating those changes to inequities in the downstream impact of vaccination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure patients with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) exhibit severe exercise limitation and exertional dyspnea and in this context, the central premise of our proposal is that locomotor and inspiratory muscle pathophysiologic mechanisms contribute to these HFpEF symptoms. In this application, we investigate the role the 1) locomotor muscle reflexes have on the abnormal cardiopulmonary responses during exercise in HFpEF patients, and 2) exaggerated inspiratory muscle blood flow demand during exercise (arising from inspiratory muscle inefficiency) have in contributing to exercise intolerance and exertional dyspnea in HFpEF patients. The novel mechanistic questions we have developed combined with the cutting-edge measurements, innovative experimental design, and use of a clinically relevant intervention (i.e., inspiratory muscle training) will provide new targets to intervene on to improve exercise tolerance and exertional symptomology for HFpEF patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose using cutting-edge microelectrode recordings collected in the operating room to study unprecedented tumor-altered single cell activity at high resolution in the human brain in vivo paired with 3D computer vision-enabled mapping and direct electrical stimulation. This work will lead to a mechanistic basis for understanding how tumors alter activity in neurons and will allow us to test a novel high resolution diagnostic tool to generate a physiological map of the tumor boundary which could aid clinical decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomedical datasets relevant to fundamental biology and human health are increasingly deposited in centralized databases, enabling opportunities to train powerful machine learning models and perform large-scale meta-analyses. Unfortunately, poor metadata in biomedical databases is currently a barrier to these opportunities and thus there is a critical need for metadata curation. We will develop machine learning methodologies for automated standardization and enhancement of biomedical metadata, allowing the information contained within centralized biomedical databases to be used to the fullest extent possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Effector B cells (Beff) can profoundly influence the immune response by expressing inflammatory mediators that promote transplant rejection and autoimmunity. However, lack of identifying markers make Beff difficult to study. Moreover, factors regulating the development and function of Beff are poorly understood leaving no approach to manipulate their activity. We have now discovered that TIM-4 identifies Beff that express a variety of pro-inflammatory effector molecules. Studies in this proposal will allow us to determine how these cells and their inflammatory mediators are regulated, providing critical insights necessary to manipulate their activity to promote allograft survival and inhibit autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  NUP98-NSD1 fusion-positive acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a poor prognostic subtype in children and is frequently associated with co-occurring mutations in the transcription factor WT1. Focusing on the cellular and developmental context, our proposal aims to dissect mechanisms of action of the fusion oncoprotein NUP98- NSD1, investigate WT1's role in therapy resistance, and identify novel therapeutic targets for childhood AML. These results are poised to reshape our understanding of childhood susceptibility to AML and provide a rationale for therapeutic intervention in future clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Adoptive cellular therapy (ACT) has had dramatic impact on patients with blood cancers, however, these transferred immune cell therapies have a high relapse rate of >50% as they rarely lead to long-term functional anti-cancer immunity. Blood stem cells can be modified to express a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR), which would continuously renew cancer-targeted immune cells; however, in this case, all blood cell types, including those associated with cytokine release syndrome (CRS), would express the CAR, likely leading to unacceptable on-going risk of toxicity. Here, we propose to engineer the CAR vector so that blood stem cells stably carry the DNA (taking advantage of their ability to continuously re-populate all blood cell types and convey long-term anti- cancer immunity), while the mRNA, and thus the therapeutic protein, are only expressed in specific cancer- fighting immune cells, minimizing the risk of toxicity and enabling this therapeutic approach that can prevent relapse through long-lived anti-cancer immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphatic vessels act like miniature hearts to pump fluid from the tissues to prevent swelling, but these lymphatic pumps fail in lymphedema and contribute to a progressive and incurable swelling. This proposal is focused on determining how calcium handling in lymphatic muscle cells regulates lymphatic pumping and transcriptional control. We propose a set of experiments to investigate calcium signaling through a process called “store operated calcium entry” to maintain functional lymphatic muscle cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research seeks to enhance public health by pinpointing genetic markers that can forecast who is at risk for serious side effects from widely-used cancer immunotherapies, thereby enabling personalized treatment plans. By investigating how these genetic factors interact with immunological and somatic variables, we aim to improve the safety profile of these therapies, reducing healthcare burdens associated with treatment complications. The project has the potential to minimize treatment-related complications on a broad scale, thereby enhancing the overall quality of healthcare and contributing to a reduction in illness and disability across the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Mitochondria, the essential energy-generating compartment within cells, including neurons, are dysfunctional during aging and in neurodegenerative disorders. We have identified mitovesicles, a small, mitochondria- derived vesicle secreted by cells, and have demonstrated that their amount and content are altered in brains with mitochondrial dysfunction. In this proposal, we will examine the role of mitovesicles in maintaining mitochondrial function in neurons, determining the interrelationship between the most important Alzheimer's disease-risk gene, apolipoprotein E, and mitovesicle generation, mitochondrial health, and the impact of the mitovesicle system on neuron function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this proposal is to identify and validate novel genes and variants that cause congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), a common and severe birth defect that is poorly understood. We will use genomic data from our large, well-characterized CDH patient cohort to identify novel genes and variants associated with CDH, and prioritize these genes and variants for validation in mouse models. Using advanced genome editing approaches, we will validate candidate variants and study promising hits in depth, providing insight into the genetics and mechanisms that underly CDH pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of people are affected by benign bladder disorders, including overactive bladder, cystitis, recurrent urinary tract infection, and bladder pain syndrome that dramatically decrease quality of life. Urothelial cells, the cells that line the inside of the bladder, are thought to convey sensory and nociceptive information to the brain via sensory neurons, and urothelial cells and their signaling are often disrupted in these disorders. For these reasons, we plan to investigate the role of urothelial cells in sensory signaling and nociception using new innovative approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The mission of the PsycheMERGE Network is to advance equitable precision psychiatry in learning healthcare system frameworks across the United States. During the course of this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators at twelve academic medical centers will bring together clinical data (>29 million individuals), genetic data (>1.9 million), and an extraordinary range of scientific expertise (psychiatry, medical informatics, machine learning, statistics, genetics, sociomedical sciences, decision sciences, and ethics) to advance this mission. We will leverage this expertise and data to build on our prior success and address barriers to scalability, utility of genomic data, clinical application, and translation to clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Many patients with blood cancers now take pills to control their cancer, but it can be difficult for patients to start these medications in a timely manner and to consistently take their pills as prescribed. The reasons for these difficulties, the patients who face the most barriers, and the effects that delays and inconsistent pill taking may have on patients’ health are not well known. This study describes how long it takes patients to start their cancer pills and how they take them over time; identifies barriers they may face; and how patients’ health may be affected by their ability to start and continue taking their cancer pills.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive resilience to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and brain aging is a phenomenon whereby an individual’s cognitive functioning is better than predicted based on chronological age, genetic risk, and/or advanced neuropathology. Understanding the protective factors that improve cognitive resilience requires comprehensive identification of the protein components of unique brain cell types – an analysis that cannot be performed longitudinally in human patients. In this project, we will combine human clinical and molecular data with proteomic data from neurons and immune cells from the hippocampus of mice that are resilient and susceptible to cognitive decline to identify novel proteins and complexes that could ultimately be therapeutically targeted to delay or prevent cognitive symptoms in AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We uncovered a novel virulence function of the SARS-CoV-2 Nsp1 protein that results in inhibition of host gene expression, including those encoding antiviral factors, via targeting the cellular mRNA nuclear export pathway. Understanding how the mRNA nuclear export machinery is targeted by SARS-CoV-2 is of critical importance to understand viral pathogenicity and will reveal novel information on the molecular interactions leading to mRNA export and on the host antiviral defense mechanisms. Our studies may also aid in the development of novel therapeutic strategies that target Nsp1 function during SARS-CoV-2 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Basal epithelial cells play critical roles in maintaining a healthy corneal epithelium and are responsible for wound healing after corneal injury. We propose to characterize the diversity of basal epithelial cells in the central cornea, limbus, and conjunctiva and their roles in homeostasis and wound healing. Successful completion of this study will advance our understanding of the maintenance of a healthy corneal epithelium and reveal new targets for the treatment of severe corneal epithelial defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision Medicine has now been firmly incorporated into the routine standard-of-care in many medical specialties, in stark contrast with Psychiatry where quantitative predictors that guide clinical decision-making remain extremely limited. Our proposed studies aim to advance the goals of Precision Psychiatry by using artificial intelligence to build clinical outcome predictors of psychosis through integration of electronic health records, dimensional phenotyping, and genetic information, in addition to exploring the psychosocial impact on patients and clinicians. Our long-term goal is to advance the tools available for personalized approaches to diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis in mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Public Health Relevance Atherosclerosis kills more people than any other disease and is caused by cholesterol accumulating in arteries. Removing excess cholesterol from vascular smooth muscle cells in arteries may prevent atherosclerosis. Our proposed studies will use strategies that alter cholesterol removal pathways precisely in vascular smooth muscle cells, which may lead to the development of effective atherosclerosis treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to improve the delivery of agents that increase or decrease gene expression – which are named anti-sense oligonucleotides – in a selective and non-invasive manner to neurons in the brain. This research will involve conjugating anti-sense oligonucleotides to binding proteins (antibodies) that penetrate the blood-brain barrier, target proteins on neurons, release their conjugated agents after cellular internalization, and modulate gene expression. Successful completion of this research would enable a broad range of fundamental neuroscience and therapeutic applications, including treating diseases such as Dravet syndrome and other brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Better model systems are needed to study the impact of senescence and the senescence associated secretory phenotype (SASP) on early tumor formation in vivo. We hypothesize that irradiation or chemical insult of the mammary gland induces senescence, which can then drive the outgrowth of preneoplastic cells into tumors. We plan to test this model system by targeting senescent cells with senolytic agents, followed by studies targeting specific SASP factors, to gain insight into the mechanisms by which senescence drives early tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid abuse is a massive public health crisis; maintenance therapies can help wean people off opioids but additional therapeutic approaches are much needed. Here we propose to evaluate the effects of opioids on an overlooked neural circuit that plays a known role in nicotine dependence but that also expresses high levels of the receptor that opioids act on. This work will provide new information on how opioids induce dependence and new avenues for preventing or treating opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Cancer Clinical Trials Network (NCTN)-led clinical trials have transformed the landscape of the frontline management of patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) in the past decade. With an increased understanding of the role of measurable residual disease (MRD) in the contemporary management of CLL, the next generation of NCTN-led clinical trials will use MRD to guide the optimal duration and intensity of therapy. This proposal highlights my goals of helping to develop, implement, and complete these state-of- the-art NCTN-led clinical trials that will lead to a paradigm shift in the frontline management of CLL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement Aberrant calcium handling by the neuron’s major intracellular calcium store, the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), is associated with a host of neurodegenerative disorders, but it is unclear how ER calcium signaling regulates the function and stability of neurons in vivo. The mechanisms linking ER calcium handling to neuronal function are likely to be deeply conversed. By investigating the role of the ER in neuronal calcium signaling in the context of well-defined neural circuits in a tractable experimental system—the Drosophila visual system—we seek to provide an essential mechanistic framework for understanding how ER calcium uptake and release contribute to brain function in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Syphilis is becoming an increasingly urgent public health issue, however, existing methods for the clinical diagnosis of syphilis are lacking with respect to speed, availability, cost, and time to resulting, and are also subject to false testing results under certain circumstances. This proposal outlines the development and validation of an inexpensive, specific, rapid, and ultrasensitive strategy for diagnosing syphilis infections using sensors based on aptamers, which are short single-stranded DNA molecules able to bind target proteins. These technologies will be immediately translatable and practical for clinical diagnostics, and will provide enhanced capabilities in support of rapid, point of care testing for syphilis infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will elucidate how the brain adaptively solves sequential decision-making problems by focusing on three key areas implicated in many high-level cognitive operations, including the prefrontal cortex, basal ganglia, and hippocampus. The results will contribute to improving artificial intelligence and treatment of various psychiatric and neurological disorders, such as schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging cells show considerable deterioration of nuclear structure, but specific factors or events that cause the deterioration are poorly understood. This study uses the genetic model C. elegans to analyze cellular mechanisms that drive nuclear deterioration. A major focus is the formation and consequences of nuclear fat deposits that accumulate in some cell types during aging, and that have the potential to damage the nuclear envelope.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of these studies is to understand how sensory nerves in the skin regulate immune cell function during skin penetration by parasitic worms found in contaminated water. We think that protective immunity against these worms may be dependent on interactions between itch-specific nerves and immune cells in the skin, but this has not been studied before. The proposed experiments may uncover a therapeutic means to prevent skin penetration, which does not currently exist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: This study will examine the impact of school-located vaccination (SLV) on routine, influenza, and COVID-19 vaccination rates among school-aged children and adolescents in Colorado from 2018-2024, overall and among health disparity populations. We will use propensity score matching in extended Cox models to assess the causal impact of three SLV models: school-based health centers (SBHCs), school- located vaccination clinics (SLVCs) independent of an SBHC, and SLVCs run by an SBHC, on students’ vaccination likelihood; simulate potential local- and state-level impacts of SLVCs on routine, influenza, and COVID-19 vaccine coverage among all students in Colorado and members of health disparity populations; and use the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research and a modified positive deviance approach to examine contextual factors influencing recent implementation and success of the three models of SLV. Study findings will be immediately actionable for implementers and policymakers in Colorado and across the country as they work to address vaccination inequities exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic and prepare for future public health emergencies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Copy number variants are important genetic risk factors for autism and related neuropsychiatric disorders. This project aims to define neurodevelopmental mechanisms, as well as behavioral abnormalities, associated with 17q12 CNVs, genetic risk factors for autism and other neuropsychiatric disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) is characterized by attenuated capacity to recognize and interpret the emotional states of others. Despite the relevance of interpersonal function to AUD treatment and recovery, fundamental questions regarding social cognition during treatment and early abstinence remain unaddressed. The proposed project will characterize change in emotion processing, identify cognitive and affective mechanisms driving such change, and evaluate the causal contribution of disrupted emotion processing to critical treatment outcomes (e.g., treatment dropout, relapse).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed work is expected to result in the development of a brief, peer-led video intervention that will utilize innovative narrative communication strategies to deliver evidence-based principles for self-management of chronic musculoskeletal pain to older adults in order to expand treatment uptake and reach. Such results are expected to have an important positive impact on patient functioning that will move us closer to the long-term goal of widespread dissemination of evidence-based interventions for those with chronic pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed investigation is relevant to public health because it focuses on establishing the efficacy of an accessible telehealth exercise intervention specifically for rural cancer survivors experiencing cancer-related fatigue. Novel methods of remotely assessing objective physical function and performing state-of-the-art metabolomic analyses are utilized to investigate exercise-associated mechanisms of cancer-related fatigue remediation first in an underserved population that stands to benefit from subsequent innovations in exercise prescription due to existing health disparities. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the interest of the NCI Division of Cancer Control and Population Sciences in reducing the burden of cancer through improved survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The mission of the PsycheMERGE Network is to advance equitable precision psychiatry in learning healthcare system frameworks across the United States. During the course of this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators at twelve academic medical centers will bring together clinical data (>29 million individuals), genetic data (>1.9 million), and an extraordinary range of scientific expertise (psychiatry, medical informatics, machine learning, statistics, genetics, sociomedical sciences, decision sciences, and ethics) to advance this mission. We will leverage this expertise and data to build on our prior success and address barriers to scalability, utility of genomic data, clinical application, and translation to clinical practice.

She is conducting work closely related to Dr. Xiao-Jing Wang’s project 2 of the CO HNC SPORE CA261605 Immunotherapy has a limited response rate in the treatment of recurrent and metastatic oral cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Persons of African Ancestry (PAA) are at the epicenter of the obesity and AD epidemics; this higher risk may begin in middle-age. We propose to extend our current Tobago Brain Study to measure circulating levels of AD in middle-aged men and women, and assess the influence of adipo-myokines and cardiometabolic conditions. Our results may advance our understanding of the biological determinants of adiposity-related AD in a high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Our preliminary results show that heterochronic mutations that cause precocious neuronal differentiation result in early-onset neurodegeneration. This proposal describes a comprehensive and multifaceted set of experiments aimed at understanding the relationship between the timing of neuronal differentiation and the timing of neurodegeneration. The ability to focus on mechanisms and control of neurodegeneration in a single neuron type (nociceptive neurons) in vivo, and to readily employ complementary experimental approaches, will allow us to describe the process at a resolution that is not readily attainable in other systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millisecond timescale sensorimotor feedback control of the tongue is necessary for eating, drinking, speaking, and maintenance of airway patency, and aspiration pneumonia due to dysphagia is a leading cause of death in neurological disease. Combining high speed tongue videography and deep learning based image segmentation, we track tongue kinematics with high precision and find that when mice lick at a spout they use information about unexpected misses and touches to rapidly (<50 milliseconds) re-steer their tongue - revealing important online control processes previously studied in primate reaching. To test for general control principles and to determine how cortex, cerebellum, basal ganglia and brainstem control the tongue, we combine recording and manipulation in head-fixed mice engaged in carefully designed lick tasks requiring rapid sensorimotor feedback control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) The incidence of neuroendocrine tumors has increased nearly 10-fold over the last four decades, and neuroblastoma is the embryonal neuroendocrine tumor accounting for 15% of pediatric cancer-related deaths resulting in a significant public health burden. Alpha-emitter radioligand therapy (α-RLT) is an exciting emerging treatment resulting in enhanced tumor responses (up to 80%) and even complete responses in some patients. Understanding how α-RLT dosing can be optimized with novel diagnostic and nephroprotective therapies to increase tumor response and reduce long-term kidney damage is expected to provide essential data needed for future clinical trial design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria that cause ocular infections are becoming increasingly resistant to antimicrobials used in ophthalmology, leading to recalcitrance to cure and treatment failure that can result in serious morbid consequences such as blindness and loss of the eye. This proposal will combine the latest developments in DNA sequencing, microbial enrichment methods and bioinformatics to develop a precision diagnostic tool able to identify the causative agent of the infection and predict antimicrobial agents to which the organism is resistant in a timely and sensitive manner, supporting the use of targeted and effective therapies at early stages of the disease. This work will ultimately provide an innovative diagnostic test extensively optimized for clinical application that has the potential to significantly advance clinical management and help improve the care of patients suffering from sight-threatening infections.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The worldwide burden of HSV infection requires a better understanding of virus-host interactions. We propose to define critical determinants of effective immunity that rapidly eliminates HSV before viral dissemination in the skin and mucosal epithelium. This knowledge is central to developing novel interventions and a successful vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the availability of symptomatic treatments and surgeries, ~10% of the 70 million patients suffering from glaucoma reach permanent blindness. Trabecular meshwork cell loss is an early event in the development of glaucoma and is accelerated in the case of mutant myocilin. Our proposed studies will identify the mechanisms underlying mutant myocilin cytotoxicity and lay the foundation for new disease modifying glaucoma therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative A mechanistic understanding of how the gut microbiota influences the development and progression of Celiac Disease is currently missing. This project aims to dissect the complex metabolic interactions between the microbiota and the host in Celiac Disease. This will help establish causal relationships between the gut microbiota and the disease, paving the way for the development of therapeutic strategies that target the gut microbiota to treat Celiac Disease

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose performing metagenomic deep sequencing on conjunctival and rectal swabs that have been collected as part of several previous NIH-funded trachoma studies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This clinical trial is focused on prevention of lymphedema by immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) at the time of ALND in patients treated for inflammatory breast cancer (IBC), who have almost double the rate of lymphedema compared with the overall breast cancer patient population, to improve the quality-of-life in cancer survivors. The study proposal will determine the incidence of clinical lymphedema in IBC patients following ILR, establish a longitudinal, dynamic, imaging-based profile of changes in lymphatic vessel architecture and function following ILR using near-infrared fluorescence lymphatic imaging (NIRF-LI), and characterize longitudinal changes in serum inflammatory cytokines/ chemokines following this surgery, comparing these metrics in patients that develop lymphedema following ILR with those that do not. If successful, our work would provide impetus to change the surgical standard-of-care for patients with IBC and help direct the highest risk patients to specialized treatment centers for surgical intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaginal candidiasis is a widespread fungal infection that affects over 75% of women. Approximately 15% of women experience vaginal yeast infections recurrently, resulting in serious impacts on quality of life and significant cost burden. There are no licensed vaccines to any fungal pathogens, and mechanisms of host immunity remain poorly understood. This project seeks to understand the role of specific immune cytokines in limiting infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB), caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), is the leading cause of death from a single infectious agent. The lack of understanding of the protective immunity against TB significantly hinders the development of more effective therapeutics and vaccines. This proposal seeks to define the underlying mechanism that regulate how lung alveolar macrophages (AMs) respond to early Mtb infection, allowing us to leverage AMs for novel host-directed therapies and more effective vaccines against TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legionella pneumophila (Lp), agent of a form of pneumonia known as Legionnaires’ disease, persists in a wide range of water systems due to its capacity to survive at high temperatures, grow in amoebae, and persist in biofilms, and once in the mammalian lung, flourishes by infecting macrophages. Independently of other components encoded within a Lp CRISPR-Cas locus, the Cas2 ribonuclease confers upon Lp the ability to survive heat shock, infect amoebae and macrophages, and form biofilms, and this novel, non-canonical function is due at least in part to the ability of Cas2 to promote the expression of a previously undefined heat shock protein (HspC2). Thus, the proposed studies seek to establish a new paradigm by deciphering how Cas2 controls the expression of the hspC2 gene to promote the thermal tolerance and virulence of a human pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Alveolar soft part sarcoma is a deadly cancer that is caused by a mutation resulting in the aberrant fusion of two genes, ASPSCR1 and TFE3. Alterations in gene expression caused by the fusion protein depend on interactions with a protein unfolding machine known as VCP. This study aims to define the role of VCP in driving the altered gene expression associated with the ASPSCR1-TFE3 fusion protein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addressing disparities in health and healthcare for minoritized older adults requires innovation in aging research at the nexus of geriatric medicine, gerontology, and palliative care research. Community Based Participatory Research (CBPR) is an important and promising strategy to meet this challenge because it has been shown to reduce health disparities, decrease distrust in healthcare system, and result in positive health outcomes. To accomplish the goal of leveraging the candidate’s leadership in health equity and CBPR to create a training program in CBPR that will result in a path towards health equity for older adults, the candidate will (1) Build a national CBPR training program focusing on health equity in older populations; (2) Measure program outcomes, and (3) Develop a program sustainability plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The brain receives signals from all of our internal organs through the sensory vagus nerve, but the way in which this information modulates individual neurons and circuits is not understood. This proposal investigates how internal organ information is represented in the sensory vagus nerve. Our work will then enable investigating how each internal organ signal influences brain function and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Influenza, especially aggressive types like H1N1, can severely damage lungs, leading to dysplastic repair and the formation of Krt5+ basal cell pods in the damaged alveolar. Our research is centered on a protein, "Ezh2", which appears to diverge from its conventional role within the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) to uniquely regulate basal cell behavior following influenza infection. The goals of this proposal are to study the unique role of Ezh2 in regulating basal cell dynamic post severe influenza infection and aim to offer insights into improving lung repair following influenza infections and potentially other lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the role that implicit bias plays in clinical dentistry—both in clinician decision-making and in the recruitment/ retention of the oral health workforce—is essential to advancing health equity and closing the gap in health disparities. The current project focuses on clinician decision-making by establishing a baseline prevalence of implicit bias among dentists in the United States and supporting dentists with implicit bias training. To advance diversity in the workforce, this project will provide psychosocial support to help students actively pursuing careers in the biomedical research enterprise mitigate the effects of implicit bias and other barriers to successful entry into the oral health workforce.

PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health because it will identify key pathologic pathways and identify novel therapeutic targets in choroideremia, which causes blindness early in life and has no treatment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Consumption of a Western Diet, high in saturated fat and sugar, during the adolescent phase of development impairs hippocampal-dependent learning and memory function during adulthood. The hippocampus is also known to regulate aspects of food intake control that are relevant for obesity, including impulsive behaviors to obtain and consume palatable yet otherwise unhealthy food. We propose to determine the impact of an adolescent Western Diet on food impulsive behavior, identify the neurobiological circuits involved, and determine whether the impact of the diet can be reversed by exercise and/or treatment with a GLP1R agonist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood-forming stem cells in the bone marrow regenerate blood and immune cells throughout life. Defects in stem cell maintenance that occur during aging lead to anemia, impaired immunity, bone marrow failure, and leukemia, but the underlying cause of these defects is largely unknown. This proposal will examine if blood-forming stem cell maintenance and longevity is regulated by errors in protein synthesis, and if increasing the fidelity of protein synthesis delays onset of age-related stem cell defects and extends lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE  Antigen presentation is a critical component of anti-tumor immunity. While numerous classes of tumor specific antigens have been described, a deep understanding of the most clinically valuable immune targets and the mechanisms by which they are presented remains limited. In this proposal, we will utilize a multidisciplinary approach to understand non-canonical antigens in lung cancer that will pave the way forward to broaden the antigen repertoire that can be targeted for next-generation precision immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  QS-21 is an adjuvant sourced from the Chilean soapbark tree (Quillaja saponaria) that is utilized in four FDA-approved vaccines; however, current methods to improve its immunogenicity by diversifying its molecular structure (i.e., plant biosynthesis or chemical synthesis) and learning structure-activity relationships are limited. Our extraordinary discovery that yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) can be engineered to produce QS-21 from simple sugars and our extensive experience characterizing the immunogenic profiles of small molecules like QS- 21 uniquely position us to design improved QS-21 analogs. Herein, we propose to engineer adjuvants by iteratively diversifying their molecular structures (synthetic biology) and discovering their molecular-level immunogenic mechanisms (systems-level immunology), enabling the design and deployment of best-in-class adjuvants that transform the treatment and prevention of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. The parent award involves the development and application of machine learning methods that can be used to prioritize natural products with therapeutically relevant bioactivities and provide insight into natural product structure activity relationships. One strategy for bioactive natural product discovery currently being pursued by a graduate student working on this project, Adrian Russ, is to apply our machine learning-guided genome mining to understudied taxa of bacteria that are more likely to produce novel compounds. This supplement will support Adrian’s research project and career development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although astrocytes are key components of brain circuits underlying voluntary behaviors and proposed an important layer of regulating social behaviors, yet the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We will investigate astrocyte and neuron interactions in regulating social novelty recognition that involve glutamatergic signaling using multi-layered cutting edge experimental evaluation with computational approaches. At its conclusion, this work will illuminate novel targets that can reduce the devastating social behavior-related psychiatric and medical consequences such as autism spectrum disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Osteosarcoma is a extremely aggressive bone tumor with a high propensity to metastasize, which is associated with an extremely poor prognosis and thus in dire need of more effective targeted therapies. However, with the incorporation of novel mono-therapeutic agents directed at targeting relapsed and metastatic disease, there is a high propensity for the development of resistance. Thus, the identification of molecular mechanisms of resistance and rational, synergistic combination therapies is particularly relevant to the NIH’s mission toward the identification of novel therapeutic interventions that can be implemented to prevent and treat this highly aggressive pediatric cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding the underlying mechanisms that cause or worsen age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a common form of blinding eye disease. The results of the proposed research are expected to enable identification of novel therapeutic strategies to reduce sub-retinal fibrosis and inflammation, which are not addressed by current AMD treatments. This project is well-aligned with the NEI’s mission because it is a cutting-edge research project that will enhance understanding of AMD pathophysiology and has strong potential to catalyze advancements in the prevention and treatment of AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with chronic temporomandibular disorder (TMD) pain are at increased risk for alcohol-related consequences compared to those without pain, and growing evidence suggests pain is a potent motivator for alcohol use in many individuals. However, few systematic examinations of modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors, including orofacial pain status, have been conducted. This project addresses this gap in knowledge by determining the effect of pain on drinking topography in heavy drinkers with and without chronic TMD pain in both the laboratory and daily life.

PHR: Project Narrative: The high salt diet stimulates the production of sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) in the kidneys to increase the excretion of extra sodium load. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety disorders among youth are extremely common and without effective treatment can lead to depression, substance use, suicide, and deficits in functioning into adulthood. Although pediatric anxiety interventions, such as cognitive behavioral therapy and antidepressant medications, are highly efficacious, many clinicians are under-using these evidence-based treatments. We will develop and test two complementary casemix-adjusted pediatric anxiety outcome quality measures using the GAD-7 instrument: (1) a measure of whether patients are responding to treatment (treatment response) and (2) a whether patients’ anxiety remitted (remission), which will provide a critical tool for improving outcomes from anxiety treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Existing devices to stimulate the posterior tibial nerve to treat overactive bladder either require frequent clinical visits or utilize complicated and expensive implantable devices placed many millimeters or even centimeters from the targeted nerve. This leads to inconsistent activation of the posterior tibial nerve, as well as device related adverse events. In this study, we will develop a novel minimally invasive electrode strategy consisting of only 2 implanted passive materials, and an associated surgical tool that allows for direct targeting of the nerve to improve nerve engagement while reducing complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Autistic people have significantly heightened risk of suicide deaths and suicide behavior (SB), yet there is limited understanding of mutable factors related to risk of SB for the autistic population. There is a significant need to understand how interdependent individual, community, and policy factors influence risk of SB and mental health service receipt to contribute to the long-term goal of reducing risk of SB for the autistic population. In collaboration with an established team of autistic stakeholders and policy and practice experts, this project will identify and characterize multilevel, socioecological factors associated with risk of SB and receipt of mental health services among autistic people, and generate evidence-based, community-supported recommendations for suicide prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: New technologies in genomics and proteomics have revealed thousands of previously undiscovered, yet functional, microproteins encoded in the human genome. In this study, we will demonstrate that an understudied, plentiful class of microproteins that overlap known human protein coding sequences has important roles in human cells, and that their expression relies on novel mRNA mechanisms that reprogram the coding potential of human genes. This project will therefore reveal entirely new dimensions of complexity and regulation of human protein-coding genes, with important implications for human biology and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ability to measure tissue oxygen levels has enormous clinical significance for reliable prognosis and treatment of several diseases, including cancer and vascular diseases. We propose to develop an innovative oxygen measurement device called OxyTrack for use in the clinic. The new device will be a valuable tool for clinical conditions where tissue oxygen is a critical variable for decision making, e.g., cancer patients and patients with diabetic peripheral vascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) are used by millions of Americans, however we do not understand their long-term health effects. This research proposal will quantify the effects of long-term ENDS use on validated and novel biomarkers of cardiovascular and pulmonary disease and how they are influenced by use heaviness, age, body weight, and co-use of other products. The importance of this study does not rest upon demonstrating adverse effects of ENDS use and will produce the most informative evidence to date on how long-term ENDS use affects cardiovascular and pulmonary health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE B cells can profoundly influence the immune response by expressing cytokines and co-receptors that either promote (effector B cells) or regulate (regulatory B cells) autoimmunity and anti-tumor immunity. We discovered that TIM-1 identifies B cells that possess regulatory properties by binding to phosphatidylserine expressed on apoptotic bodies. In this R01 we will determine the molecular mechanisms and transcription factors that induce Tim-1 expressing B cells with an aim to identify targets by which the regulatory properties of B cell can be manipulated to regulate autoimmunity and anti-tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Blood stem cells live in a complex microenvironment or “niche” in the bone marrow and are supported by many different types of cells. We want to understand how blood stem cells interact with niche cells when they are developing in the embryo and in adulthood. We believe defining these cellular interactions will improve our ability to make blood stem cells in the lab, and to improve outcomes for patients who receive blood stem cell transplants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Large-scale longitudinal microbiome studies offer an improved understanding of how changes in the microbiome are related to disease development and treatment efficacy, yet the dearth of available robust statistical tools has held back their potential. Within the context of several important longitudinal microbiome profiling studies, this proposal aims to develop statistical and computational approaches for enabling a more robust and sophisticated understanding of how microbes interact with exposures or outcomes over time. This information represents an imperative point of investigation both for possibly improving etiology and for possible development of microbiota-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrhythmias represent a major public health burden and remain a leading cause of mortality in the United States. Our proposed studies at the cellular, organ and animal levels will provide novel in vivo data on the specific role of the B56α regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) in the regulation of the late (arrhythmogenic) sodium current and arrhythmias. Findings from this work will provide the very first insights into the impact of a PP2A activating molecule on the cardiac action potential and arrhythmias.

The proposed study will elucidate the neural circuits underlying the generation of positive and negative infant-directed behaviors using mice as an animal model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Maintenance of genome integrity is essential for life and when impaired can lead to disease, cancer in particular. Among the DNA damage types that occur continuously, double-strand DNA breaks are particularly deleterious and present great cancer risk. Successful completion of studies in our proposal will reveal the molecular mechanisms by which a family of proteins called RAD51 paralogs perform their essential function in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks and will provide a platform for the development of novel cancer therapeutics for breast, ovarian, and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Specialized blood vessels called venous sinusoids are the nurse cells for HSCs in the marrow, but the mechanism by which they support hematopoiesis is not known. Using zebrafish, we have reprogrammed liver sinusoids to support HSPCs, providing a new location for stem cells when infiltrative processes affect the marrow such as myelofibrosis, and have also found a lipid that regulates the interaction between sinusoids and HSCs. Our studies have an impact on how sinusoids support stem cells’ expansion and will enhance current treatments for myelofibrosis and hematological disorders that require HSC transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transposable elements are selfish genetic elements that occupy nearly half of the human genome and have been associated with inherited diseases, cancer, and aging-associated diseases. This proposal will identify dietary factors that influence organisms’ defense mechanisms against transposable elements and investigate the consequential functional and health outcomes. Findings from this proposal will provide a novel perspective for gauging the full impact of how nutrition impacts health, which is critical to guiding dietary choices and interventions that support human health and prevent disease.
