IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Non-activated CAR T cells are a novel platform for T cell-based immunotherapies, generating enhanced potency and accessibility to more patients. We will explore mechanisms to further enhance the potency of non-activated T cells by inhibiting IFN1 which limits transduction and overall functional competence. We will also focus on restoring the expression of viral-associated proteins, and concurrently modulating the IFN1 response in quiescent T cells, to enhance transduction efficiency, which is a critical barrier to the use of these cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it aims to understand the cues guiding tooth develop- ment, which can be used to develop better preventative and treatment strategies for our dentition. This re- search stands to reveal candidates to test in follow-up tooth regeneration experiments that could help develop new pulp therapies and greatly improve dental healthcare at all stages of life. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIDCR’s mission to improve dental healthcare through research and dissemination of health information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Changes in kidney health are believed to be common during medical treatment to lower blood pressure because clinicians use an antiquated monitoring approach based on blood creatinine levels. This research proposal will develop and evaluate an improved method for assessing kidney health based on urine proteins that originate within the kidneys. Our goal is to change the paradigm for kidney health monitoring and allow more people to achieve hypertension control and healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: Project Narrative Social behavior is a key element of mammalian function and impairments are a core feature of Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). There are known genes that influence social function, and genetic risk factors for ASD, but the influence of these genes on neural circuits of social behavior is mostly unknown. Understanding the impact of these genetic factors on these neural circuits is necessary to uncover how they influence social function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Calcium oxalate kidney stones are a common, recurrent condition (affecting about 10% of the US population) with increasingly prevalence, but preventative treatments are only incompletely effective. Stones are aggregates of calcium oxalate crystals held together by a complex mixture of urinary proteins, though the matrix phase and its role in mechanical strength is poorly understood. The proposed experiments will characterize the protein-protein interactions and their influence on protein-crystal interactions involved in stone formation, so that we can better understand matrix contributions and design better treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the ecological and epidemiological dynamics underpinning emerging bat-borne viruses and how risks are altered by human activities. We will focus on three important and tractable host-virus systems: coronaviruses, rabies lyssavirus, and Bombali ebolavirus, in their wild bat hosts in the Taita Hills, Kenya and Orange Walk, Belize. This research will represent an unusually comprehensive and detailed investigation into the dynamics of viruses in wild bat populations and provide a critical advance towards evidence-based risk prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In burn injuries, healing wounds and managing the associated itch and pain are critical but often not addressed sufficiently. Our project aims to explore how Langerhans cells and sensory neurons interact and impact wound healing, itch, and pain following burn injuries. By understanding these interactions, we hope to uncover new insights into Langerhans cell functions and develop innovative therapeutic strategy for burn injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Strong attentional control can protect cognitive function when the brain is injured and inflamed, which makes attentional control a potentially powerful tool for reducing the incidence and impact of delirium and dementia. This work will explore neural mechanisms behind attentional resilience—the ability to maintain strong attentional control despite physiological stressors—using the natural experiment of scheduled surgery in cognitively intact older adults. By studying neural mechanisms that allow for robust attentional control capacity before surgery and attentional resilience after surgery, we expect to identify mechanistic targets which may inform future interventions to protect cognition in older adults at risk for delirium and dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite significant improvements in treatment-adapted strategies, over 70% of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients cannot be cured with contemporary therapies, underscoring the unmet medical need to identify new therapeutic target(s) and develop improved strategies. This proposal aims to investigate the role of METTL1, an enzyme responsible for tRNA 7-methylguanosine (m7G) modification, in AML pathogenesis and leukemia stem cell homeostasis, and explore the underlying molecular mechanism(s). Additionally, we have identified a potent and selection small molecule inhibitor of METTL1 and will assess its therapeutic potential, either alone or in combination with other therapeutic agents, for the treatment of high-risk AMLs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans have both the highest incidence and mortality of lung cancer compared to any other racial/ethnic group. To address this urgent public health concern, this study aims to reduce disparities and the burden of lung cancer among AA smokers by supporting a Multiple-level intervention integrating lung cancer screening and smoking cessation{MILS), followed the NIH DEIA strategies using multilevel interventions that impact determinants of health and address health disparities at appropriate time points across the life course. The results of the study will directly guide the development of targeted strategies to improve lung cancer screening rates among minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Aicardi Goutières syndrome (AGS) is a progressive, autoinflammatory encephalopathy caused by genetic mutations in nucleic acid sensing and processing machinery that leads to overproduction of type I interferon. How systemic IFN production leads to predominant neuropathology is unknown but is imperative to understand for therapy development. This proposal uses mouse models of AGS that recapitulate neuropathology, paired with new gene and cell targeting approaches to uncover the cells, which drive pathology in order to facilitate therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute lung injury (ALI) is a clinical syndrome of acute respiratory failure with high morbidity and mortality, and is associated with an uncontrolled inflammatory response due to excessive production of cytokines and other inflammatory mediators. We recently discovered a significant upregulation of specific tRNA- and rRNA-derived short non-coding RNAs (sncRNAs) in a Lipopolysaccharide-induced ALI model. Our project aims to comprehensively investigate the dysregulation of these sncRNAs in human and mouse ALI models and to elucidate their role in cytokine overproduction and immune cell infiltration, thus contributing to a deeper understanding of the molecular pathogenesis of ALI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Obesity is associated with increased risk of metabolic disorders including fatty liver disease, but the mechanisms underlying this connection are not fully understood. Work from our lab and others has demonstrated that in the liver, obesity is associated with striking changes in sub-cellular architecture, particularly of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and its interaction with other organelles. Here, we will investigate the relationship between ER structure and function in metabolic regulation and disease, which we anticipate will reveal novel strategies to treat metabolic-associated fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses a critical unmet medical need for patients with liver disease and associated kidney injury. The studies in this proposal will provide key and potentially paradigm-changing insights to the role of kidney and biliary tract bile acid transport in the development of those disorders. The studies are predicted to have a therapeutically significant impact on the development of medical therapies for patients suffering from cholestatic liver diseases such as Primary Biliary Cholangitis, Progressive Familial Intrahepatic Cholestasis, and Alagille Syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiological studies have found a strong link between obesity and colorectal cancer and experimental studies in mice substantiate these claims. Based on our convincing preliminary data that shows that the cannabis plant can reduce inflammation and metabolic dysregulation – factors that are associated with driving tumorigenesis - we will test the hypothesis that the cannabis plant can reduce meta-inflammation and subsequent metabolic dysfunction in obesity-associated colorectal cancer. This work will provide Chrisitan with extensive training in mouse models of cancer, in immune profiling, and in assessing microbiome and metabolite signatures, as well as career development that will provide a platform for Christian to launch his independent career focused on metabolic dysregulation and cancer risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop new genomic methods for mapping the interactions of proteins and snRNPs to pre- mRNA that are essential to gene function and are often disrupted by mutations causing human disease. An important goal in medical genetics is to identify deleterious sequence variants in patient genomes, but it is currently difficult to predict the effects of many mutations on splicing. By identifying all the binding sites for the U1 snRNP, the LASR complex, and U2AF, we will be able better recognize pathogenic mutations in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse midline gliomas (DMGs) are deadly brain tumors in children. Clinical translation of our studies has the potential to improve outcomes and quality of life for children with this pernicious form of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Sepsis is a leading cause of in-hospital mortality and involves a heterogeneous and dysregulated host immune response to infection. This proposal seeks to advance our understanding and management of sepsis by profiling the immune response and detecting microbial pathogens in blood samples from 1,563 patients enrolled in the multicenter CLOVERS trial, using a technique called metagenomic sequencing. Together, this work will achieve the following specific aims: 1) understand the microbial causes of sepsis, 2) identify subgroups of sepsis patients with distinct immunologic and microbiologic characteristics that may be uniquely treatment-responsive, and 3) develop a novel molecular blood test to accurately predict sepsis outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Ventral tegmental area (VTA) dopamine neurons are essential for associative learning of reward and aversion-related cues, updating learned associations by prediction errors, as well as supporting a value of rewarding and aversive outcomes that each play foundational roles in psychiatric disorders. While it is well established that VTA dopamine neurons show heterogenous signaling patterns related to these motivationally- relevant events, as well as express diverse molecular characteristics such as the release of dopamine alone or co-release with glutamate, our understanding of how dopaminergic molecular heterogeneity contributes to VTA dopamine neuron functions are unclear. This research program will comprehensively determine the involvement of specific subtypes of dopamine and glutamate VTA neurons, as well as the neurotransmitters they distinctly release, in reward and aversion-based motivated behaviors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE National guidelines to reduce maternal mortality from uncontrolled hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (HDP) recommend blood pressure (BP) measurement 3-10 days after discharge and at least one preventive care visit within one year of delivery, yet adverse social determinants of health reduce adherence to these guidelines. The proposed public health study responds to research gaps and needs to address uncontrolled HDP, as recently identified by the US Preventative Services Task Force, by yielding high-quality evidence on the effectiveness of an innovative technology-based, statewide collaborative care model for postpartum people with hypertension—RI-SPHERES—in reducing rates of persistently elevated hypertension in the first six weeks after delivery and increasing the proportion of patients with HDP who receive HTN-related preventive care within a year of childbirth. As part of this study, we also plan to develop an implementation toolkit for widespread dissemination of RI-SPHERES in other states, which would provide a scalable, low-cost intervention that is broadly applicable to communities throughout the country and would reduce the overall incidence of maternal mortality and decrease racial and ethnic disparities for Black/Latinx patients with HDP during the immediate and remote postpartum period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sudden cardiac death due to ventricular arrhythmias is the leading cause of death in the U.S., prematurely taking the lives of more than 300,000 U.S. citizens each year. The goal of this project is to use mathematical modeling and computer simulations to discover novel antiarrhythmic therapies to prevent this deadly manifestation of heart diseases and to identify ECG markers for risk prediction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colorectal cancer accounts for 8-9% of all cancer-related deaths in the U.S. in both women and men, and estimates predict it will account for 52,550 deaths in 2023. The long-term goal for this research is to provide novel therapeutic strategies to treat patients with metastatic disease by targeting PGC-1β signaling. Additionally, we hope to develop treatment strategies with tolerable side effects to lengthen and improve the quality of life after a diagnosis of metastatic colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will develop a real-world data platform to advance clinical research in post-stroke cogni- tive impairment and dementia (PSCID). It is relevant to public health, as it will not only address critical gaps in epidemiology of PSCID, but will also provide a robust scientific foundation to investigate potential therapeutic targets for PSCID that now afflicts 2.2 million stroke survivors in the US. Thus, the proposed research is highly aligned with the goal of the National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s Disease, which seeks to treat and prevent Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias by 2025.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop a new strategy to engineer “helper” CD4+ T cells that orchestrate the function of other immune cells in tumors to allow these cells to better activate immune responses. We will then apply this strategy to tumor targeting CD4 T cells obtained from patient tumors with the goal of inducing anti-tumor immune responses and clinical benefit in patients. We hope this project will lead to a clinical trial of this approach in patients with melanoma and other solid tumors who have failed existing therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide and among the leading causes of death in women, and the vast majority of breast cancer deaths result from metastatic recurrences following treatment. Understanding how cancer cells spread to distant sites, persist as dormant disseminated tumor cells, and eventually recur is essential to developing therapies to kill dormant DTCs and prevent metastatic recurrences. We previously identified a role for the antioxidant transcription factor NRF2 in promoting breast cancer recurrence following therapy, and in this proposal we will build on this work to elucidate the regulation and function of NRF2 in breast cancer metastasis.

ORG_NAME: ST. JOSEPH'S HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Stroke remains a leading cause of death and disability worldwide, creating a huge socio-economic societal burden. Aberrant endothelial C3a/C3aR signaling post-stroke exacerbates BBB dysfunction, inflammation, synaptic loss, and functional deficits. Our study will contribute to our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying stroke to facilitate the future translation of therapeutics to prevent brain tissue injury and long-term functional and cognitive impairment post-stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotics frequently fail to resolve chronic infections because bacteria in the host environment adopt physiological states that are highly tolerant to antibiotics. Our work investigates how the host nutrient environment drives the bacterial physiologies that underpin chronic infections: slow growth and biofilm formation. Studying clinically-relevant physiologies in diverse bacteria will inspire new therapeutic approaches that are capable of resolving chronic infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) carries a dismal prognosis. The unmet need is our inability to provide molecular and metabolic information to characterize of the chronic inflammatory state of the pancreatic tumor microenvironment for delineating the extent of the pancreatic cancer for specific diagnosis and individualized treatments and to monitor treatment responses. The goal of this proposal is to develop a small molecule 18F-CCR2 antagonist as the positron emission tomography (PET) tracer for non-invasive molecular and metabolic imaging of PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developmental motor skills, such as learning to walk or speak, first start as highly variable behaviors that then gradually become more consistent as the skill is successfully learned. Deficits in the stabilization of motor control are associated with motor disorders such as developmental dyspraxia, yet the biological basis of this dysfunction is poorly understood. The goal of the proposed research is to understand the molecular mechanisms in a cortical motor circuit that regulate this transition from variable to precise motor skill action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE In up to 5% of people with diabetes it is due to a defect in a single gene and these varieties of diabetes provide opportunities for precision medicine. A current challenge is our inability to correctly interpret the hundreds of rare and often unique DNA changes in the protein coding sequence of these genes which leads to uncertainty over the genetic diagnosis. We will address this by generating comprehensive variant maps which catalogue the impact of sequence change on protein function and provide a roadmap for implementing similar efforts across all medically actionable diabetes genes to accelerate precision medicine for people with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HBV chronically infects >250 million people and remains a significant public health burden, despite the availability of an effective prophylactic vaccine for more than 30 years. Immunological control of HBV, i.e. functional cure, is possible, as evidenced by HBV natural history in some infected populations, but the immune correlates of protection remain undefined. Here we will define the immune responses mediating functional cure and identify pathways of immune dysfunction that could be targeted by specific immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative With nearly 68% of all epilepsies now thought to have a genetic cause, including many childhood epilepsies that are in desperate need of more effective therapies, our proposal is squarely focused on a timely and significant unmet need in the epilepsy community. While it is possible to generate mutant mice for all known human epilepsy genes, doing so would be time consuming, expensive and labor intensive. An alternative pre-clinical animal model, zebrafish offer significant advantages for in vivo analysis of gene function and drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative About 10% of older bereaved adults will develop Prolonged Grief Disorder, a psychiatric condition associated with significant impairment that, if left untreated, is associated with adverse health outcomes. We will examine the prevalence, risk, and protective factors associated with PGD in the Nurses’ Health Study, Nurses' Health Study 2, and Health Professionals Follow-up Study, which are large, longitudinal cohorts of older populations at risk of bereavement. Results will deliver insights into risk and protective factors that can inform primary prevention efforts for the millions of older adults currently at risk of PGD, generating evidence to guide strategic bereavement care that addresses this looming public health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Newly available large-scale human neurobiological data offer an unprecedented opportunity for biologically- grounded, data-driven stratification of psychiatric disorders—a major public health concern. The goal of this proposal is to develop and validate a novel computational framework for the identification, validation, and characterization of biological subtypes of psychiatric disorders using large-scale human brain imaging, phenotypic, and transcriptomic data, and to apply the framework to the study of autism. The framework developed here can be extended to examine other psychiatric disorders and can enable the development of more effective and precise diagnostic and treatment strategies for the disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Androgen receptor inhibition remains the most effective and among the least toxic interventions used to effectively control advanced prostate cancers. Reversing and even preventing resistance is of the highest importance to patients and clinicians given the lack of desirable, alternative treatment options. This proposal will develop a novel means of regulating androgen receptor inhibition sensitivity by modulating biochemical signaling in the microenvironment with a non-toxic agent that has entered clinical development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and related non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHL) account for a high number of patients with cancer. Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK) inhibitors have transformed the therapeutic landscape for patients; however, resistance to BTK inhibitors emerge on monotherapy and the mechanisms are incompletely understood. This project aims to identify the specific mechanisms underlying resistance to non-covalent BTK inhibitors and to identify the genomic basis for BTK inhibitor resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The capacity to regenerate complex organs varies greatly at different stages of development. Using skin as a model, we aim to identify genes that can functionally drive multi-lineage regeneration or scarring responses after wounding. These results are not only important for the mechanistic understanding of regeneration, but may also provide innovative therapeutic solutions to advance treatment strategies for wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Though critical in the healing process, our understanding of how local inflammation following extremity trauma is linked to the systemic immune response in the bone marrow is still poorly understood. Here, we propose a new paradigm where itaconate is synthesized at the injury site and trafficked back to the bone marrow by cycling neutrophils to regulate hematopoiesis. This proposal will establish a new mechanism by which the body coordinates the distant local injury site to the systemic immune response.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mark Ilgen, Ph.D. is a productive Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Researcher who is recognized nationally as a leader in the area of Addiction Health Services Research and is dedicated to improving care for Veterans with Substance Use Disorders (SUDs). His work is designed to enhance positive treatment outcomes and reduce potential adverse events for Veterans with SUDs, particularly for those who have comorbid pain or who are at increased risk of suicide. The proposed Research Career Scientist Award will support his continued research to enhance care for Veterans, as well as an expanded role in mentorship and training of early career scientists as the next generation of VHA health services researchers and leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in uptake of the new Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) vaccine by race/ethnicity will threaten potential public health gains from the vaccine. Through a community-based participatory research approach this study will focus on increasing RSV vaccine uptake among Latinos. In two trials we will determine the effectiveness of community health worker counseling and text-message interventions to (1) increase RSV vaccine uptake among older adults and (2) activate adults to discuss RSV vaccination with older adults in their social and family networks, while also gaining insights into the facilitators and barriers of these approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: We have designed a 3D tissue chip which includes an RPE monolayer sitting on a perfusable choroid containing anastomosed endothelial cells, fibroblasts and pericytes which eventually form a BrM to complete the structure. This proposal will utilize this model to characterize the responses of the RPE- choroid to various stressors under the influence of the CFH and ARMS2/HTRA1 risk genotypes.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospitalized children suffer harm from medical errors at a rate three times that of adults and depend on clinicians to exchange information with parents to identify and intercept errors. While access to information within clinical notes, which detail a child’s diagnoses, treatment and contingency plans, has prompted parents to identify safety concerns, less than 10% of parents access notes during their child’s hospital stay. The objective of this proposed multisite clinical trial is to evaluate the effect of Bedside Notes – a health IT intervention designed to improve parent note access and, in turn, parent engagement in safety concern reporting in the pediatric inpatient setting.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Bedside Notes: A multicenter trial to improve family clinical note access and outcomes for hospitalized children

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Rational combinatorial approaches are urgently needed to enhance immune checkpoint inhibitor efficacy in patients with liver metastases. We have discovered that liver metastases siphon and delete tumor-specific T cells to cause systemic immunotherapy resistance, and moreover that ablative liver-directed radiotherapy can restore immune checkpoint inhibitor efficacy. Herein we propose to evaluate mechanisms of immunotherapy resistance in melanoma patients and preclinical melanoma models of liver metastases as well as mechanistically define how liver SBRT overcomes immunotherapy resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiac rehabilitation, a structured program combining exercise training and risk factor management, may improve the health of patients with heart disease, but few eligible patients in the US receive the therapy. The proposed research will use novel statistical methods to examine the effectiveness of in-person and virtual cardiac rehabilitation in diverse populations, produce personalized estimates of benefit, and project the long- term effect of cardiac rehabilitation on population health and healthcare costs. The results of this study will help patients, clinicians, and policymakers make informed decisions about cardiac rehabilitation, and equitably advance the health of millions of US adults living with heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aortic stenosis (AS) is a progressive narrowing of the aortic valve that causes significant disability and premature mortality in older adults despite being treatable with a minimally invasive valve replacement procedure. The application proposes a multicenter randomized clinical trial evaluating a low-cost and practical artificial intelligence-based, 2-stage screening strategy for older adults that can detect advanced AS before the onset of symptoms. In addition, the concomitant challenge of a lack of a precision follow-up strategy for incidentally discovered early-stage aortic valve disease is addressed with a novel digital biomarker for AS progression that can define individuals at an elevated risk of rapid progression of AS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SRD5A2 is a critical enzyme for prostatic development and growth. Little is known about why patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) do not uniformly respond to SRD5A2 inhibitors. Building on our previous studies, we use an SRD5A2 null mouse model and human prostate tissues with BPH to identify a discrete subpopulation of prostate luminal epithelial cells that maintain prostate survival upon dihydrotestosterone restriction and their potential role in non-responsiveness to 5ARI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overcoming the burden of tobacco use among Latinos, the largest minority group in the U.S., demands innovative, effective, accessible, culturally appropriate, and community-engaged solutions. In partnership with the Latinos Contra el Tabaco Community Advisory Board, we developed Actívatexto, an innovative mobile intervention that integrates four components: 1) a text messaging program that promotes both smoking cessation and physical activity, 2) wearable devices to monitor physical activity, 3) smoking cessation pharmacotherapy (i.e., nicotine replacement therapies), and 4) an online dashboard where the research team manages participants’ incoming and outgoing data from both the text messaging program and wearable devices. We will assess the efficacy of Actívatexto (Aim 1), the mediators of the presumed treatment effect (Aim 2), and the barriers and facilitators of its implementation (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: COVID-19 and influenza vaccination are essential to reducing racial/ethnic disparities in infectious disease morbidity and mortality. However, African American/Black and Latino populations have serious barriers to COVID-19 and influenza vaccination and, therefore, insufficient vaccination rates. The proposed study will use the multiphase optimization strategy framework to address the problem of low COVID- 19 and influenza vaccination rates for this population: We will test the effects of four candidate intervention components and then create a efficient multicomponent intervention comprised of the most cost-effective combination of components, which can then be rapidly scaled up in community and outpatient health care settings to boost COVID-19 and influenza vaccination rates annually.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Increasing evidence suggests that selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) suppress height growth in young adolescents. In this application, we seek to determine the extent of SSRI-induced height growth suppression in mid-puberty, whether adult height would be ultimately reduced, and whether differences exist between the four most prescribed SSRIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE RUNX1 is mutated in a familial platelet disorder that predisposes these patients to blood cancer (FPDMM). This work will define what genes RUNX1 regulates, and it will also determine how RUNX1 controls the transcription of these genes to promote normal blood development. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke is a leading cause of long-term disability and to date, research has placed little emphasis on how to integrate carepartners (family members) into the rehabilitation process without increasing negative carepartner outcomes. We have developed and implemented a novel, web- based carepartner partner-focused intervention (CARE-CITE) designed to foster problem- solving and skill building while facilitating carepartner engagement during upper extremity practice of daily activities in the home setting. By providing a family-focused approach to rehabilitation interventions, this project will help develop more effective treatments that improve both carepartner and stroke survivor outcomes after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, chemotherapy-induced cognitive impairments have emerged as a major adverse effect affecting approximately 35% of 500,000 childhood cancer survivors. The findings of this proposal are critical towards elucidating dysregulation of PARP1-dependent NAD+ metabolic signaling pathways mediating chemotherapy-induced neurocognitive decline in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. To this end, we will test if PARP1-dependent NAD+ metabolic pathways can be novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets to ameliorate chemotherapy-induced neurocognitive impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Significance Kidney transplant is the best treatment for chronic kidney failure, but the immune-suppressing medications also increase the risk of getting and dying from cancer. Because of this, transplant providers may require that patients who have had cancer in the past be in remission for years before they are transplanted, but there is little evidence to guide these practices. In order to provide the best care for patients with chronic kidney failure, transplant providers need quality data on how the risks of cancer recurrence after transplant balance against the risk of dying while waiting for a kidney transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Although breast cancer (BC) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) represent two of the most common causes of mortality among women, certain medications for these diseases, such as chemoprevention and statins, can lower a woman’s risk. Yet, low uptake of chemoprevention continues to perplex BC researchers, particularly given high-risk women’s expressed desire for risk-reduction options and the considerable resources expended to develop effective chemopreventive agents. By integrating CVD risk assessments into our existing decision aid, there is a potential to illuminate the previously unaddressed barriers to chemoprevention decision-making in the context of competing comorbidities like CVD and to educate women about ways to mitigate their risk for BC and CVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed program will develop robust, efficient, and flexible dual-duration and multi-wavelength fiber sources of light enabling several orders of magnitude contrast enhancement for nonlinear and multimodal label-free, deep, and diffraction-limited imaging in living tissue. Building from advances in ultrashort pulse generation pioneered by the PIs, all of the critical pulse durations and wavelengths required for the major nonlinear imaging modalities can be achieved synchronously, for the first time, in a compact and accessible multimodal imaging platform. Successful completion of this program will have major impact for biomedical research and clinical applications by significantly improving performance and broadening access to this powerful new technology for deep-tissue, label-free, nonlinear optical imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Statement  B cell malignancies are significant health issues both in the US and worldwide, constituting more than 50% of blood cancers, approximately 85% of lymphomas, and all myelomas. Despite recent treatment advancements that significantly improve patient survival, many B cell malignancies remain incurable. This new R01 project aims to elucidate novel paradigm-shifting mechanisms of B cell tumorigenesis, treatment resistance, and relapse driven by commensal bacteria-derived molecules, which can be exploited to develop new diagnostics and therapeutics to transform the management of B cell malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Transcription factors (TFs) have been implicated in many diseases like cancer, but despite their high therapeutic potential the vast majority of TFs have resisted traditional drug discovery efforts. To address this challenge, we developed a new and generally approach to create synthetic transcriptional repressors (STRs), which can potently and specifically bind to target DNA sequences to thereby block cancer-causing TFs from regulating gene expression. We now propose to design and test more potent and specific STRs that directly block XBP1/HIF1alpha-DNA binding, profile their effects on oncogenic gene expression programs, and evaluate their therapeutic efficacy in cell and animal models of triple negative breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major threat to national efforts to better integrate health care for dual eligible Medicare-Medicaid beneficiaries (‘duals’), a population with complex medical and social needs, has emerged in the form of non- integrated Medicare Advantage (MA) Dual-Eligible Special Needs Plans (D-SNP) “look alike” plans, which circumvent all state and federal regulations to coordinate health care for duals. Using a quasi-experimental study design and national Medicare-Medicaid administrative data, this study will evaluate the impact of a 2023 federal regulation—the “80% rule"—that eliminates “look-alike” plans on: 1) enrollment changes into integrated care plans (ICPs, which have the potential to improve quality, efficiency and outcomes for duals) and the key factors associated with ICP enrollment, 2) potentially avoidable or low-value health care use, and 3) quality of care and clinical outcomes among duals overall (plus a subset of high-risk duals with dementia, mental illness, frailty, multimorbidity, and from minoritized groups), and among duals who transitioned into ICPs vs. non-ICPs. Findings from this study will guide policymakers’ efforts to improve integrated care for duals—including consideration of further regulation to eliminate the full threat of look-alike plans—to better meet the needs of some of our country’s most medically complex and socially vulnerable people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Thousands of children have in-hospital cardiac arrests each year. Administration of epinephrine is recommended in all cardiac arrests, but its physiologic effects and therapeutic benefits vary between patients, suggesting that a personalized, physiology-directed epinephrine dosing strategy may be efficacious. Therefore, this multicenter study seeks to better delineate the physiologic effects of epinephrine during cardiopulmonary resuscitation and how that information can inform more targeted epinephrine dosing strategies to improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite significant advances in pediatric cancer treatment, childhood cancer remains the commonest cause of death from disease in children, due to resistance of the tumor cells to drug treatment. Our recent research has unveiled a new mechanism of cancer drug resistance driven by virus-like components of our genome known as “retrotransposons”. We've identified a way to block this resistance by safe drugs already used for viral diseases and discovered that the immune system can target cells with activated retrotransposons. Our program aims to explore these findings further, potentially offering new hope to children with currently untreatable cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many diseases are treatable with gene therapy, but it is difficult to target specific organs and large doses of vector are used to overcome this off-target loss. In this multi-PI project, we will develop a novel platform to enable cardiac gene therapy by encapsulating viral vectors in hydrogel delivered to the epicardium. These studies will test the ability of this strategy to minimize effective dose, overcome immune neutralization, and repair cardiac damage, validating it for clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A paucity in our understanding of the functional consequence of variation in the human genome is a major roadblock in the diagnosis and study of genetic disease. We will develop Multiplexed Assays of Variant Effects, MAVEs, to characterize the functional consequence of thousands of variants simultaneously in the disease genes JAGGED1 (JAG1) and NOTCH2, mutations in which cause Alagille syndrome, an autosomal dominant cause of pediatric liver, cardiac, vertebral, ocular, and renal disease. Scalable functional characterization using MAVEs will revolutionize the speed with which we are able to understand genomic findings, and we propose additional, complementary approaches to test assay through-put and employ high fidelity cell models to comprehensively interrogate the strength of functional assays for variant reclassification.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The current Dietary Reference Intakes (DRIs) for iron are based on a relatively small number of studies from homogenous populations outside the US. The proposed study will determine dietary iron requirements in a large, representative sample of US adults. These data will serve as a crucial resource for informing the necessary updates to the current DRIs, ensuring they accurately reflect the specific needs of the increasingly diverse US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision Medicine has now been firmly incorporated into the routine standard-of-care in many medical specialties, in stark contrast with Psychiatry where quantitative predictors that guide clinical decision-making remain extremely limited. Our proposed studies aim to advance the goals of Precision Psychiatry by using artificial intelligence to build clinical outcome predictors of psychosis through integration of electronic health records, dimensional phenotyping, and genetic information, in addition to exploring the psychosocial impact on patients and clinicians. Our long-term goal is to advance the tools available for personalized approaches to diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis in mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will examine the contribution of developing neural markers—valuation and control—to substance use throughout adolescence and young adulthood (13-27 years) by following a well-characterized longitudinal sample recruited from understudied and underserved communities that have high rates of substance use and addiction. Thus, the neurobehavioral and psychosocial predictors of health risk behaviors in this cohort may provide important insights about health risk behaviors in this community and other high-risk populations. By clarifying (1) long-term effects between valuation and control decision-making systems and health risk behaviors throughout adolescence and young adulthood and (2) roles of psychosocial risk and resilience factors that influence these mechanisms, the proposed study will yield critical information for identifying youth with high neurobiological vulnerability for developing substance use disorders. The findings will further inform ways of designing optimally-timed, targeted prevention efforts to ameliorate developmental pathways of youth who are at risk for substance misuse and addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative A progressive reduction in skeletal muscle mass and strength occurs during aging, a phenomenon known as “sarcopenia”. The prevalence of sarcopenia is expected to significantly increase due to the increasing proportion of elderly individuals in the populations of developed nations. The long-term goals of our research are to decipher how chemical modifications that occur during aging impact the function of myosin and associated chaperones which are vital for proper muscle function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: • The behavioral treatment of choice for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is exposure and response  prevention (ERP), which depends on safety learning processes and large-scale brain networks that are  aberrant in OCD. • The proposed project would be among the first to characterize neural functions associated with safety  learning and memory deficits in OCD. • The target engagement aim of the proposed project would test the effects of frontopolar multifocal  transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) on functional connectivity and functional activation of the  default mode network (DMN) and salience network (SN) and on fearful responding during extinction  training in patients with OCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The potential for enteric pathogens to proliferate within the gut is dependent on the reduction or complete loss of colonization resistance. This proposal will define how the endocannabinoid system can lower colonization resistance in the gut, thus enhancing pathogen colonization and exacerbating gut inflammation. Understanding how this occurs is critical for developing therapeutic strategies that harness the putative beneficial effects of the endocannabinoid system, while also preventing adverse effects that may arise from decreased colonization resistance and gut microbiome dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal combines advanced pattern analysis applied to magnetic resonance imaging with integrative omics analysis to enhance understanding of the disease biology of white matter hyperintensities (WMH), a common age-related imaging finding indicative of poor brain health. We will leverage novel machine learning-derived spatial patterns representing unique causes of WMH to improve prediction of related clinical outcomes including stroke and cognitive impairment on an individual basis, discover new genes relevant to WMH, and identify potential drug targets to advance development of mechanism-based therapies.

PHR: Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is an intraocular pressure-related, chronic optic neuropathy that produces visual disability of public health importance. The biomarker data generated will be combined with genomic markers to gain insight into POAG etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative In this proposal we will study a new synthetic blood substitute that is designed to open dormant blood vessels deliver oxygen to regions of the brain affected by a stroke. This will not only keep the brain cells from dying but also reduce the paradoxical disability from injury induced by successful removal of the clot (i.e. reperfusion injury). This a new drug and requires study in a controlled experiment with advanced imaging to better understand its method of action but has the potential to dramatically change the way people with stroke are treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Selective expression of XBP1 in the unfolded protein response IRE1 pathway has been shown to be effective against multiple neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. The major goal of this project is to characterize the mechanism of action and improve the in vitro potency and specificity and in vivo pharmacological properties of a novel molecular glue activator of IRE1, Rapireon, that selectively activates the nuclease activity of IRE1, leading to splicing and activation of latent XBP1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Twenty six million people in the United States are limited English proficient, meaning that they report speaking English less than “very well”; this population is vulnerable to poor cancer outcomes, in part as a result of communication problems. Medical interpretating services are mandated by laws and regulations, but access is limited by expense and logistical factors, which may potentially be overcome with technology-enabled solutions. We will compare three types of technology-enabled human-delivered interpreting solutions in a study with limited English proficient breast cancer patients who speak Spanish or Mandarin (1. “UN-style” simultaneous interpretation versus 2. audio consecutive, and 3. video consecutive interpretation) to determine which type has the lowest error rate, has the best patient outcomes, and is the most efficient, and what factors contribute to or impede the implementation of these solutions; we will also explore the potential of artificial intelligence to deliver automated “UN-style” simultaneous medical interpreting, which could be a scalable and inexpensive future solution to providing medical interpreting services to people with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Bile duct cancer, the second most common primary liver cancer, is considered to be an incurable cancer with no identifiable risk factors that can rapidly become lethal, unless it can be detected early enough to be fully resected. Because of the poor prognosis, a technique capable of reliably detecting pre-cancer of the bile duct is urgently needed. We propose to employ the minimally invasive endoscopic light scattering spectroscopy technique for rapid data collection from the entire internal surface of the bile duct and identification of bile duct pre-cancer and early cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic, progressive disease that results in lung scarring and breathing difficulty with a median survival of 2-5 years. We hypothesis that aging-associated dysregulation of mechanosignaling drives pulmonary fibrosis. We will exploit a novel in vitro 3D bioengineered microtissue model that mimics healthy and diseased lung tissue to dissect mechanosignaling in aging fibroblasts and a disease-relevant aged mouse model to evaluate inhaled microparticles delivering drugs in alleviating pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is increasing recognition that many neurological and psychiatric illnesses are dysfunctions of neural circuit computation. But we lack a theoretical framework for how such neural circuit computations function to support a wide variety of cognitive processes. Through the proposed research, we aim to provide such a theory, thereby providing a better understanding of the details of how brain circuits operate, leading to better assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of a wide range of brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: People with Down Syndrome (DS) have an intellectual disability and are more likely to develop Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) earlier than the general population because of the extra copy of chromosome twenty-one, affecting neuronal activity and connectivity. In this proposal, we are using a three-dimensional patient-derived human cellular model system of regionally-patterned cortical organoids to determine how trisomy 21 affects cellular, functional, and motility-related neuronal properties and the accumulation of pathological proteins. Furthermore, our studies will include organoid xenotransplantations into mouse cortex that provides a neuronal maturation- promoting environment and allows the assessment of how spontaneous and stimulus-induced neuronal function in implanted organoids is impacted in trisomy, which will contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms underlying intellectual deficits and AD pathology in DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, over 8 million women and 2 million men age 50 and above have osteoporosis and another 51 million women and 35 million men have osteopenia; this translates into a higher risk of fracture within this population, with half of all women and one quarter of men projected to suffer a low bone mass-related fracture. Osteoporotic fractures impart deleterious consequences, including increased hospitalization and mortality; an estimated 25% of individuals will die within one year of a hip fracture. This project explores the role of novel myeloid subsets in limiting age-associated cortical bone loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the US, yet therapeutic options are limited. The advent of electronic health data has brought an unprecedented opportunity to accelerate drug discovery and identify new therapeutic options for COPD among existing drugs (drug repurposing). Building on state-of-the-art methods for causal inference and existing claims data sources, supplemented with EHR data and deeply phenotyped data from COPDGene, we will develop, test, and implement an analytics and data infrastructure to efficiently evaluate non-COPD medications for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are a population of tissue-specific stem cells that live in the bone marrow and both continuously regenerate and replenish blood and immune cells during life. HSCs are the therapeutic component of bone marrow transplants. HSCs are born in the developing embryo and we seek to understand the native conditions that produce HSCs in order to help support attempts to generate them in vitro as a resource for transplant therapies, pharmacological investigation, and disease modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Skin and soft tissue bacterial infections, along with the emergence of antibiotic resistant bacterial strains, pose significant challenges to public health. Our objective is to uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying compromised lymphatic vessel function during and after skin and soft tissue infections, while also understanding the relationship between impaired lymphatic vessel function and compromised immunity. Identification of these molecular mechanisms will inform novel therapeutic targets to enhance lymphatic vessel function and anti-bacterial immunity, effectively breaking the cycle of infection and lymphatic vessel dysfunction.

PHR: Project Narrative We aim to develop a high-resolution model for temperature on a 30-meter scale for all roads in the contiguous United States from 2000 to 2020. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through a national, multicenter, randomized controlled trial, we will evaluate the effect of a shared decision- making (SDM) toolkit versus Usual Care on the utilization of surveillance mammography in breast cancer survivors ≥80 years of age. We will also examine decisional quality, knowledge, and clinical outcomes in addition to multi-level facilitators and barriers to toolkit implementation and discontinuation of mammography. Successful toolkit implementation that leads to individualized discussions and appropriate use of mammography will help to minimize the harms of testing for the large and growing population of older breast cancer survivors through a patient-centered approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular heterogeneity and lineage plasticity pose tremendous challenges for developing cell-targeted therapies and biomarkers of clinically significant prostate cancer. This proposal will use new mouse and organoid models to investigate the mechanisms underlying luminal plasticity and cellular diversification focusing on a novel luminal transcriptional state with a unique “basal-like” Wnt/p63 signaling (luminal intermediate, LumI) that contributes to clonal expansions of luminal cells in aging and prostate cancer models. Our studies will yield essential insights into the functional and molecular heterogeneity sustaining adult prostate homeostasis and the age-related dysregulated mechanisms of lineage plasticity that allow expansions of malignant clones in progressive prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many older adults use sedating medications for pain, anxiety, and mood, which can have harmful effects on their health. Deprescribing, a process that safely reduces or stops these medications, holds great potential to improve the well-being of older adults, especially if personalized and data- driven support is available. This proposal aims to enhance deprescribing efforts by 1) leveraging medical records and artificial intelligence to personalize deprescribing recommendations, and 2) examining factors that optimize doctors' and patients' understanding and trust in artificial intelligence-driven clinical guidance on deprescribing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Given the desire to move from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources, the market for wood pellets is booming, and wood pellet production plants are rapidly sprouting up across the United States, most notably in predominantly black and poor communities in the deep south. Taking advantage of the staggered opening of wood pellet production plants in Mississippi--a state also grappling with significant pediatric health and quality of life issues, this project will measure and model the propagation of both air and noise pollution from wood pellet production into the surrounding community and will examine how and to what extent these wood pellet production exposures impact the health and well-being of children living nearby. Understanding how multiple physical and chemical environmental exposures impact children’s respiratory and stress health will reveal key insights that can help us better assess economic benefits against environmental health costs of wood pellet production as an alternative energy source and investing in local human capital will create a cohort of diverse, local researchers and concerned residents who will become first-authors in their future stories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal in response to PAR-22-085: Microbial-based Cancer Imaging and Therapy - Bugs as Drugs, is relevant to public health since it focuses on metastatic pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), a cancer considered particularly difficult to target and generally unresponsive to current therapies. We propose to investigate the systemic administration of genetically-engineered Bifidobacterium delivering a novel human IL- 2 (SumIL2) to the TME in combination with radiotherapy and/or immunotherapy. Our approach takes advantage of the natural features and genetic engineering of Bifidobacterium to reinvigorate the immune suppressive TME via systemic injection, and thus could have broad applicability in other hard-to-treat cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human papilloma virus-induced cancers of the throat are becoming much more common, and difficulty distinguishing easily curable cases from more serious ones prevents tailoring treatment to be adequately effective but not unnecessarily toxic for each individual patient. This project explores how differences in the levels of a particular viral protein within each cancer influences how quickly it spreads and how well it responds to treatment. This effort will help minimize treatment toxicity for easily curable patients while helping to identify more effective therapies for the most serious cases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Choline is an essential metabolite for wide range of cellular processes, but how mammalian tissues import serum choline has been poorly understood. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that FLVCR1 and its close paralog FLVCR2 are required for choline transport and homeostasis in mammals. Our work will provide unprecedented physiological and structural insight into the role of choline transport in mammalian physiology and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity poses a major health risk, and children living in rural areas have higher rates of obesity than their urban counterparts. Based upon our extensive prior work, we propose a multilevel factorial design randomized controlled trial with interventions at the clinic and individual patient level to treat pediatric obesity among underserved rural children and families. These interventions could fundamentally change the treatment of the 41% of rural children who are overweight or obese and lead to a decrease in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma affects millions, leading to significant vision loss; current limitations in predicting disease risk and progression result in potential preventable blindness and inefficient resource allocation. This project aims to refine glaucoma risk prediction and prognostication by combining advanced genomics and computational tools. Successful implementation could transform early disease detection, optimize treatment, preserve vision, and conserve medical resources, yielding a profound positive impact on public health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a more thorough understanding of drivers of racial/ethnic disparities in utilization of medications to manage pancreatic cancer- related symptoms and improve health-related Quality of Life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal concerns the development of natural language processing methods and tools that establish essential guardrails to the safe use of large language models (LLMs) when used to simplify medical texts. The premise is that LLMs oﬀer the tantalizing opportunity to enable lay access to newly published evidence, but current models risk introducing inaccurate information into automatically simpliﬁed texts; this proposal concerns designing techniques that mitigate such risk. These kinds of “safe generation” techniques have the potential to empower users with the ability to critically read LLM outputs; our immediate, important aim is to enable access to trustworthy plain language summaries of medical evidence, but the developed methods will have application in similar contexts where “safe” generation is critical.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The predominant focus of studying the underlying causes of congenital heart disease (CHD) has been on interrogating transcriptional regulators of early cardiac development, however recent progress proposes that post-transcriptional mechanisms, and specifically mechanisms that regulate RNA, play major roles during normal heart development. Here we have identified DDX3X as a new RNA-binding protein required in multiple cell types of the cardiovascular lineages during development. The proposed work will study the cell type-specific mechanisms by which DDX3X regulates normal heart development and interrogate how mutations in DDX3X found in humans with CHD affect its function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cytoskeleton (“cell skeleton”) is crucial for organizing our cells and allowing them to adapt to changing conditions. Proteins called actin nucleation factors are required for assembling the cytoskeleton in processes that maintain cell viability, but how the factors control programmed cell death – apoptosis – is not understood. To discover how the cytoskeleton enables the proper cellular responses to DNA damage, the goal of this research project is to determine how actin nucleation factors interact with proteins that promote apoptosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The lack of large and representative data with information on both individual childhood experiences and adult health status by race limits studies on the childhood origins of health and health disparities. The project will overcome existing data limitations via historical records linkages and fill vital knowledge gaps regarding the impacts of childhood environments on longevity and racial disparities. The data constructed from the project will catalyze future studies on aging, demography, and intergenerational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Despite intensive research, the etiology leading to neuronal cell loss in Parkinson’s diseases remains unknown. There is compelling evidence that aberrant histone acetylation is implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and related dementias, however there is currently no mechanistic insight about the cause and how dysregulated histone acetylation is functionally linked to the age-related neurodegeneration. This proposal aims to combine pluripotent stem cell-based disease models and patients’ postmortem tissue to systematically dissect the contribution aberrant of histone acetylation in the development of Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Hypothyroidism is a common condition, more frequent in females, associated with excess of cardiovascular risk and poor quality of life not completely abrogated by treatment with levothyroxine. There is an unmet need to define a safe, effective, and feasible regimen to be applied in large trials aimed at assessing levothyroxine/liothyronine combination therapy in patients living with hypothyroidism. To address this knowledge gap we propose a randomized, three-arm, double-blind, controlled, escalating dose parallel pilot study whose results will lay the foundation of large multicenter trial(s) able to demonstrate the effectiveness (or lack thereof) of levothyroxine/liothyronine combination therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our research is to provide molecular insights into endothelial regulation and heart regeneration and repair with the intention of uncovering next-generation therapeutic targets to increase blood vessel growth in injured heart following myocardial infarction. We discovered that loss of the epsin 1 and 2 endocytic adaptor proteins from the endothelium resulted in restoration of blood flow and contractile function in the ischemic heart through enhanced artery formation. Here, we will study the molecular mechanisms underpinning this phenomenon, which will allow us to discover novel targets that will propel development of effective treatment for ischemic heart diseases, a primary cause of mortality worldwide.

PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis represents one of the most frequent causes of morbidity and mortality in humans worldwide. Tuberculosis drug resistant infections are increasing throughout the world, making it critical that rapid screening strategies are developed for therapeutics and other novel interventions. This project is geared toward improvement and validation of groundbreaking imaging technologies that can be used to replace much slower and inefficient conventional approaches to track bacterial viability, whole animal localization during disease and speed development of novel therapeutics and vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cohesin protein complex has been proposed to shape mammalian nuclear architecture in ways critical to genome function. The purpose of this research proposal is to investigate how cohesin, and its auxiliary proteins, couple genome structure to gene regulation in vivo during brain development. These studies are poised to reveal new molecular mechanisms and physiological implications of genome structure with direct relevance to human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal and neonatal mortality remains high in sub-Saharan Africa, and infections are a leading cause of death. Poor water quality and highly contaminated surfaces in health care facility maternity wards are known to increase gut colonization with bacterial pathogens, including antibiotic resistant bacteria. This study will evaluate a novel intervention consisting of passively chlorinated water supply and on-site generation of chlorine disinfectant in health facilities to reduce environmental contamination, reduce colonization of mothers and neonates with sepsis-associated bacteria and antibiotic resistant microorganisms, and improve maternal and neonatal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will investigate racial disparities for receipt of cancer treatments, the impact of time from diagnosis to first cancer treatment, number of cycles received, and dose of drugs given on survival in elderly non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients for Blacks compared to Whites, using The Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Result database. We will further investigate whether Black patients who are underserved and live in urban and rural areas and other geographic regions in the USA, received comparable treatments that extended their survival. We will determine causal patient and provider characteristics important in NSCLC treatment that extended patients’ survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Excess thyroid hormone has been associated with the development of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD). This project aims to clarify whether thyroid hormone is associated with the progression of AD/ADRD in a dose dependent manner and to determine what other characteristics make people particularly vulnerable to the actions of excess thyroid hormone for these outcomes. Since most excess thyroid hormone is the result of over treatment with thyroid hormone therapy, this work examines an important potentially preventable risk factor for AD/ADRD, a growing public health problem world- wide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The current gold standard method for sperm retrieval is still manual microscopic examination and retrieval, which is highly subjective, time-consuming, and expensive. To the best of our knowledge, there is currently no assay in the market or the commercial development pipeline that can efficiently, reliably, and rapidly help in the retrieval of sperm cells from testicular biopsies or severe factor ejaculated semen samples, and all previously developed systems and networks for sperm localization are highly susceptible to domain bias and may not maintain efficiency when identifying sperm in clinical microTESE samples. Here, we propose to develop the first domain- adaptive, automated, high-throughput, sensitive, and inexpensive AI-assisted screening, and retrieval tool for rare sperm from minimally processed heterogenous microTESE and semen samples.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Transgender and gender-nonbinary (TNB) adolescents may receive gender-affirming hormone therapy (GAHT) with estradiol or testosterone to induce physical changes that align with their gender identity. This has been shown to improve symptoms of anxiety and depression, but parents and caregivers often worry that giving GAHT during adolescence, a period of rapid brain maturation, may affect their child’s brain development and function and, in turn, their child’s ability to think and learn. In this proposed project, we will use advanced neuroimaging techniques and a battery of well-established tools for cognitive assessment to study the neurocognitive effects of GAHT in TNB adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A fundamental question in biology is - how did humans acquire their unique characteristics from their primate ancestors? We have identified a non-coding element—a member of a class of DNA sequences called human accelerated regions (HARs)—that our evidence indicates is a strong candidate to have generated human- specific traits involving cognition during human evolution. Understanding HARs is relevant to NIH’s mission of reducing illness and disability, as HARs are linked to neuro-developmental disorders such as schizophrenia and autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application, we will probe the hypothesis that mechanistic communication and spatial interactions between myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSC) and cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAF) drive tumor-permissive and immune suppressive signaling in the tumor microenvironment to promote chemoimmunotherapy resistance in pancreatic cancer. Our studies will precisely deconstruct the underpinnings of this previously unrecognized MDSC-CAF communication using novel mouse modeling techniques and spatial proteomics in human pancreatic cancer samples. Moreover, by developing a highly selective pharmacologic strategy to disrupt this MDSC-CAF crosstalk in preclinical models, our proposal will lay the foundation for a neoadjuvant clinical trial in patients with operable pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This K23 application from a geriatric psychiatrist aims to explore the neurobiology of affective symptoms (AS) in behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) with the goal of developing and testing targeted treatments for this devastating neurodegenerative disease. A Positron Emission Tomography (PET) study to measure glucose metabolism is proposed to measure changes in neural circuitry associated with AS in bvFTD. Treatment with a multi-modal antidepressant, Vortioxetine, is then employed to investigate changes in cerebral glucose metabolism in neural networks hypothesized to be associated with AS and cognitive changes in bvFTD (default mode network, salience network), offering insights into future neurobiologically targeted therapy for neuropsychiatric symptoms in bvFTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is associated with a substantial medical and societal burden, but no small molecule therapy that alters the disease progression is currently available. Several studies including our own indicate that prostaglandin-E2 receptor EP2 is associated with exacerbation of inflammation and neurodegenerative pathology and cognitive deficits in rodent models of Alzheimer’s disease. We propose to develop an EP2 inhibitor with an overall goal to suppress neuropathology and cognitive deficits in mouse models and eventually in human patients with Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative With endovascular stroke therapy, we now can rapidly recanalize the occluded vessel that is causing stroke; however, only about half the patients that receive this treatment have a good neurological outcome. The goal of our proposal is to better understand this population that does not benefit by organizing them into different categories based on etiology of their persistent dysfunction. We will then generate models that use machine learning to predict who those patients might be, so that we could target treatments specific to the etiology of their dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart attacks result in permanent loss of cardiac muscle cells, leading to increased morbidity and mortality with limited treatment options. To regenerate cardiac muscle cells, special populations of fibroblasts and immune cells are required, yet their precise functions and contributions to cardiac renewal are not well understood. In support of the NIH mission to promote better treatment and prevention strategies, my research project will elucidate the interplay between these non- muscle cells and the cardiac muscle cells, which may lead to novel therapeutics promoting cardiac renewal.
