IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Clostridioides difficile is a toxin producing pathogen that causes life-threatening diarrhea in hospitalized patients undergoing antibiotic therapy. Chondroitin sulfate proteoglycan 4 (CSPG4) is the most critical host receptor for these toxins and eliminating CSPG4 provides protection from C. difficile disease. Our work has connected Hippo signaling to CSPG4 expression and then used a drug targeting Hippo signaling to downregulate CSPG4 and prevent C. difficile disease in a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Ammonia exposure causes the most severe chemical burns to the ocular surface. In this proposal, we will correlate the degradation of corneal sensory fibers by ammonia exposure with the impairment of corneal wound healing, which further leads to chronic corneal erosion and ulceration. Results from the proposed studies will fill the major gaps in our knowledge about the neuro-regulatory mechanism underlying corneal injuries by ammonia, and offer a new therapeutic strategy for ocular pain and injuries by ammonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of new chemotherapeutic approaches for the treatment of infectious disease is, by acclamation, one of the preeminent challenges of modern biomedical science. This Phase II proposal is designed to strengthen and enhance the investments and infrastructure established in Phase I for the Center for Chemical Biology of Infectious Diseases. The CBID Center will continue to address critical gaps and enable researchers at the University of Kansas (KU) and associated institutions to apply these tools to better understand and potentially prevent infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The microbial species that reside in the colon are important for many aspects of human health, including energy balance, which is important for managing body weight. In this project, we will extend the findings from a completed randomized crossover trial, which showed that under the very controlled conditions of a domiciled controlled feeding study, the gut microbiome plays a role in how much energy (calories) from the diet people excrete via fecal energy loss. We will interrogate samples from that study to quantify how many additional calories are excreted because of growth of the gut microbiome and which microbial functions contribute to fecal energy loss and therefore energy balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The total number of people with cognitive impairment and dementia including Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is expected to rise exponentially with a fast pace of population aging, placing enormous social and economic burden worldwide. Epidemiologic and pathological studies have indicated an association between vascular diseases and cognitive dysfunction, implicating vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID), but the driving pathologic mechanisms of VCID remain unclear, halting the development of effective prevention and treatments. This proposal aims to investigate the mechanisms of cognitive impairment caused by atherosclerosis, the leading cause of vascular disease worldwide, and facilitate the identification of therapeutic target and early intervention for VCID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tissue factor (TF) is the primary initiator of blood coagulation, so the production of TF must be carefully controlled to prevent thrombotic diseases including venous thromboembolism, heart attack, and stroke. This proposal seeks to comprehensively investigate mechanisms regulating how cells turn on or off the production of TF, and how these processes are disrupted by human genetic variation. These studies suggest that genetic variation in the gene for TF may impact blood clotting in humans and contribute to bleeding or thrombotic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Narrative Post-stroke aphasia is a significant public health problem whose symptoms depend on the stroke lesion and on the status of the surrounding brain tissue. Stroke survivors are at risk for premature brain aging and this project will evaluate the mechanistic relationship between brain tissue aging, aphasia severity and recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The objective of this study is to validate an innovative concept that the unique dual TC14012 protects against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity (DICT) by activating cardiac CXCR7 to reprogram cardiomyocyte metabolism and prevent cardiac dysfunction and by antagonizing CXCR4 to inhibit cardiac mast cell infiltration and activation in multiple mouse models. We will first optimize the doses of TC14012 for protecting against DICT in two tumor-free and tumor-bearing mouse models, and then we will determine its direct effects and mechanisms on energy reserve metabolism and mitochondrial function in cardiomyocytes and on cardiac mast cell infiltration and degranulation. This project will reveal new insight into the underlying mechanisms behind and provide fundamental evidence for TC14012 as a novel approach for the prevention of DICT in future clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The first allele-specific KRAS inhibitors were recently approved in lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD), but clinical benefit is limited by intrinsic and acquired resistance. We hypothesize resistance to KRAS inhibitors is driven by cancer cell differentiation into AT1-like or squamous states, which is determined by LKB1 proficiency or deficiency, respectively. Here, we interrogate the function and molecular drivers of the AT1-like and squamous transition states, which we hope would lead to new therapeutic strategies overcoming resistance to KRAS inhibitors in LUAD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because peripheral T-cell lymphomas are diagnosed in approximately 10,000 individuals in the U.S. annually. More than 70% will relapse after initial chemotherapy, and no current standardized therapies are at the relapse stage. This proposal aims to determine the relevance of novel actionable targets in T-cell lymphomas and is relevant to the NIH’s goal to foster fundamental creative discoveries, innovative research strategies, and their applications as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Analyses of humans with enlarged hearts and heart failure have identified FHOD3 as a gene that influences the age when someone develops hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The collaborative research proposed here will determine how FHOD3 gene variants influence the heart’s response to stress leading to heart failure in humans. By defining how heart cells respond to stress, these studies will provide new insights into how the heart can fail and could lead to new strategies to prevent heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addressing immunodominance in the humoral response has the potential to advance the development of truly universal influenza vaccines. This project is relevant to public health because it aims to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms through which prolonged and targeted stimulation a toll-like receptor, facilitated by adjuvant formulation, can overcome immunodominance and broaden the antibody response to an influenza antigen. These insights will not only pave the way for future clinical trials involving similar adjuvants but also hold promise for uncovering innovative strategies to support universal vaccine development. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although many older adults require rehabilitation in skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) following a hospitalization for heart failure, research on how medications enhance or interfere with rehabilitation is scarce. This project will rigorously examine the effects of using individual medications for heart failure and other common conditions (e.g., pain) as well as using multiple medications together on physical function and successful discharge from SNFs to home. Findings from this project will 1) inform prescribing and deprescribing interventions to sustain optimal physical function following a hospitalization for heart failure and 2) open new frontiers in aging and heart failure research by establishing a novel data resource that can be re-used to conduct previously impossible medication-related studies in SNFs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  DNA repair by homologous recombination (HR) is a fundamental biological process necessary for the maintenance of chromosomal integrity. The failure to maintain genomic integrity is a major source of predisposition to cancer. The research in this proposal will focus on molecular events essential for chromosomal maintenance by homologous recombination which, when defective, is known to result in predisposition to cancers, and also to hematological malignancies, bone marrow failure, and developmental abnormalities in Fanconi’s anemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the advent of combination antiretroviral therapy, people with HIV (PWH) suffer from an accelerated development of cardiovascular disease, which drastically reduces their life expectancy. Despite this knowledge, the mechanisms predisposing PWH to high blood pressure, the leading risk factor for cardiovascular disease remain ill-defined and unstudied. The proposed study will combine the use of novel genetically engineered animal models, human specimens, and cultured endothelial cells with pharmacological approaches to test whether HIV derived proteins accelerate cardiovascular aging via inducing hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cilia motility is essential for airway clearance and is powered by a large motor called the dynein arm. Defective dynein arm is responsible for primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a genetic disease characterized by mucus impaction, recurrent sinopulmonary infections and accelerated decline of lung function. This project focuses on an early step in building dynein arms and is highly relevant to PCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pathogenic fungi are leading causes of corneal ulcers, resulting in corneal blindness and vision loss in the USA and worldwide. Risk factors are contact lens associated corneal abrasions and ocular trauma. Once the corneal barriers are compromised, fungal spores can enter the corneal stroma where they germinate, and hyphae penetrate throughout the cornea. Immune cells called neutrophils rapidly infiltrate the cornea to kill these invasive fungi, but these cells also cause tissue damage that contribute to the clinical symptoms associated with this infection. Experiments in this proposal will characterize the molecular events leading to neutrophil mediated fungal killing in corneal infections, and will identify potential molecular targets for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging, particularly the increased incidence of disease in older individuals, is emerging as one of the most important health concerns in the United States, yet every individual ages differently. Understanding how different genetic backgrounds influence aging, especially how these differences influence the response to drugs and other aging interventions, is key to implementing strategies that increase the period of healthy aging in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity is a major health problem associated with metabolic syndrome and type II diabetes and the control of adiposity is a top priority in managing these diseases. Promoting thermogenesis may not only help in combating obesity but also in improving glucose/insulin homeostasis. This research is to understand how the main critical protein of thermogenesis is induced to promote thermogenesis in brown fat and may provide new therapeutic targets for obesity/diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have known for 30 years that the 10% of infants born small for gestational age, compared to average for gestational infants, are at increased risk for later life coronary heart disease (CHD) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality. This one-of-a-kind 60-year longitudinal study seeks to understand why and to advance clinical and public health strategies to reduce this increased risk. It will identify and link biomarkers collected during pregnancy (in the 1960s) to sophisticated measures of heart function and disease among 800 adults now ages 60-65.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune-mediated disorder of the central nervous system that affects more than 2 million people worldwide, causes irreversible neurologic disability, and is currently incurable. Focal inflammatory demyelination in the cortex is common in MS and is associated with disability and disability worsening over time, but our understanding of cortical lesions has so far been limited by insensitive in vivo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods. Here we propose to use a combination of advanced, ultra-high field MRI and cutting- edge transcriptomic methods to characterize cortical demyelination and repair in early MS and its impact on the course of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative - public health relevance The current approaches to prescribing medication for patients with post-traumatic stress disorder and major depression disorder are inadequate, as clinicians are forced to use a trial-and-error to determine the best course of treatment. It is possible to analyze a patient’s DNA to determine if their metabolism will cause a positive therapeutic response or have serious negative side effects, but current methods are expensive and take multiple weeks to return results. We plan on creating a simpler test that can be carried out in the clinicians office < 1 hour, and while it won’t provide the same breadth of information as the more expensive test, the results are immediate and enhances the chances that the clinician prescribes the correct medication, potentially avoiding adverse effects such as toxicity and ineffective levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative This project aims to investigate the role of endothelial cell metabolism and cell cycle in the fluid shear stress patterns that determine resistance vs susceptibility to atherosclerosis. We will conduct an extensive, unbiased analysis of the effects of different shear stress patterns on metabolic and metabolomic parameters; will test the role of a piezo1-mitochondrial pathway in susceptibility to atherosclerosis; and will investigate the role of a late G1-arrested state with active Cdk2 in disease, including both in vitro mechanistic studies and in vivo pre-clinical experiments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic rhinosinusitis and olfactory dysfunction are clinically impactful and understudied complications of cystic fibrosis in young children; highly effective therapies that aim to correct the defective protein responsible for the clinical manifestations of cystic fibrosis are becoming more widely available. This proposed investigation will characterize chronic rhinosinusitis and olfactory dysfunction in young children with cystic fibrosis and determine the degree to which highly effective therapies improve these complications. Findings from this investigation, which are aligned with cystic fibrosis community research priorities, will inform optimization of both quality of life and overall health, and will highlight the importance of evaluating and managing comorbidities at a young age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neural network hyperexcitability caused by impairments in GABAergic inhibition gives rise to epilepsy which currently affects 3.4 million patients in the US. KCC2 is a neuronal chloride transporter critical for the inhibitory action of GABA, and its dysregulations are associated with various brain disorders including epilepsy. Leveraging our previous discovery that drugs inhibiting the FLT3 kinase pathway stimulate KCC2 expression in neurons and strengthen GABAergic inhibition in the brain, our research will establish the functional roles of FLT3 signaling in healthy and epileptic brains, laying the foundation for a novel therapeutic approach to suppress the onset and recurrence of epileptic seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Existing healthcare data systems lack relevant information to support social interventions: it is difficult to identify individuals with social needs and difficult to facilitate their engagement with social service providers. This project will apply a precision medicine approach to the identification of, and engagement with, Medicaid recipients with social needs. We will help identify and address social needs and shrink disparities in health outcomes across a large, high-risk population while informing the next generation of value-based care paradigms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The interphotoreceptor matrix (IPM) is an essential extracellular matrix crucial for maintaining vision by connecting neuronal photoreceptor cells with the glial retinal pigment epithelium. Deficiencies in IPM proteins, such as IMPG1 and IMPG2, contribute to blinding diseases like retinitis pigmentosa. This project seeks to enhance public health by elucidating the roles of IMPG1 and IMPG2 in maintaining photoreceptor health, exploring their link to blinding diseases, and evaluating therapeutic strategies for these retinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure myocardium exhibits electrophysiologic pathological remodeling that underlies the development of arrhythmias leading to sudden cardiac death. Here we aim to delineate the mechanisms behind KChIP2 transcriptional repression of the stress kinase JNK2 gene and the possible causal role of increased/activated JNK2 to arrhythmia mechanisms and sudden cardiac death onset. The outcomes of this proposal will establish the therapeutic potential of KChIP2 gene transfer and/or JNK2 inhibition as prospective anti-arrhythmia interventions for a translational path toward future arrhythmia therapies in HF patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative Interleukin-17A (IL-17A) plays an important role in autoimmune diseases; however, the limited therapeutic utility of blocking IL-17A in rheumatoid arthritis points to the gaps in understanding its signaling mechanisms. We recently published 14-3-3z-TRAF interaction-mediated novel regulation of IL-17A signaling. This proposed work studies the molecular mechanisms, consequences, and physiological relevance of 14-3-3z-TRAF interactions that will elucidate fundamental knowledge of IL-17A signaling and rheumatoid arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Leukocyte migration into tissue is a key control point in the inflammatory response. Integrin interactions with their endothelial ligands are crucial for this process, yet very little is known about the signaling events downstream of integrins that drive migration. In this proposal, I will investigate the role of a novel mechanical scaffold in triggering integrin signaling events needed for T cell migration, with the ultimate goal of revealing new molecular mechanisms that can be manipulated to alter T cell functions in inflammatory diseases and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) is a relapsing rheumatologic disease characterized by inflammation of multiple organ systems, including the sinuses and nose. This study will examine the molecules and symptoms related to sinonasal disease as well as other factors that predict development of relapse in AAV. Completion of this work may lead to novel biomarkers and therapies which prevent relapse, minimize unnecessary exposure to long-term immunosuppressive treatments, and improve the quality of life in patients with AAV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immunotherapies with genetically engineered T lymphocytes are successful in controlling the growth and spread of blood cancers but are not effective against solid cancers. We will test the hypothesis that oxidative stress-induced molecular changes in these T cells reduce their ability to kill cancer cells. Our goal is to develop a new version of engineered T cells with reduced stress-induced molecular changes to improve T cell function and therapeutic efficacy against solid cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision Medicine has now been firmly incorporated into the routine standard-of-care in many medical specialties, in stark contrast with Psychiatry where quantitative predictors that guide clinical decision-making remain extremely limited. Our proposed studies aim to advance the goals of Precision Psychiatry by using artificial intelligence to build clinical outcome predictors of psychosis through integration of electronic health records, dimensional phenotyping, and genetic information, in addition to exploring the psychosocial impact on patients and clinicians. Our long-term goal is to advance the tools available for personalized approaches to diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis in mental health.

PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial intracellular nucleotide second messenger signaling plays an important role in biofilm development. The project proposes to develop small molecules and tether these molecules on polymeric biomaterial surfaces so that small molecules can interfere with nucleotide signaling pathways and interrupt biofilm formation and growth on biomaterial surfaces, and will increase the efficacy of antibiotics against biofilm bacteria in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Lupus patients have dysfunction of skin lymphatic vessels that bring signals from skin to immune tissues, but the underlying cause is not well understood. This project dissects how skin immune cells can regulate the lymphatic vessels to promote a healthy immune system and improve morbidity in lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fasting interventions have numerous health benefits, but the underlying molecular mechanism remains less explored. Here we focus on lysosomes, a dynamic signaling organelle that regulates cellular metabolism, protein homeostasis, and metabolic adaptation – using the mammalian intestine as a paradigm, we will investigate how lysosomes maintain intestinal stem cells and fuel tumorigenesis. Collectively, the goal of this proposal is to leverage novel genetic and biochemical tools to uncover the downstream molecular effectors of lysosome biology, which may have direct implications in developing stem cell regeneration and anti-tumor therapies to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women are disproportionally affected by osteoporosis and low bone mass, yet non-estrogen-based sex-specific therapeutic modalities have not been explored. We propose that a X-chromosome-linked gene, KDM5C, contributes to sex differences in bone by regulating bone homeostasis and formation. The successful completion of this study will provide conceptual advances of the genetic mechanisms driving sex-differences in bone homeostasis and disease-associated bone loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke survivors typically experience varying degrees of neuropsychiatric impairments after injury, including post- stroke depression (PSD). We have strong supporting data showing that both stroke and aging lead to a reduction in taurine and oxytocin levels, loss of oxytocin leads to a depressive phenotype in mice, and we have also found that plasma taurine and oxytocin levels decline in stroke patients and correlate with depressive symptoms in stroke patients. This project will examine how age-associated reduction of taurine and OXT signaling contributes to microglial activation, the development of PSD, and impaired functional recovery after an induced ischemic stroke in aged mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: New therapies are needed for the treatment of obesity and obesity-related conditions like type II diabetes that address core limitations of GLP-1-based therapeutics. In this application we will investigate the activity states of the brain’s endogenous GLP-1 system in diet-based models of obesity, a major gap in knowledge. Further, we will investigate how dysregulation of the brain’s GLP-1 system contributes to obesity pathogenesis and whether elevation of the activity state of this system is a tractable treatment strategy for obesity using laboratory mice, behavior, and neural circuit techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a devastating illness most commonly caused by viral infections, and Influenza-A virus (IAV) alone accounts for 300,000-500,000 annual deaths worldwide. Our strong and exciting preliminary data support the hypothesis that epithelial and endothelial TREK-1 potassium channels are downregulated in ARDS lungs, and this injurious process can be counteracted by pharmacological activation of the subset of residual TREK-1 channels with newly-developed compounds. In this proposal we will explore the potential of TREK-1 channels as novel targets against IAV-induced ARDS by establishing (i) the importance of ARDS-induced TREK-1 deficiency in the development of lung injury, (ii) the potential of TREK-1 enhancement as a novel protective strategy, and (iii) the molecular signaling mechanisms underlying TREK-1 protection to facilitate future rational drug design.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to study the mechanistic role of oogenic JNK in regulating DNA damage response and apoptosis-related signaling in the oocytes of primordial follicles following treatment with gonadotoxic anti-cancer agents such as doxorubicin. This research is critically important for us to identify the molecular mechanisms of chemotherapy-induced primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) and infertility and the development of therapeutic targets to preserve young female cancer patients’ ovarian reserve, fertility, and ovarian endocrine functions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 1 million pregnant patients per year in the US undergo induction of labor with oxytocin. Despite widespread use of this medication, we have a limited understanding of how oxytocin should be dosed and how the uterus should contract in response to oxytocin to achieve the ultimate goal of cervical dilation and labor progression. We propose a clinical and translational study investigating the physiologic and functional response to exogenous oxytocin by placing universal intrauterine pressure catheters in patients undergoing labor induction to determine contraction parameters predictive of success and assessing serial maternal serum oxytocin levels and myometrial oxytocin receptor function in response to oxytocin dosing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Results from this study will inform the suitability of VAChT as a candidate biomarker for severity of schizophrenia. This would be applicable to measuring severity of psychotic or cognitive deficits in patients with schizophrenia, and may be useful in diagnostic subtyping of patients with cholinergic system alterations whose symptoms could be responsive to cholinergic-modulating treatments. The data gleaned from this study will also be critical information in further elucidating underlying pathophysiology of symptoms of schizophrenia and in guiding future studies of treatment efficacy and therapeutics development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite a multi-modal standard of care treatment approach including radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and surgical resection, the outcome remains poor for pediatric high-grade gliomas necessitating the development of new therapies. We have previously established an FDA IND- approved personalized adoptive cellular therapy (ACT) platform utilizing total tumor RNA-pulsed dendritic cells (DCs) to expand polyclonal tumor-specific T cells for the treatment of invasive and refractory brain cancers. In this proposal, we will explore a superior approach utilizing the identification and selective amplification of patients’ tumor-specific antigens and uniquely identifying, sorting, and expanding responding tumor-specific T cells for use in ACT to improve the eradication of invasive HGG before pursuing an early phase human clinical trial.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to combat childhood obesity, a pressing public health concern, by focusing on early childhood nutrition habits in rural areas. Rural children are more likely to become obese, making it crucial to promote healthy eating habits in rural family childcare homes (FCCHs). This project will evaluate the “EAT for Prevention” program's ability to empower FCCH providers in rural communities to implement evidence-based practices that improve children's diets and overall health, ultimately contributing to better public health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision Medicine has now been firmly incorporated into the routine standard-of-care in many medical specialties, in stark contrast with Psychiatry where quantitative predictors that guide clinical decision-making remain extremely limited. Our proposed studies aim to advance the goals of Precision Psychiatry by using artificial intelligence to build clinical outcome predictors of psychosis through integration of electronic health records, dimensional phenotyping, and genetic information, in addition to exploring the psychosocial impact on patients and clinicians. Our long-term goal is to advance the tools available for personalized approaches to diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis in mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Therapeutic development in ALS relies on the availability of robust biomarkers to asses drug efficacy and improve statistical power in clinical trials. Our work seeks to apply high resolution proteomic approaches to elucidate NfL, NfM, and NfH isoforms in sporadic and familial ALS biofluids that may serve as improved prognostic and/or pharmacodynamic biomarkers. In addition, we propose that in-depth comparison of protein abundance and kinetics of pre- and post-tofersen treatment biofluids from SOD1-ALS participants has the potential to reveal a proteomic signature of improvement in ALS that can be leveraged to identify novel disease pathways and biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To successfully control hypertension in Ghana, Nigeria and Africa, we need new ways to treat chronic diseases. Even though there is a lot of proof about effective, long-term ways to control hypertension, these strategies have not been used equally in places with few resources, like Ghana and Nigeria. We want to see if the ADHINCRA Program, an innovative, patient-centered, program that includes home blood pressure monitoring, mobile health technology, team-based care with doctors and nurses, and adjustments to medicines by nurses using an adapted, simplified hypertension treatment protocol, improves hypertension control in Ghana and Nigeria compared to usual care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The ability of bacteria to actively export (efflux) antibiotics is a prominent mechanism of drug resistance, common among many serious bacterial pathogens and a major contributor to the escalating global antibiotic resistance health crisis. This proposal aims to define the molecular mechanisms that regulate expression and activity of one such efflux pump in an important bacterial pathogen. These studies will broadly enhance our understanding of bacterial responses to antibiotics and bacterial efflux drug systems, and will support the future goal of developing novel strategies to counter the antibiotic resistance they confer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Biologic drugs and nanomedicines with conjugated polyethylene glycol (PEG) show improved pharmacokinetics. However, the application of PEGylated therapeutics is limited by the presence of anti-PEG antibodies, which not only accelerate the clearance of PEGylated therapeutics and attenuate their efficacies but may also cause severe side effects. We propose to develop zwitterionic PEG as a replacement of PEG in therapeutic delivery for minimized side effects and consistent efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Vaccines against influenza virus infection induce protetive antibody responses. However, these vaccine-induced immune responses are often not as durable as seen after infection. In the proposal we are investigating factors that might be responsible for the better immunity induced to infection than to vaccination with influenza virus. By identifying these factors we hope to learn how we can generate vaccines that trigger longer-lasting and better immune protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Health inequities in older adults along racial and sociodemographic lines are pervasive, overall and among older adults living with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD). Accountable care organizations (ACOs), in which groups of clinicians assume responsibility for quality and costs of care for patient populations on an annual basis, are one promising mechanism by which to improve equity and outcomes. In this project, we will use quantitative and qualitative methods to study the ACO Realizing Equity, Access, and Community Health (ACO REACH) program, which is an ACO program specifically aimed at reducing health inequities among Medicare beneficiaries, including people from minoritized racial and ethnic groups and those living in poverty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (IIM) such as dermatomyositis are a group of inflammatory disorders characterized by muscle weakness and associated with significant morbidity and mortality with limited treatment options that focus largely on the use of broad-spectrum immunosuppressive drugs with significant complications. Myositis and other IIM represent a truly unmet medical need as there is currently no cure for any IIM. Our research project will test if a new mechanism of muscle cell damage contributes to the progression of myositis and generate proof-of-principle data that increasing the membrane repair capacity of muscle cells may be an effective therapy for the treatment of myositis that does not involve immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) causes significant mortality, and carries a case fatality rate of > 20%. Sepsis is defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysfunctional host immune response to an infection. We have new data showing that when cells respond to pneumococcal infection with more rapid changes in cell metabolism because of a different genetic variant, mice are more likely to die of sepsis. The proposal investigates the inflammatory, physiological and metabolic consequences of expression of this variant in mice infected with pneumococcus, and initiates a search for therapies that prevent septic death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conventional ultrasound does not allow the quantitative assessment of the severity of pulmonary edema and fibrosis. We propose to develop quantitative ultrasound methods to assess the severity of pulmonary edema in patients with heart failure, and to monitor response to diuretic treatment. We will also investigate whether these methods can be used for the diagnostic and assessment of severity of pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study addresses the critical knowledge gap in understanding how peptidergic neuromodulation dynamically adapts cerebellar processing to physiological state and behavioral context. We investigate the fundamental cellular and circuit mechanisms by which the neuropeptide oxytocin regulates information processing in the cerebellar cortex, establishing the cerebellum as an oxytocin-sensitive brain region that may link cognitive-affective and motor components of complex behavior. These findings have implications for neurodevelopmental, psychiatric, and neurological disorders characterized by impairments in both social communication and motor domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome (IC/BPS) is a debilitating syndrome of unknown etiology. This proposal seeks to determine if there are distinct cells in the spinal cord that contribute to bladder sensation and overactive bladder in IC/BPS. These studies will improve our current understanding of how spinal cord processes bladder sensations and possibly launch new avenues for drug discovery for relieving IC/BPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision Medicine has now been firmly incorporated into the routine standard-of-care in many medical specialties, in stark contrast with Psychiatry where quantitative predictors that guide clinical decision-making remain extremely limited. Our proposed studies aim to advance the goals of Precision Psychiatry by using artificial intelligence to build clinical outcome predictors of psychosis through integration of electronic health records, dimensional phenotyping, and genetic information, in addition to exploring the psychosocial impact on patients and clinicians. Our long-term goal is to advance the tools available for personalized approaches to diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis in mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CAR-T cell therapy has revolutionized the treatment of lymphoma, but its unprecedented efficacy is often limited by acute ICANS (Immune Effector Cell Associated Neurotoxicity Syndrome), which may increase the risk for neurocognitive dysfunction; however, the chronic neurologic impact of CAR-T cell therapy has not been studied systematically. Our proposal will describe the molecular, neurocognitive and neuroimaging features of acute and chronic neurotoxicity through retrospective and prospective cohorts of lymphoma patients treated with CAR-T cells, with the overarching goal of providing a comprehensive characterization of neurotoxicity and improving current trial and therapeutic design in this vulnerable set of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Most children with cancer globally are diagnosed in low and middle-income countries, where there is limited access to tools for pathologic diagnosis and, by extension, a high probability a child will receive the wrong treatment for their disease and needlessly die. Recent advancements in nanopore-based platforms for RNA sequencing provide a transformative low-cost, flexible and scalable approach, with potential for broad applicability to the diagnosis of most pediatric cancers. We propose to developa cost-effective nanopore RNA sequencing-based platform to characterize diverse pediatric tumors and prospectively validate its effectiveness in a realistic LMIC setting; in a step toward ultimately curing more children with cancer globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The disruption of gene expression through Polycomb Repressive Complexes 1 and 2 (PRC1 and PRC2), which consists of a group of proteins that serve an essential role in chromatin regulation, is a common occurrence in various human malignancies, including cancer. While PRC2 has been the primary focus of pharmaceutical research, our objective is to identify small molecules that can specifically inhibit PRC1. Validated and selective inhibitors of PRC1 could provide unique insights beyond conventional genetic techniques and offer new options for therapeutic development, potentially addressing the existing challenges associated with PRC2 inhibition in cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As an important oral pathogen, the oral bacterium Treponema denticola is not only associated with oral infections (e.g., periodontitis, necrotic root canals and endodontic infections) but also implicated in several systemic illnesses such as Alzheimer’s disease and oral squamous cell carcinoma. However, little is known about its virulence determinants that are associated with those diseases. Therefore, identification of virulence factors and understanding their roles in the pathogenicity of T. denticola will ultimately lead to a new modality to prevent and treat periodontitis and probably other diseases as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clostridioides difficile (Cd) infections (CDIs) constitute a significant public health challenge, annually affecting ~500,000 individuals in the U.S. alone. The etiologies of CDIs are complex and depend on pathogen variations, gut microbiome (GM) composition, and environmental exposures (i.e., antibiotics); however, how these environmental and microbial-host factors interact to affect disease progression remains unknown. To address this gap in knowledge, we propose to leverage our extensive collection of cultured Cd isolates and patient stool samples from Cd carriers and CDI patients to i) identify genomic determinants of Cd pathogenesis, ii) establish GM signatures of Cd colonization and CDI onset, and iii) investigate the role of clinically-relevant Cd genetic variation in disease development utilizing defined GM-humanized gnotobiotic animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the PsycheMERGE Network is to advance equitable precision psychiatry in learning healthcare system frameworks across the United States. During the course of this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators at twelve academic medical centers will bring together clinical data (>29 million individuals), genetic data (>1.9 million), and an extraordinary range of scientific expertise (psychiatry, medical informatics, machine learning, statistics, genetics, sociomedical sciences, decision sciences, and ethics) to advance this mission. We will leverage this expertise and data to build on our prior success and address barriers to scalability, utility of genomic data, clinical application, and translation to clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tailoring cancer therapy to allow the best cure with the fewest side effects is one of the highest priorities in cancer care. Unfortunately, even radiation therapy, one of the most widely used cancer therapies, although very technologically advanced, has not had biomarkers to identify those at increased risk of toxicity. We have identified a new class of biomarkers that predict significant late toxicity risk to radiation therapy in prostate cancer, and believe that further validating, defining and understanding these biomarkers, as well as applying the most advanced technologies for treatment of these patients, will radically improve our ability to meaningfully decrease toxicity for prostate cancer radiation treated patients in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary objective of this project is to determine how the formation of heterochromatin is driven by targets of the degradative ubiquitin ligase anaphase-promoting complex (APC), including Ki-67 and phosphorylated histone 3. The elegant experiments we propose aim to test the hypothesis that these APC-targets drive heterochromatin formation by promoting the biophysical process of phase separation. Achieving these aims will provide fundamental insight into the role of chromatin regulation in neurons and the contribution of this process to inherited disorders of neurodevelopment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Down syndrome (DS), caused by triplication of chromosome 21, is the most common intellectual disability disorder affecting more than 250,000 individuals in the United States alone. Abnormalities in brain development and metabolic dysregulation are hallmarks of DS, and emerging evidence suggests that metabolism plays a key role in brain development, yet the consequence of altered cellular metabolism on brain development in the context of DS is unknown. This project will support the NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge about the nature of living systems and apply that knowledge to advance human health by exploring the consequence of altered cellular metabolism on neural progenitor cell proliferation and fate specification in brain development to gain insight into the pathogenesis of DS and enhance health outcomes for individuals suffering from the disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative You see because light from objects in your environment evokes electrical signals in the retina of your eye. The brain decodes these signals to analyze what those objects are, but because the eye is moving all the time, the brain cannot decode where those objects are in the world without using information about how the eye moves and where it is located in the skull when it moves. This project will apply physiological and neuropsychological methods to investigate the brain network that creates an accurate representation of the world around us for memory and action, and which goes awry in patients with certain brain lesions of the cerebral cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently showed that chronic mild hypoxia (CMH; 10% O2) accelerates clinical recovery in the multiple sclerosis (MS) mouse model, experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), leading to long-term stable reductions in clinical score, in part due to enhanced vascular integrity and apoptotic removal of infiltrated monocytes. As we have recently shown that hypoxia mimetics, drugs that stimulate hypoxia signaling pathways, confer similar protection, here we plan to explore the therapeutic potential of this finding and define the underlying mechanisms responsible by testing the hypothesis that hypoxia mimetics promote recovery from inflammatory demyelinating disease by enhancing vascular integrity and suppressing neuroinflammation via HIF-mediated signaling. The proposed research is relevant to public health and the mission of NIH because it is expected to lead to the development of novel therapeutic approaches aimed at treating MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Few adolescent girls and young women (AGYW, ≥16 to 24 years) at risk of HIV acquisition are initiating pre- exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for HIV prevention in Kenya. Thus, in the R00 parent award of this supplement application, we proposed refining and testing a new model to increase PrEP initiation among AGYW at HIV risk that has never been explored: formalized peer PrEP referral + HIV self-test delivery. Unexpected implementation challenges (e.g., approval delays, participant recruitment challenges), however, have had cost implications for this award so we are requesting additional resources to complete the proposed R00 parent award research on time and generate high-quality evidence on how to engage an important population in PrEP services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To combat malaria, new discoveries of parasite biology are highly desirable, especially those from the less studied lifecycle stages. We have discovered that an ancient proton pumping pyrophosphatase (PfVP1) is essential for ring stage development. We will investigate the mechanisms by which malaria parasites utilize pyrophosphate, but not ATP, as the energy source to pump protons and generate plasma membrane potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The field of psychobiology lacks robust, biologically informative biomarkers to evaluate the emerging role of mitochondria in the stress-disease cascade. We have assembled an interdisciplinary team of psychosocial, clinical, and mitochondrial scientists to examine the psychobiological regulation of cell-free mitochondrial DNA (cf-mtDNA) and validate dynamic features of stress-evoked cf-mtDNA responses across thousands of samples from healthy women and men. The combined i) multi-study psychosocial challenge approach, including nested (quasi)experimental manipulations of mitochondrial energy metabolism, ii) novel discovery-based human stress proteome analyses, and iii) laboratory experiments to dissect the molecular nature of cf-mtDNA, will provide foundational knowledge to develop novel markers of mitochondrial biology, which can subsequently be deployed at scale in clinical and epidemiological studies aiming to understand the basis of human health, resilience, and vulnerability to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to understand, at the level of cells and neural circuits, how visual information is detected and processed by the visual system so that it can contribute to our perception of the world around us. The discoveries made by this proposal regarding the function and organization of healthy visual system circuits will facilitate our understanding of how these circuits could be impacted by disease, and will help speed the advent of therapies designed to treat damage to, and diseases that afflict, the visual system and lead to blindness. More generally, understanding the mechanisms and neural circuits responsible for normal functioning of the visual system has important implications for a range of other diseases in other parts of the nervous system where impairment in the function of neural circuits has been implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Lack of representation of racial and ethnic minorities in genetic repositories, association studies, and prediction models results in their unequal benefit from medical and technological advancements, thus contributing to the persistence of health disparities. We will develop accessible methods to explore and meta-analyze data from diverse biobanks through a common coded language called phecodes and optimize phecode resolution for eye disease phenotypes (eye phecodes) with the hopes of reducing ocular health disparities. We will share these tools to allow others to practically leverage biobank data to explore ophthalmic disease patterns, associations, and disparities with results that are reliable, reproducible, and generalizable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is an aggressive, devastating malignancy with despondent morbidity and mortality. While there have been advancements in clinical imaging, histology, and cellular/molecular profiling, these advancements have occurred largely independent of one another, thus there is a need to integrate these to provide a more causal understanding of how clinical imaging phenotypes relate to pancreatic adenocarcinoma subtypes from more to less aggressive subtypes, and in the process establish “molecular omic-type to clinical phenotype” relationship in order to find new strategies to diagnosis and treat the disease. The work in this proposal will use cutting-edge cellular and tissue measurements of the microenvironment of pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) with computational systems biology (using integrated transcription, signaling, and metabolic networks), focusing on the of glycolytic and inflammatory characteristics of tumors in relation to specific histological tumor characteristics, in order to 1) develop a non-invasive imaging test (i.e. anatomical and metabolic imaging through PET/CT) to identify PDAC phenotypes that 2) lead to new potential cellular targets for treatment in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy is a groundbreaking treatment that has proven to be lifesaving for patients with blood cancers. This project is about making this treatment effective for patients with hard-to-treat solid tumors by integrating endoradiotherapy into CAR-T cell therapy. Our goal is to optimize this combinatorial therapy to enhance clinical benefits while minimizing adverse effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type-2 diabetes (T2D) is growing in an alarming rate in urban areas in many low and middle-income countries such as Bangladesh, leading to a higher risk for premature deaths, disability, and poverty. Evidence-based WHO guideline exists to help control T2D, yet effective strategies to adopt and sustain this recommended practice into routine urban primary care are unavailable – highlighting a major global unmet need for rigorous implementation research data. Our study addresses this gap and aims to evaluate the implementation and effectiveness outcomes of an integrated community-to-facility strategy for implementing the WHO best practices (HEARTS-D module) in Bangladeshi cities and other similar settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it introduces new strategies for systematically addressing the factuality and unfaithful reasoning of Large Language Models (LLMs) – the main barriers to using LLMs in biomedicine and healthcare applications, and posing the risk of spreading misinformation, potentially leading to misdiagnosis or incorrect treatment recommendations. The research will establish a foundation for advancing LLMs, ensuring they provide more accurate and trustworthy responses to support biomedical discovery and healthcare, refine the current development and evaluation processes of LLMs in the biomedical and health domains, and provide resources including benchmarks, methods, and tools to the community. Therefore, the proposed research aligns with the National Library of Medicine (NLM)'s mission to develop innovative biomedical informatics and data science methods, including natural language processing, artificial intelligence, and LLMs, to advance biomedical discovery and data-powered health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is the third leading cause of cancer mortality in the United States, and there are urgent needs to identify causally related protein biomarkers and build improved prediction models for pancreatic cancer risk. The proposed study will identify causally related protein biomarkers for pancreatic cancer using an innovative design of combining novel statistical methods and functional characterization and develop improved pancreatic cancer risk prediction models using novel methods. Knowledge generated by this project will not only significantly contribute to the etiologic understanding of pancreatic cancer, but also have potential utility in improving its risk assessment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative If science is to inform effective child protection policy and ultimately improve public health, the field needs an effective strategy for directly supporting policymakers’ use of research evidence, yet our field lacks an evidence- based model designed for this purpose. Accordingly, we propose a state-level randomized controlled trial (N = 30 states) of a formal, theory-based approach for appropriately supporting policymakers’ use of scientific evidence--known as the Research-to-Policy Collaboration (RPC) Model. This work has the potential to reduce population-level child maltreatment and protect children by improving the use of scientific information in policymaking, thus increasing the availability of evidence-based prevention programs and policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Temporal Interference (TI) is a non-invasive brain stimulation method with transformative potential for deep brain stimulation in neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders. This proposal aims to bridge the gap between theory and practice by investigating TI's mechanisms, its deep brain stimulation capabilities, frequency-dependent effects, and influence on brain components. Ultimately, our investigation into TI's mechanisms and efficacy promises a better understanding of this new non-invasive neuromodulation technique for both research and clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: While the lung is usually adept at repairing after injury, factors that impair restoration of normal gas exchange after repetitive injury remain poorly understood. In this proposal, we will identify and study signaling pathways, including Hypoxia Inducible Factor, that inhibit normal repair mechanisms and can be targeted to improve healing after injury, thus preventing or limiting fibrosis. We believe that this work will facilitate development of new therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes in Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pre-eclampsia is an obstetric condition that affects 5–8% of all pregnancies and is a leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide. Currently, no curative treatment options for pre-eclampsia exist. The goal of the proposed work is to develop a targeted, placenta-tropic lipid nanoparticle (LNP) platform for the delivery of therapeutic pro- angiogenic mRNA cargo to the placenta to treat pre-eclampsia during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In addition to core motor impairments, Parkinson's Disease often entails motivation-related symptoms such as apathy and depression. However, we lack a detailed understanding of the neural circuit interactions underlying how we select and perform effortful actions in the pursuit of our goals. By characterizing circuit mechanisms regulating the activity of different nigrostriatal dopamine projections and examining how these dopamine neuron subpopulations contribute to effortful reward-seeking behavior, this research program will yield critical new insights into the cell types and circuits supporting motivated behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a serious health and societal problem, and development of better therapies is needed. This project investigates neuroanatomical mechanisms by which administration of oxytocin, a potential novel treatment of AUD, can mediate its effects on alcohol drinking. Understanding these mechanisms is important for the development of novel treatments of this disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemodialysis is a lifeline for patients with kidney failure. Close to 50% of successful hemodialysis accesses develop frequent complications; however, the current imaging modality to diagnose such complications has several limitations. This grant proposes to examine an alternative imaging technique that is more sensitive, provides additional information on the nature of complication, and guides vascular interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Understanding of protein dynamics – and their relationship to protein sequence evolution – lags far behind understanding of stable protein structure despite the fact that few proteins could fulfill their biological functions effectively without specific dynamic properties. We have developed methods for real-time characterization of the functional dynamics of single molecules of a paradigmatic protein nanomachine in a family required for bacterial growth and pathogenesis. Our proposed studies will expand basic understanding of protein function and sequence evolution in a manner that can be applied to the development of new drugs modulating the function of dynamically active proteins and to the engineering of proteins to perform novel molecular activities of biomedical utility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The excess fluids removed from the lungs or abdomen of patients with malignant effusions could serve as substrates for liquid biopsy (i.e., molecular profiling of tumor cells in body fluids) to develop novel predictive biomarkers and discover drug targets to treat these frequent and devastating complications of metastatic breast cancer. UCSF investigators collaborated with Deepcell, a company that developed an artificial intelligence- assisted, morphology-based approach to isolate tumor cells away from the predominant immune cell populations in malignant effusions and successfully generated molecular profiles and morphology atlases of these cells. In this proposal, we expand this collaboration to validate the Deepcell platform and develop liquid biopsy tests to assess known actionable biomarkers and discover new ones, with a vision of transforming the treatment of malignant effusions from a palliative setting to a therapeutic opportunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A pattern of shortened weekday sleep and weekend recovery sleep begins to emerge as early as 8 years of age and has been shown to blunt positive emotional experiences, increasing risk for mental health disorders. The present set of studies will provide a mechanistic understanding of how this sleep pattern produces acute and long-term changes in positive valence systems (PVS) in both social and non-social contexts during a period of increased reward sensitivity. Results will provide needed insight into sleep’s role in psychiatric risk during a period of the lifespan marked by rapid changes in socioemotional functioning, including actionable targets for future research and interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal (GI) problems are among the most common concern reported by families of autistic children and youth, but efforts to understand the nuances of GI symptoms are stymied by a lack of longitudinal research using real-world clinical datasets. We will use a multimethod, participatory approach to: (1) qualitatively describe autistic people’s GI experiences throughout the lifespan; (2) quantitatively characterize GI symptom rates, presentations, trajectories, and responses to treatment among autistic children/youth using electronic health records (EHRs) from Children’s Hospital Los Angeles (CHLA) (with both structured data, e.g., diagnosis codes and prescriptions; and unstructured data, i.e., keywords extracted from clinical notes via natural language processing); and (3) build predictive models of risk of GI symptom profiles and response to treatment using both traditional and machine learning approaches. By using longitudinal analyses and real-world clinical data, the proposed study provides a more nuanced prediction of GI symptom profiles and response to treatment, and holds promise for informing future targeted interventions to improve care for autistic individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to elucidate the novel role of S100A7 signaling in enhancing immune evasive mechanisms, especially in African American (AA) triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients. In addition, these studies will determine if S100A7 and its downstream signaling molecules could be used as novel therapeutic targets and prognostic biomarkers for AA TNBC using different pre-clinical mouse models and patient samples. These studies will also provide novel insights for developing innovative immune-based therapies against aggressive and metastatic TNBC observed in AA women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The unresolved question of how the fetus and placenta avoid being rejected by the maternal immune system has major implications for understanding potential disorders of human pregnancy such as spontaneous abortion and preeclampsia. Capitalizing on recent work demonstrating the potent immune-modulatory function of the carbohydrate structures that decorate placental proteins, this proposal seeks to gain insight into how these structures suppress maternal immune responses both systemically and locally, within the pregnant uterus. We anticipate our work will also foster application of underlying mechanisms to immune tolerance induction in the clinical arena.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project aims to comprehensively measure Aβ42/40 and phosphorylated tau species in plasma from the Health and Aging Brain Study-Health Disparities (HABS-HD) study. The overarching hypothesis of this project is that plasma biomarkers related to AD pathology present differently among diverse populations and as a result have different relations to established clinical outcomes such as PET amyloid levels and cognitive outcomes. To test this hypothesis, we propose to characterize plasma p-tau217 and Aβ42/40 in Mexican Americans, AA and non-Hispanic white populations of the HABS-HD study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal follows up on our robust finding that mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) antagonism can greatly improve donor heart function and ischemic tolerance. We also show that cardiac preservation is associated with increased MR expression and its organization into molecular condensates or clusters. Our proposal will clarify how MR condensates form and if dampening MR signaling can improve heart function in pigs and human heart which can ultimately improve heart transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extensive research efforts have led to substantial advances in our understanding about how the brain regulates the eating termination due to meal-induced satiety, but the role of sensory inputs in feeding regulation, such as olfactory cues of food, is under-studied. We will investigate whether the brain circuit involving three nodes, namely the olfactory bulb (OB), ventral subiculum (vSub) and ventral medium hypothalamus (VMH), regulates food-derived odor-suppressed food intake. These studies will start to reveal the neurobiological mechanisms of this novel concept that olfactory signals prevent overeating, and may identify rational targets for the development of novel therapeutic approaches to combat obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The basal forebrain (BF) plays a pivotal role in regulating cortical activity and plasticity to support vital cognitive functions such as attention. Recent findings have prompted a re-evaluation of the role of its cholinergic neurons in attention, shifting the focus to alternative circuits. We propose study a major cortex-projecting inhibitory projection: parvalbumin-expressing GABAergic neurons (BF-PV). Our research will uncover the neural circuitry and computations behind sustained attention, providing insights into the basal forebrain's role in cognition and inform therapeutic avenues for attention disorders and BF-linked dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Few children with recurrent neuroblastoma survive, so we have developed a molecule that binds to ROR1 on neuroblastoma and to CD3 on T cells causing the T cells to kill the cancer cells. Because nearby cancer cells will upregulate a protein called PD-L1 to escape immune surveillance, we also included a PD-L1 binder so that the T cells will kill the cancer cells that are trying to escape. We propose to test this molecule in multiple patient-derived neuroblastoma models, including those with heterogeneous ROR1 expression to determine whether this molecule should advance toward human clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative Our goal is to decipher how neural circuits in the orbitofrontal cortex support adaptive decision-making and generate choice biases. We propose that different subcortical projections of orbitofrontal cortex have specialized roles, each transmitting specific information and influencing particular choice biases. This has crucial implications for understanding brain malfunctions and informing circuit-specific therapeutics for drug abuse disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to identify the unique signatures underlying the potent effect of the calcium-activated phosphatase calcineurin (CN) on acute pancreatitis (AP), which is a major public health problem that has limited therapeutic modalities. In the current proposal, we will firstly map key signaling pathways that are modulated by CN in AP and secondly identify novel CN substrates within these pathways. The proposal is relevant to the NIH mission relating to the application of knowledge to enhance health and reduce illness and disability.

Our research will reveal key loci of potential dysfunction and therapeutic intervention in psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Autism spectrum disorder and neurodevelopmental delay (ASD/NDD) are complex conditions, and although many different genes have been implicated in their etiology, no clear molecular mechanism that leads to these conditions has been identified. We propose to integrate molecular technologies as well as patient datasets to holistically map how 72 genes associated with ASD/NDD impact brain function, seeking shared points of convergence between these genes. Our results will dramatically expand our understanding of how loss-of- function of risk genes mechanistically contributes to ASD/NDD, provide a framework for large-scale interrogation of gene function in the brain, and potentially identify common points of molecular dysregulation leading to ASD/NDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The public frequently perceives vaping e-cigarettes as being less harmful than smoking cigarettes. However, it has become clear that vaping involves a lot of the same cardiovascular risk as smoking. The proposed project will investigate the cardiovascular effects of dual use of e-cigarettes and cigarettes on the human, rat, and cellular levels, focusing on whether dual use increases, decreases, or has the same harmful cardiovascular effects as exclusive use of either product.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative There is a critical need to increase vaccine acceptance, especially among populations with health disparities, including Black and Latinx populations. As new types of vaccines are developed and released, it becomes increasingly important to understand the multi-level factors (including social media and social networks) that affect vaccine acceptance among these populations. This application seeks to use a novel approach to recruit participants and study these factors as well as to build a visualization tool that can be used by researchers and health departments. This project is being conducted in collaboration with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM), along with a team of scientists from a recent NASEM report, in order to improve likelihood of broadly translating and implementing the findings throughout public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative In 2016, Dengvaxia, the first licensed dengue virus (DENV) vaccine, was administered to >830,000 school- aged Filipino children without prior serological testing. Subsequently, DENV-seronegative children who received Dengvaxia developed severe disease after breakthrough DENV infection (BTDI) and the efficacy of Dengvaxia waned over time, underscoring a critical need for an in-depth understanding of antibody and T-cell responses following Dengvaxia vaccination. In collaboration with the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine Philippines, we will determine the baseline DENV serostatus of Dengvaxia recipients to assess the long-term safety and effectiveness of Dengvaxia, and characterize humoral and T-cell responses induced by Dengvaxia prior to and after BTDI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major hurdle in developing effective neurological treatments has been translation of scientific discoveries from rodent models to humans. To close this critical translational gap, we will use 3D organoid- and marmoset tissue- derived-tools to explore ARX-associated mutations linked to cortical malformation, epilepsy, and intellectual disability. The overarching goals of this project are to develop a marmoset model system to represent the neurobiology of the human brain to advance the utility of the marmoset model to benefit the brain health research community.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This study is responsive to the identified need for more information on the health and corresponding healthcare needs of women veterans, as well as recognized gaps in the understanding of the gender-specific impact of military service on female and male veterans’ long-term health. Given that trauma exposure can have negative and lasting effects on health, traumatic stress and mental health sequelae (i.e., PTSD, depression, anxiety, and substance abuse) are a public health concern that is of particular relevance to VA clinical services. To date, risk models linking military service with health outcomes have been understudied in older populations, and especially in older women. Combining data from two important VA cooperative studies—the Health of Vietnam Era Women’s Study and the Veteran Health Study—will provide the foundation for key insights into gender differences in the long-term health effects of military service, including risk for cardiovascular and other chronic disease morbidity, as well as mortality due to these and other causes, including suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inherited mutations in the gene DDX41 are the most common cause of genetic predisposition to Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS), a blood disease where the bone marrow fails to produce blood cells of sufficient quality and quantity. The goal of this proposal is to engineer a model of MDS in mice that accurately follows the natural genetic progression of the disease, beginning with inherited mutation of DDX41. These mouse models can then be used to elucidate the mechanisms by which mutations in DDX41 promote MDS onset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  TDP-43 proteinopathy and hippocampal sclerosis are established features of Alzheimer's Disease, but their complex interactions are not well understood. This proposal aims to leverage spatial sequencing technology to delve into the regional, cellular, and molecular dimensions of the interplay between new TDP-43 species and hippocampal sclerosis in the context of Alzheimer's Disease. Our study will facilitate the translation of recent advances in spatial transcriptomic studies to practical applications for Alzheimer's Disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overall objective of this study is to develop a well-defined 3D bioprinted in vitro model that mimics the molecular, cellular, and metabolic interplay occurring in the bone-tumor microenvironment of metastatic prostate cancer and confirm that it is responsive to novel targeted and non-targeted diagnostic and therapeutic modalities. The rationale for undertaking the proposed research is that development of a reproducible predictive PC tumor- bone-vasculature model will accelerate therapeutic development for PC and minimize clinical failures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Normal brain function depends on the orderly development of circuits in the cerebral cortex and on their intact function. Knowledge of the normal circuitry provides a foundation for understanding the causes of impaired brain function and developing corrective measures. Our studies of the normal circuitry between early visual cortical areas will provide greater insight into the causes and effects of central vision defects when these circuits are damaged by stroke or other neurological or developmental cause. In particular, our studies of feedback circuits between different visual cortical areas will help our understanding of how these pathways mediate the influence of stimulus context on neuronal responsivity, spatial integration, and changes in visual sensitivity associated with top-down attention. Moreover, understanding how these circuits operate in normal vision will provide a foundation for understanding the consequences of their dysfunction in neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as autism, schizophrenia and attention deficits disorders, which have been directly linked to abnormalities in inter-areal connectivity [e.g. Belmonte et al. J. Neurosci. (2004) 24:9228-9231; Lynall et al. J. Neurosci. (2010) 30:9477-9487].
