IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our current clinical approach to re-irradiation is not based on data, as guidelines vary widely and are not rooted in observed toxicities. This proposal aims at developing a novel re-irradiation framework integrating the patient’s response to the first treatment and the time the organ had to recover. This proposal will advance knowledge how to incorporate the patient’s individual response to the first radiation treatment, and the time that has passed since, into the planning of re-irradiation, which is crucial to control for the variability among patients to enable correct interpretation of toxicity data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE  Delayed identification of infant head malformation is causing unnecessary medical complications and societal costs, partly because of the absence of tools available to pediatric offices. For this Fast-track SBIR proposal, PediaMetrix Inc. has joined forces with clinical institutions to develop and evaluate a 3D mobile scanning tool that provides cranial volume and malformation measurements. Our tool, called SoftSpotTM, will improve the early detection and management of infant cranial malformations at the point-of-care and avoid delayed, costly and intensive treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative (Parent Grant) Protein allostery is a fundamental phenomenon in which ligand binding at one site affects substrate activity or ligand binding at a second, distal site of the protein. Allostery is a primary mode of regulation for enzymes and other proteins that drive signal transduction and metabolism, and it is now being used in some drug development efforts, even though the mechanisms of allostery are not well understood. The work in this project will characterize dynamics and allosteric communication pathways for the homodimeric enzymes chorismate mutase and thymidylate synthase, and for engineered optogenetic conformational switch proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders (ADRD) research represents an area of major national investment. But ADRD research faces delays and risks to internal and external validity resulting from consistent challenges to efficient and generalizable accrual. Recruitment registries are tools to address these challenges by establishing large repositories of individuals who are potentially eligible and willing to participate in research, expediting discovery. This proposal will provide researchers with critical evidence to instruct methods to diversify registries by including people from the most disadvantaged neighborhoods and addressing sample bias in these unique recruitment interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Balancing between tumor control and preserving post-treatment speech outcomes is of primary importance in surgical management of patients with early-stage laryngeal cancer. Transoral laser microsurgery has become the primary surgical approach to endolaryngeal tumors, although no reliable approaches are approved to aid the surgeon's intraoperative visual assessment of tumor borders. This study will demonstrate clinical feasibility for a novel, combinatorial optical imaging approach to aid intraoperative identification of laryngeal cancer borders for surgical treatment while preserving essential normal tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food security – having consistent access to healthy foods – is important for prevention and management of diet-sensitive chronic diseases such as diabetes. This is especially critical for communities of color who are disproportionately impacted both by food insecurity and diet-sensitive chronic diseases. Policies such as the recent CalAIM Medicaid waiver, which is a recently implemented policy that allows healthcare organizations to be reimbursed for providing healthy food, address this double burden. This study will assess the impact of the CalAIM policy change on food insecurity, diet quality, obesity, and indicators of cardiometabolic risk among diverse patients with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Diabetic retinopathy (DR) is a common complication of diabetes mellitus that causes significant damage to the blood vessels and nerve cells of the retina. While our previous studies established the role of 12/15-lipoxygenase (12/15-LO) enzyme in inducing damage to retinal blood vessels in diabetes, there is still a gap in understanding of the underlying mechanisms. This project will investigate the role of G-coupled protein receptors (GPR31 and GPR39), suggested receptors for 12/15-LO metabolites in retinal vascular damage that occurs in DR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Opioids are often prescribed to manage neuropathic pain, but their addictive properties have led to the opioid crisis, posing a serious global challenge. This has created an urgent need for the development of non-addictive pain management alternatives. Our proposed research is to validate and explore human equilibrative nucleoside transporters (ENTs) as potential targets for pain relief. Our research proposal, if successful, could provide a platform to improve the lives of patients suffering from neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This innovative study seeks to determine the role of dietary intake in supporting the growth of cognition- changing gut microbes and by-products that influence cognitive health in breast cancer survivors during receipt of chemotherapy. If proven correct, our study could provide compelling mechanistic evidence to explain how diet consumed during chemotherapy impacts the development or severity of cognitive impairment due to chemotherapy treatment in breast cancer survivors by modulating the gut microbiota and its products. The key outcomes include our first understanding of how diet and the gut microbiome impact the development or severity of cancer treatment-related cognitive impairment (CRCI), dietary or probiotic interventions designed to reduce incidence and severity of CRCI, and increased efforts to change local and nationwide policy to reimburse individuals with CRCI for the purchase of cognitively beneficial meals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE High grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC) is the most lethal gynecologic cancer with current treatment strategies including the naturally derived compound, Paclitaxel. Unfortunately, drug resistance to current therapies has led to relapse and eventually death in ovarian cancer patients. Combinatorial treatment of cytotoxic natural products didesmethyrocaglamide and phyllanthusmin34 as well as mechanism of action will be studied in vitro and in vivo as novel strategies for treating this deadly cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Nicotine pouches and “non-menthol” cigarettes are new tobacco product categories with rapidly growing user populations. We found that the industry added artificial flavors to these products, including sweeteners and cooling chemicals. In our proposed study we will examine the content of flavors and sweeteners in these products, and test whether they make it easier to become addicted to nicotine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The cancer substrates regulated by arginylation and subsequent degradation are largely unknown. This proposal aims to unbiasedly unveil the arginylation substrates and their sites in cancer cells and recruit ATE1 to achieve targeted protein degradation through arginylation-ubiquitination-degradataion cascade. The novel approach called arginylation targeting chimera (ArgTAC) holds full potential to be developed as cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recently, our lab developed a novel immune therapeutic approach delivering TT as a neoantigen surrogate into tumors by Listeria infection in vivo, which attracts pre-existing TT-specific memory T cells (generated earlier in life during childhood vaccinations) now killing the highly immunogenic tumor cells. Our ultimate goal is to test this promising therapy in patients with advanced PDAC. However, in contrast to all other Listeria-based therapies in patients, our Listeria needs to be injected intraperitoneally in order to reach tumors and metastases. This is completely new and requires extra precautions. Monitoring Listeria in vivo is such a precaution. Therefore, we have uploaded Listeria-TT with 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) and demonstrated that this Listeria could be visualized in tumors and metastases by PET/CT. The main goal of this proposal is to finetune the Listeria-TT- FDG for human application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Intrusive memories of a traumatic experience are leading predictors of the onset, maintenance, and severity of transdiagnostic post-traumatic mental health difficulties; however, transdiagnostic treatments for such memories are limited as their underlying physiological mechanisms remain unclear. Tuning in to the distinct sensory-rich properties of trauma-related intrusive memories, the current project will test how the neurochemical and electrophysiological regulators of intrinsic sensory cortical activity are related to the day-to-day experiences of vivid trauma-related intrusions. Findings from this work will identify novel candidate targets for neurotherapeutics in the transdiagnostic treatment of intrusive memories in trauma-exposed individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Patients with Temporal Lobe Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s Disease suffer from debilitating impairments of learning and memory, which can have devastating consequences on everyday actions such as the ability to safely navigate back home. While considerable work has identified how neurons in the medial entorhinal cortex and hippocampus collectively form a “map” of the external environment to enable spatial learning and memory, little is known about how these maps can be flexibly used across environments with different cognitive demands. Here, we propose to use cutting-edge technology to determine how brain-wide interactions shape the flexibility of neural activity in entorhinal cortex, which in turn, will aid in elucidating potential neural mechanisms which may go awry in neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular pain is highly prevalent, leading to decreased quality of life and suffering, and yet its pharmacologic management remains very limited. Protracted ocular pain is often associated with chronic inflammation that persists in the absence of ongoing insult. This project, grounded on our two pre-clinical models of chronic ocular pain, proposes to determine the analgesic efficacy and underlying mechanisms of topical neurokinin-1 receptor (NK1R) antagonism, as an effective non-addictive therapeutic strategy for chronic ocular pain management, utilizing its dual anti-nociceptive (anti-pain) and anti-inflammatory (thereby anti-neuropathic) properties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While patients with advanced or metastatic triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) have a poor prognosis, survival can be extended, albeit, modestly using a combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy, known as ‘chemo- immunotherapy’, reflecting the longstanding rationale that the immune system can be an integral player in the overall anti-cancer response. Here, we are testing a novel approach in preclinical models of TNBC, one based on the identification of new tumor antigens generated by the chemotherapy insult, which will then be utilized as a ‘vaccine’ to immunize the host potentially enriching the breadth of the anti-cancer immune response. Overall, immunization against these novel tumor antigens, termed ‘chemo-neoepitopes’, has the potential to enhance the efficacy of existing regimens and, thus, may have important implications for expanding treatment options for patients with advanced or metastatic TNBC receiving standard-of-care alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall Core The Center for Biomolecular Structure (CBMS) presents state-of-the-art structural biology facilities at the National Synchrotron Light Source II (NSLS-II) to the world-wide community of researchers interested in the study of biological structure. These facilities include 1. micro-beam and highly automated macromolecular crystallography, 2. several modes of x-ray scattering from non-crystalline material, including from solutions, scattering images from tissues, and others, and 3. synchrotron x-ray footprinting of biological materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Per Parent Award R01CA259046 Non-genetic changes in gene expression promote melanoma progression and metastasis; however, whether aberrant miRNA sequestration by competitive endogenous RNAs (ceRNAs) is involved in this process is unknown. We have discovered a cluster of ceRNA genes located on the frequently gained chromosome 1q region, and found that the mRNA with the greatest predicted ceRNA potential, CEP170, promotes melanoma migration/invasion in vitro and metastasis in vivo. We propose to define the miRNA-dependent oncogenic potential of CEP170 and characterize how the deregulation of downstream miRNAs and ceRNA effectors provokes melanoma metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking remains the leading preventable cause of death in the United States, and there are persistent and significant disparities in tobacco use among transgender and gender diverse (TGD) individuals. Stigma, discrimination, gender dysphoria, and other gender minority stressors likely contribute to these disparities, and the increased burden of gender minority stress may also be driving higher prevalence rates of anxiety and depression, both of which are more common among TGD individuals and among those who smoke relative to comparison samples. This study will (1) explore the ways in which gender minority stressors and associated anxiety and depression compromise smoking cessation among TGD individuals, identifying elements in an existing smoking cessation intervention that need to be adjusted to meet their unique needs; (2) adapt an existing smoking cessation intervention for TGD individuals; and (3) evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the adapted intervention in a pilot randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Thyroid cancer affects up to 1-in-10 people in the United States, and there are several acceptable treatments. While prognosis is excellent, these treatments are costly to society and may produce significant adverse effects. This study uses a preference-elicitation instrument to measure how patients value different treatments for small, low-risk thyroid cancers so that we can maximize value-for-cost through consensus guidelines and policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Existing and proposed mental health quality measures may be biased against health systems, facilities, and clinicians serving more Black and Hispanic patients, measuring the patients they serve rather than the quality of care they provide. This research will use detailed records data from five large health systems to evaluate potential biases in existing and proposed measures and evaluate alternatives to reduce biases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulated proteostasis, particularly protein turnover, is a hallmark of brain aging and Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), but many details remain to be understood about protein turnover due to previous technical limitations. In this proposal, leveraging new protein-tagging methodologies, l aim to (1) identify aberrations in neuronal protein turnover dynamics and their functional consequences during aging and AD and (2) understand a neuron-intrinsic regulator of protein turnover (autophagy/lysosome) and a neuron-extrinsic regulator of neuronal protein turnover (microglia) during aging and AD. The findings from my studies will substantially increase our basic biological understanding of neuronal proteostasis/protein turnover during brain aging and AD, and ultimately identify new targets to promote resilience to brain aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in five American children live in rural regions, and almost 3 million of these have chronic health conditions. The overall objective of this project is to analyze three States’ all-payer claims data to comprehensively evaluate urban-rural disparities in healthcare utilization and quality for children with complex or disabling health conditions, and to identify community and health system factors associated with these disparities. This research will be the first population-level analysis to characterize the magnitude of urban-rural disparities in healthcare quality for children with chronic and disabling conditions, generating foundational knowledge to improve clinical care and public health support for this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Structural variants (SVs) are frequently associated with disease phenotypes and represent the largest and most complex source of human genomic variation. Limitations in sequencing technologies lead to challenges in the accurate discovery and characterization of SVs, but which can be overcome by taking an integrative approach leveraging the advantages of multiple platforms, as well as by utilizing more comprehensive reference genome representations such as the pangenome graph. In this proposal, I will be constructing an SV calling pipeline which is versatile to technological developments across sequencing platforms, and which can leverage the latest developments in graph genome reference representations to achieve high-performance results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with atrial fibrillation (AF), a common cardiac arrhythmia, endure higher symptom burden and lower quality of life (QOL) compared to men, but the factors that contribute to these gender differences remain largely unknown. The proposed research will elucidate and compare differences in social (social support, living situation, social network interaction) and biological (epicardial adipose tissue and adipokines) factors that influence AF symptoms and QOL in women and men. Findings generated from this investigation will provide foundational knowledge for a program of research focused on interventions that bridge the gender gap and improve symptom burden and QOL in AF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Stressful events are a well-established risk factor for suicidal ideation, but a more granular understanding of when stressful events increase risk for suicidal ideation, as well as which person-level markers exacerbate this risk relationship, is imperative. This research will: (1) evaluate the direct effect of real-time stressful events on concurrent and prospective momentary suicidal ideation, (2) evaluate the moderating effects of trait and state impulsivity and emotion dysregulation on the stressful events – momentary suicidal ideation relationship, and (3) explore the propensity to experience suicidal ideation in response to prior stress as a potential moderator of this association. Findings of the proposed research will specify person-level conditions that portend imminent suicidal ideation, information that has the potential to inform the development of effective just-in-time interventions, consistent with precision care objectives of the NIMH Strategic Plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This SBIR project aims to continue developing and validating a novel magnetic cytometer to rapidly isolate, identify and sort single intact and viable cells from heterogeneous cell population. The project will provide a powerful tool for single cell analysis and have a broad impact in both basic research and clinical applications.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The study goal is to promote viral load suppression among women with serious mental illness (SMI) and HIV in Botswana, given that these women are especially vulnerable to psychiatric medication nonadherence and symptom exacerbation, which are made worse by stigma and threaten antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence. We propose to test an intervention to reduce stigma due to the statuses of SMI and HIV, against an attention control condition, in the high-risk transition period after discharge from an initial psychiatric hospitalization. Enabling women with SMI and HIV to resist stigma has the potential to improve their HIV outcomes and empower these women to elicit broader, structural-level change.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: INSTITUTE FOR IN VITRO SCIENCES, INC.
PHR: Project Narrative The Institute for In Vitro Sciences is organizing and hosting a series of expert Workshops (8 so far) to identify, discuss and publish recommendations for the best scientific/technical approaches to the generation and interpretation of in vitro assay (initially genetic toxicity) data that can be used to compare toxicity across different tobacco products, and within and between classes of tobacco products. These recommendations will assist public health researchers in performing high quality experiments to understand the relative toxicities of conventional cigarettes, the new Electronic Nicotine Delivery Systems (ENDS), and other tobacco-related products. Such studies will then provide public health officials with the high quality data they need to make science-based decisions during the regulation of tobacco and nicotine containing products.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Workshop series to identify, discuss and develop recommendations for the optimal generation and use of in vitro assay data for tobacco product regulation

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: THE FEDERAL UNIVERSITY OF TECHNOLOGY, AKURE, NIGERIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intervertebral disc degeneration (IVDD) is a multifactorial process regarded as the primary cause of low back pain that exerts an enormous public health burden and disability on millions of individuals with current conserva- tive surgical options having limited treatment efficacy. This study evaluates the modulating role of gene therapy, an unleveraged therapeutic intervention, on pyroptosis-mediated pathways in a rat model of IVDD progression over 12 weeks. Uncovering the potential of gene therapy as an alternative treatment option for low back pain and its role in pyroptosis proteins aligns with the National Institute of Health’s mission and Fogarty International Center’s vision statements to reduce disease burden and disability, improve health, and extend longevity for all people. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acquired therapy resistance is a major problem for patients with metastatic prostate cancer. This proposal seeks to identify novel strategies to prevent acquired therapy resistance by studying a rare subtype of prostate cancer with IDH1 mutation that fails to acquire therapy resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rural areas experience several vaccine-related disparities, yet little is known about two salient public health issues (COVID-19 vaccination and general vaccine hesitancy) in such areas. The proposed study will analyze existing data on a national sample of participants to provide an in-depth understanding of how rurality affects COVID-19 vaccine coverage and general vaccine hesitancy. Findings will lay the foundation for future interventions to increase COVID-19 vaccine coverage and decrease general vaccine hesitancy in rural areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is a major public health concern in the United States, and healthcare systems have begun implementing evidence-based screening, prevention, and intervention approaches to mitigate risk. New national process and outcome quality measures are needed to assess whether suicide prevention processes are being implemented and whether suicide outcomes are improved. This proposed R01 application develops and tests quality measures for suicide prevention across multiple health systems in partnership with leading quality organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is a growing mental health crisis among older adults, which may be exacerbated by limited access to mental health specialists in the rapidly growing Medicare Advantage program. This project will characterize geographic access to mental health specialists for older adults and evaluate how access to specialists impacts mental health treatment and outcomes for older adults in the Medicare Advantage program. This application will support a new investigator who aspires to a research career focused on improving access to mental and behavioral health treatment in underserved populations and will allow him to develop new skills necessary to achieving this goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Soil-transmitted parasitic nematodes infect over a billion people around the world and can cause devastating and sometimes fatal illness, but their basic biology remains almost entirely unexplored. The proposed research will investigate how temperature cues shape the specialized behavioral and physiological responses of parasitic nematodes. Our results will elucidate the key molecular and cellular mechanisms that underlie the remarkable thermal adaptability of mammalian parasitic nematodes, establishing an essential foundation to enable the development of novel interventional strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to address the pervasiveness of structural racism and discrimination (SRD) and its impact on the health of rural Black adolescents. Integrating Life Course Theory with community-based systems dynamics, our study will investigate potential intervention strategies aimed at reducing adolescent exposure to SRD and mitigating the impact of SRD within neighborhoods, schools, and peer networks on adolescent substance use and mental health. Study findings will yield data-driven recommendations for policy and community-level interventions; offering insights into key implementation factors while advancing efforts to reduce adolescent health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Diffuse midline glioma (DMG) is a lethal form of brain tumors that occurs in the brain stem region of children and young adults. DMG is an exceptionally challenging cancer to treat because of its unique cellular features and location, resulting in a median survival time of 9-12 months and a 5-year survival rate that is nearly 0%. This proposal aims to develop drug delivery technologies that can facilitate mRNA therapies for DMG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a deadly under-recognized disease characterized by high blood pressure in the lungs and right heart failure. While there are several medicines available to treat PAH, none cure the disease nor address right heart failure directly. In this proposal, we will conduct a clinical trial to determine if a new class of drugs called sodium glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitors, currently used to treat diabetes and heart failure, will improve right heart function and outcomes in PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Rising syphilis cases have led to shortages in the treatment of choice ‐ single‐dose intramuscular penicillin – leading to increased reliance on multiday therapy with doxycycline, since high rates of drug resistance preclude use of azithromycin as an alternative single‐dose therapy. This proposal outlines development and validation of two complementary types of molecular tests to detect genotypic determinants of drug resistance to azithromycin and doxycycline which could be applied at the point of patient care to inform antibiotic therapy and for public health monitoring of emerging doxycycline resistance. The point‐of‐care strategy will develop an allele‐speciﬁc variant of a rapid, Loop‐mediated isothermal ampliﬁcation (LAMP) assay developed by our laboratory to detect Treponema pallidum, the etiologic agent of syphilis; a second, complementary approach will develop an amplicon‐next‐generation sequencing assay for detection of T. pallidum drug resistance in the clinical laboratory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a highly metastatic subtype of breast cancer with low survival rate and limited therapeutic options and therefore, novel and effective therapies are urgently needed for TNBC treatment. We discovered that PBK kinase is a driver of anoikis resistance, a cell state that promotes TNBC tumor growth and metastasis, and thus, the studies in this proposal aim to establish PBK as a driver of TNBC tumor growth and metastasis, and establish small-molecule inhibitor of PBK kinase as novel and efficacious therapeutic agents for TNBC treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Rapid fluctuations in the strength of synaptic connections in the brain underlie the complex patterns of neural activity which drive all behaviors including those that require the retrieval of stored information in memories. Therefore, understanding how synapses operate is crucial to our understanding of cognitive deficits associated with aging and aging-related neurological disorders. In this project we will determine how the properties of synaptic connections directly map onto cognitive processes that allow us to separate similar instances in episodic memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Vollger, Mitchell PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to decode the regulatory elements in fast-evolving regions of the human genome, segmental duplications, shedding light on their roles in human evolution and susceptibility to diseases. By understanding these genetic components, the findings could pave the way for novel therapeutic targets and improved health outcomes. Ultimately, this project seeks to enhance knowledge about the functional contribution of duplications to the human genetic makeup, with the potential to uncover mechanisms of disease and adaptation in these unique regions. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Follicular lymphoma is the most common indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and while it has a highly variable clinical course, advanced stage patients requiring treatment who have an early clinical failure (within 2 years of diagnosis) have very poor outcomes. We have identified a tumor gene expression signature that can be used at diagnosis to predict early clinical failure and propose to conduct both analytic and clinical validation in order to improve clinical trials and care of patients with follicular lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy represents a unique physiological situation in which the mother harbors within her a genetically foreign fetus. We propose to study how the mother’s immune system is balanced to prevent rejection of the fetus while guaranteeing the mother’s health and lifetime reproductive success. The studies will provide novel insights into the regulation of the immune system and into disorders of pregnancy such as preeclampsia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Candida species, including the multidrug-resistant C. auris and C. glabrata, are opportunistic fungal pathogens that cause severe, life-threatening bloodstream infections (candidemia) in critically ill patients. While Candida gut colonization is a key step in the development of candidemia, there has been little research on how clinical risk factors and host immune pathology contribute to gut colonization. By examining clinical, immune, and Candida genomic determinants that predispose to colonization (including with C. auris and glabrata), this project will provide key insights to allow for eventual development of personalized treatment strategies to avert Candida colonization and infection in vulnerable patients.

PHR: NARRATIVE Thanks to advances in genome editing technologies, it is possible to generate nonhuman primates (NHPs) with precise germline genomic alterations, enabling researchers to generate highly refined models of human disease; however, the time and cost associated with existing technologies limits the availability of these NHPs. Here we propose an innovative technology to aid in the rapid and cost effective generation of transgenic NHPs for research. This resource will significantly benefit science across multiple disciplines, and pave the way for additional technologies to improve transgenic NHP research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA), a lethal cancer is characterized by frequent metastasis, immune evasion and therapy resistance. We have recently demonstrated that pleiotrophin (PTN) is a metastasis-associated protein in breast cancer and that inhibiting PTN reduces metastasis in manner dependent on the adaptive immune system. PTN has also been linked to PDA progression. Here we propose to test the efficacy of PTN inhibition in the context of PDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overarching goal of our research is to determine the causes and elucidate the mechanisms of early onset colorectal cancer (EOCRC). In this proposal we will test the hypothesis that early life exposure to commonly used antibiotics will alter the gut microbiome and inflammatory microenvironment to increase the risk of EOCRC, using preclinical models. The results from these studies will allow us to identify developmental stages of susceptibility to antibiotics, inform the development of novel strategies to identify high risk individuals and interventions to minimize risk of EOCRC, make informed decisions on how to mitigate the deleterious effects of antibiotics that are indispensable for fighting infections, and provide the foundation for future studies to identify components of human microbiota that mediate increased risk for EOCRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Detection of pancreatic cancer at early stages (when curable treatments are effective) could represent an effective strategy to improve the survival rate of pancreatic cancer. Our prior studies have established blood- based proteomic assays that showed high accuracy in detecting pancreatic cancer from healthy and benign disease controls in multiple independent cohorts. The current proposal will carry out analytical and clinical validations of the proteomic assays, which could be potentially deployed for clinical utilities if successfully validated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with Fabry disease experience debilitating chronic pain in addition to episodic pain evoked by heat or exercise, yet there is a dearth of literature examining the mechanisms that contribute to pain in these patients. Sensory neurons in Fabry disease exhibit increased excitability and spontaneous activity. This proposal investigates the regulation of voltage-gated sodium channels contributing to neuronal excitability in Fabry disease and determines the role of elevated neuronal excitability in heat-evoked pian crises in Fabry disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: This study aims to identify a cost-effective and scalable strategy for reducing disparities in access to mental health services among the rapidly growing population of homebound older adults. It plans to evaluate a novel digital mental health intervention for depression, supported by lay providers within aging service agencies, and systematically examine the implementation process, pinpointing barriers, facilitators, and conditions for sustainment from multi-stakeholder perspectives. The expected findings aspire to guide the implementation of accessible, scalable, and cost-effective depression care within aging services, a non-specialty sector with unparalleled reach to the target demographic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid addiction has taken a form of epidemic in the U.S., resulting in a high number of opioid related overdose deaths. While opioid maintenance provides the gold standard treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD), it has been unsuccessful to prevent relapse to short acting opioids and other substances and to keep OUD individuals in treatment for long-term. In this application, we propose that a combined guanfacine and mindfulness therapy as an adjunct to buprenorphine maintenance therapy will improve stress provoked craving and opioid cue provoked craving compared to guanfacine alone or mindfulness alone treatment in OUD individuals, and thus will ultimately reduce relapse to illicit drugs and enhance treatment retention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric post-cardiac arrest syndrome (PCAS) is a state of complex pathophysiology that includes myocardial dysfunction and systemic and cardiac inflammation, and impaired ventricular function and elevated biomarkers of inflammation are thought to be associated with mortality in small, retrospective studies. Through echocardiography, including advanced ventricular function measures including global longitudinal strain (GLS), and circulating biomarker measurement, this project strives to identify key components of pediatric PCAS and their association with mortality. These measures, in addition to clinical factors, will be used to identify subphenotypes of pediatric PCAS that are associated with outcomes which will be critical in identifying patients at high risk for poor outcomes and thus may provide benefits for targeted therapies in future interventional trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our contribution in this project is expected to be the identification of gut and tumor tissue microbes and immune cells linked to the Empirical Dietary Inflammatory Pattern (EDIP) that drives malignant progression in colon tissue and underlies poor survival among colorectal cancer patients. Our study includes two major aspects of innovation: 1) Integrating a pipeline of novel sensitive bioinformatics tools (elasticnet and exotic) i) to detect parsimonious, yet highly informative microbial profiles in the gut (stool samples); and ii) to isolate a wide range of microbes typically in low abundance (compared to human immune cells) in the tumor microenvironment; while 2) demonstrating how a specific diet pattern (EDIP) influences gut and tumor tissue microbiota, their interactions with immune cells and the consequent clinical outcomes of these interactions for CRC progression and death. This contribution is relevant to public health because it is expected to provide a solid foundation upon which to design precision medicine-based dietary pattern strategies for mitigating inflammatory dietary pattern-related (high-EDIP) gut and tumor tissue microbial dysbiosis and improving the survival of CRC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis is the leading cause of death in mankind due to infections, and more than 8 million new cases occur each year with 1.2 million deaths per year. Coinfection with HIV-1 has rendered the control of tuberculosis very difficult, and we have discovered a new method of augmenting host defense so that both M. tuberculosis which causes tuberculosis and HIV-1 which causes AIDS can be controlled using a new class of Sirtuin-based drugs. We propose to develop a new intervention using immunotherapy to simultaneously control HIV-TB coinfections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative As the prevalence of multidrug-resistant bacteria increases, available antibiotics are no longer effective when used alone. It is critical that we develop effective treatment strategy (combination therapy) for multidrug- resistant infections. Otherwise, we are at risk of returning to the pre-antibiotic era in the not too distant future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Our prior research and preliminary data have demonstrated that the Gram-positive anaerobic pathogen Clostridioides difficile produces membrane-bound ferrosome organelles as part of its defense strategy against host-imposed iron sequestration; however, the molecular basis of ferrosome formation remains poorly understood. The experiments outlined in this application aim to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of ferrosome biogenesis, define the function of the ferrosome iron minerals within the gut community, and determine the impact of nutrient iron on host-microbe interactions. The findings of this proposal will uncover novel factors critical for C. difficile infection and create a framework for developing effective antimicrobial therapeutics to combat this important infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. While polyketides continue to play an important clinical role in the treatment of cancer, incomplete understanding of their biosynthesis interferes with material access. This program applies a unique state-trapped approach to differentially isolated protein samples for cryo-electron microscopy that will help us understand how polyketide synthases naturally operate. Through these studies, our team seeks an ultimate goal of enabling practical access to critically needed anti-cancer polyketide therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Adaptive interventions seek to provide the right intervention to the right person, thereby maximizing benefits and minimizing waste; however, evidence is needed to inform delivery of adaptive interventions at the social context (versus individual) level. This K23 award will innovate by testing multiple social support interventions (family and peer) and establishing the feasibility and acceptability of the protocol and adaptive interventions for adults with T2D. Moveover, completion of this work will provide a mentored experience to fulfill the principal investigator’s goals to gain expertise developing and optimizing diabetes self-care interventions leveraging social support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Our objective is to integrate and harmonize 29 randomized controlled trial datasets (N=42,509) of early preventive interventions to examine whether they reduced risk for suicide, suicidal thoughts and behaviors, fatal and nonfatal substance use disorder, opioid use disorder, accidents, and all-cause mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cranial radiotherapy for individuals with brain cancer often results in deleterious effects on the sleep/wake cycle and cognitive function, particularly in the context of childhood and grade II/III brain cancer survivors. This application centers on the circadian (24-hr.) regulation of adenosine metabolism in astrocytes, which can function both as a neuroprotectant and as a key modulator of sleep homeostasis. The purpose of these studies is to understand whether clock modulation of the adenosine modulator, adenosine kinase, can be exploited to improve response to cranial radiotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Breast cancer survivors self-report many cognitive deficits, primarily in executive function (planning, problem solving, multitasking), after cancer treatment (i.e. cancer-related cognitive impairments (CRCI). Despite the substantial impact of CRCI, rehabilitation for CRCI is minimal and knowledge to support intervention is lacking. This proposal evaluates if a novel metacognitive strategy training intervention, that targets engagement in activity, is feasible and can improve daily life cognitive performance with associated improvements in activation of neural circuitry underlying executive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired communication between cellular organelles has been claimed as an important disease mechanism in many neurological disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and other. The mechanisms by which alterations at organelle membrane contacts contribute to human neurodegenerative disorders are poorly understood that is largely due to the lack of architecture of multiprotein complexes that physically tether organelle membranes and maintain proper calcium hemostasis essential for neuronal function. The proposed studies will unravel the structural basis of protein- protein interactions involved in establishing and maintaining these membrane contacts, and this knowledge is essential for developing therapeutic inventions for neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cryo-based electron microscopy techniques are well established as superior methods for preserving the biological fidelity of cellular processes as well as capturing dynamic molecular events within cells. The Leica EM ICE high-pressure freezer will rapidly vitrify cell and tissue samples for electron microscopy supporting research in the Vanderbilt Brain Institute among 7 NIMH- and NIH-funded laboratories studying the cellular and macromolecular architecture of neuronal processes and synapses. There exists a substantial and fundamental need for this state-of-the-art instrument to support the ongoing work of numerous NIMH- and NIH-sponsored investigators at Vanderbilt University and Vanderbilt University Medical Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the critical need for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer, a second leading cause of cancer-related deaths among men in the United States. The project explores the development of novel dendrimer-based targeted nanomedicines for selective and intracellular delivery of high payloads of drugs to prostate cancer cells, increasing their efficacy and reducing side effects. Therefore, this work is relevant to the mission of NIH relating to treating cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to determine the efficacy and mechanism of action of a novel combination therapy for brain metastases of HER2-enriched breast cancer and triple-negative breast cancer. This goal will be reached through using relevant models of breast cancer, including cell line-derived xenograft mouse models and experimental metastases models. If successful, our project will identify a novel therapeutic strategy for patients with breast cancer brain metastases and provide major advances in breast cancer biology and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Middle to older age Latina immigrants have a higher incidence of cervical cancer than non-Hispanic Whites. The goal of the proposed project is to partner with community research team members to develop a multi-level intervention that builds on the strengths of community health centers, where many underserved and marginalized individuals receive a wide range of preventive services. The results of this project will help community healthcare systems develop scalable interventions for marginalized patients with a particular emphasis on community-clinic partnerships to increase cervical cancer screenings, which do not involve a one-time behavior but rather require ongoing follow-up and monitoring to improve health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While much recent research has focused on identifying the antiviral systems of prokaryotes and how those are conserved in metazoans, most eukaryotes are free-living microbes whose antiviral mechanisms remain a mystery like the amoeba species that are home to the enigmatic Megavirales family. Using an approach that combines in silico prediction, discovery-based metatranscriptomic libraries, classical molecular, biochemical, and cellular techniques, and next generation sequencing, this proposal will identify the antiviral machinery of microbial eukaryotes, specifically Acanthamoeba species. This proposal will yield results that impact our understanding of eukaryotic evolution, identify new strategies of viral defense, and provide fresh tools to exploit for biotechnology and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent and young adult cancer survivors (AYACSs) encounter psychosocial challenges that are often not addressed by existing interventions, leading to disparities in their quality of life (QOL). In response, the proposed study aims to develop and evaluate a virtual, group-based expressive writing intervention that takes into account developmental stages and communication preferences of AYACSs to improve their QOL and reduce stress. If successful, this intervention will be ready for widespread expansion, including to underserved communities with limited resources and support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a difficult-to-treat cancer associated with several undesirable features, including uncontrolled nutrient consumption, high invasiveness, therapeutic resistance, dense fibroinflammatory microenvironment, and low patient survival rate. In this proposal, we will focus on glutathione (GSH), which pancreatic cancer cells use to survive. Our goal is to determine how pancreatic cancer cells acquire and use GSH, assess the role of tumor-associated macrophages as a GSH source, and determine how preventing pancreatic cancer from using GSH could help to improve therapeutic outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The vesicular monoamine transporter 2 (VMAT2) is essential for loading neurotransmitters such as dopamine, serotonin and norepinephrine into synaptic vesicles before their release into the synapse. Amphetamine has been shown to alter VMAT2 function, causing release of neurotransmitters from synaptic vesicles. In this proposal, we aim to study the structure and function of VMAT2 and the differences that occur as a result of amphetamine in order to generate new therapies to treat neuropsychiatric disorders and amphetamine abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Calcific Aortic Valve Disease (CAVD) is a significant clinical burden that can only be treated via surgical repair or replacement. Our aim for this proposal is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms behind the rapid extracellular matrix dysregulation and calcification deposition leading to valvular thickening and heart failure in human CAVD samples via multi-omic approaches with the hope of identifying pharmacotherapeutic targets. We aim to change the paradigm of treatment from “watch-and-wait” surgical replacement to biomarker identification and early intervention with antifibrotics and anticalcific treatment targeted to specific modifications of histone subtyes, to halt disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell-free DNA (cfDNA) tests can detect diseases like cancer earlier and with just a blood draw, but current tests have low sensitivity for detecting microscopic levels of disease in the body. If we can recover from cfDNA from patient samples, we could significantly boost the sensitivity of current cfDNA tests. This proposal will pursue a novel way to achieve this through engineering of novel antibodies that can protect and improve of the recovery of cfDNA in the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias are a large and growing health problem that currently affects 5.8 million Americans. Despite numerous clinical trials, there is no treatment that stops or reverses the disease progression. This work aims to develop an efficient and physiologically relevant pre-clinical drug screening model for Alzheimer’s Disease with the ultimate goal to develop effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and epilepsy have an age-related association as well as shared disease progression features, including brain inflammation and cognitive impairment. We developed a small molecule experimental therapeutic, MW189, with potential to alter disease progression. This SBIR project will facilitate progression to future first-in-patient clinical trials for MW189 which has exhibited exceptional safety in recently completed first-in-human safety trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive ability declines with age, and declines quicker when living with Alzheimer disease or related dementias (AD/ADRD), but a reference for normative cognitive decline without any neurocognitive disorder is currently unknown. This is a major gap in the literature because researchers cannot accurately judge the results of their study outcomes because there is no reference point to determine how much quicker decline is occurring in individuals living with AD/ADRD. This study proposes to fill this gap by identifying a pace of normative cognitive aging, and determining how much faster decline is in individuals living with AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This proposal, submitted in response to NIMH RFA-MH-23-265, Developing Measures to Advance Quality in Mental Health Care Services, aims to develop Person-Centered Outcome measures for assessing quality of goal-directed care for individuals with serious mental illnesses, such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, The approach is innovative in combining personalization of goals for individual service users with a method, known as goal-attainment scaling, for tracking progress on goals in a standardized quantitative way that can be used in an outcome measure, Developing these measures will provide an assessment approach, complementary to conventional symptom-based outcome measures, that assesses delivery of person-centered care in the context of long-term recovery-oriented treatment of SMI, filling a gap in behavioral health quality measurement identified in the literature, Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The complex relationship between sleep and neural plasticity remains a subject of debate. In this project I hypothesize that experience-dependent changes in neuronal circuits undermine optimal information processing, thereby increasing the need for sleep. To support this hypothesis, a machine learning algorithm will be developed to extract the dynamical rules for sleep homeostasis, experimental work will be conducted to test the plasticity thresholds in neural circuits, and a model will be developed to build predictions and test the mathematical limits of such a problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cybersecurity threats increase every day and, accordingly, cyber-attacks become more sophisticated with time. It is necessary to obtain the highest level of health information compliance. The goal is to use the additional funds to achieve SOC2 Compliance. This, in turn, will continue improve the financial well-being of older LGBTQ+ individuals with cognitive impairment through SilverBills V.3 financial and legal management tool. We will use the funds provided to hire Prescient Assurance and Perfacon to assist us in our efforts to gain the SOC2 certificate. Chris Granzier leads Prescient Assurance and Oleg Puzatkin leads Perfacon and will perform the documentation and asset classification for the certification and liaise with all internal and external stakeholders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Millions of individuals in Low-to-Middle-Income Countries are affected by birth defects, representing a major global Public Health burden. We propose innovative low-cost strategies for reducing the impact of birth defects, based on mobile, facial recognition software to screen for dysmorphic syndromes (including Down syndrome), coupled with practical genetic solutions for early diagnosis in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Our partnership between Institut National de Recherche Biomédicale, a DRC national research institute, and Children's National Hospital in Washington, DC, will create the infrastructure of a birth defect Registry, allowing for future surveillance and intervention programs in low resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Significant knowledge gaps still exist regarding a full understanding of HIV replication. Many fundamental aspects of human retrovirus replication, including virus particle assembly, remain understudied, and will be investigated in this proposal by using cutting-edge biophysical technologies. These basic science investigations of HIV assembly will help address crucial knowledge gaps as well as help inform efforts toward next-generation HIV therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While advancements have produced modest increases in the survival of pancreatic cancer patients, the demand for novel strategies persists, necessitating a focus on combination therapies directed at emerging targets. Hence, our proposal centers on the investigation of a validated therapeutic target, Redox factor-1 (Ref- 1), both as a standalone intervention and within strategic combinations. Having progressed the initial Ref-1 inhibitor (APX3330) to a phase I clinical trial in adults, we've also identified subsequent Ref-1 inhibitors, devised a patient sensitivity screening strategy, and pinpointed molecular partners for potential synergy with Ref-1 inhibition.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-engineered T cell therapy is a breakthrough immunotherapy for lymphoma, but poor persistence of CAR-T cells contributes to relapse. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Mast cells (MC) are potent inflammatory cells that arise from circulating MC progenitors (MCp) recruited to airway mucosal tissues during type 2 inflammatory diseases, including asthma and nasal polyposis, where they take on discrete intraepithelial and subepithelial phenotypes based on their tissue microenvironment. While intraepithelial MCs prominently expand within the bronchial airway epithelium in both human and mouse during allergic lung inflammation, no tools currently exist to selectively target this population for functional analysis of its contribution to disease progression. This proposal describes the creation of a pre-clinical mouse strain allowing selective targeting of intraepithelial mast cells. The proposed studies will use our novel mouse strain to test roles for intraepithelial mast cells at several discrete points in airway inflammation, setting the stage for future mechanistic studies testing the influence of specific pathways and their contribution to inflammation in other tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Our ongoing study explores the use of Glutamate 1-Semialdehyde (GSA) in inducing porphyrin accumulation in bacteria, facilitating their visual identification and elimination via fluorescence imaging and light-based killing, notably without affecting mammalian cells. While preliminary data showcase the in vitro efficacy of GSA- phototherapy on common wound-infecting bacteria, the proposed research will delve into its detection thresholds, biosafety, and killing efficacy utilizing diabetic mice and mini-pigs. This approach proposes a multifaceted solution for the timely diagnosis, real-time monitoring, and non-antibiotic treatment of bacterial infections in diabetic wounds, potentially preventing severe outcomes like amputation and sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Maternal prenatal vaccination is a promising strategy to improve pathogen-specific antibody transfer to the fetus to provide early-life immunity to immunologically vulnerable infants. However, an incomplete mechanistic understanding of how the placenta transfers antibodies from mothers to babies impedes current immunization approaches from providing adequate protection to all newborns. This project will define the underlying rules and the complex kinetics of antibody transfer and will build mathematical models to inform new prenatal vaccination strategies that better protect newborns from infections, thus saving tremendous resources by narrowing down to top strategies for clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM; isocitrate dehydrogenase [IDH]-wild-type) is a lethal tumor with poor treatment options due to a high rate of resistance to both chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Perturbing mitosis, the process of one cell dividing into two, is a vulnerability in solid tumors, including GBM. Successful completion of this project will identify a means of blocking mitosis in GBM that will not only function to limit tumor growth but will also enhance the efficacy of current GBM therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative I will adapt my parental psychological control questionnaire to Mexican immigrant families via mixed methods (K99) and test cultural mechanisms of parental psychological control longitudinally (R00). This project will provide a reproducible methodology to create culturally sensitive measures of parental psychological control based on what people in a specific culture believe to be intrusive and also provide me with the training in family observations and interviews and in Latinx parenting. This training will equip me to become an independent researcher who studies parenting in diverse cultures via multiple methods and implements culturally sensitive preventive interventions for ethnically diverse families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will utilize three levels of data (population-level student data, institutional-level policy data, institutional leader in-depth interview data) to construct the most comprehensive evidence to date of opioid overdose prevention in higher education. The long-term goal of this research is to inform the design and implementation of opioid overdose and harm reduction programs and policies for the more than 16 million college students in the U.S. The proposed research focuses on novel prevention, treatment and harm reduction approaches, while studying the implementation of evidence-based strategies for college student populations, addressing two priority scientific areas outlined in NIDA’s 2022-2026 Strategic Plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Zika virus (ZIKV) is the causative agent of smaller head (microcephaly) and other severe brain and eye defects in newborn. However, it is not known how ZIKV enters the eye or brain to cause the Congenital Zika Syndrome (CZS). In this study, we plan to delineate the molecular mechanisms of ZIKV induced breach of blood-retinal barrier using retina organoids and animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While PSMA-targeting has been a successful imaging and drug-delivery strategy for various payloads to prostate tumor cells, there is a need to overcome the challenges of tumor heterogeneity and drug resistance in order to provide treatment options for metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) patients, especially those that relapse or fail to meet the requirements for radiotherapy. A PSMA-targeted, pH- responsive small molecule dual drug conjugate that bears two different chemotherapeutic drugs with different mechanisms of action and simultaneously releases both drugs upon internalization in tumor cells is anticipated overcome these challenges. This project aims to develop a new class of PSMA-targeting agents to meet the need for efficiently and selectively treating mCRPC patients and other PSMA(+) neovasculature cancers, as well as set the foundation for a general, dual-drug strategy for targeted chemotherapy for other biomarker- characterized diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recognized intertumoral diversity, current treatment strategies for triple negative breast cancer remain generalized due to lack of reliable biomarkers. This proposal seeks to quantitatively characterize TNBC heterogeneity using novel habitat signatures and elucidate interpatient differences to aid in stratifying patients with increased probability of response to neoadjuvant therapy. Successful whole-tumor habitat characterizations will yield greater understanding of an individual’s tumor physiology and provide an avenue to further personalize breast cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive and often fatal disease with significant variations in individual clinical courses and poorly understood underlying mechanisms. Accumulating evidence shows that abnormalities in the pulmonary endothelium precede tissue fibrosis, therefore accurate assessment of the physiological and microvascular changes in IPF s crucial for gaining a deeper understanding of the disease's pathophysiology, which is valuable for improving patient care and facilitating drug development for this deadly disease. This project aims to establish a pharmacokinetic model for absolute quantification of pulmonary perfusion and microvascular parameters and validate this model in large animal models with independent tissue analyses of perfusion and vascular permeability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb)- the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB)- establishes infection in the lungs by surviving in macrophages, even in the face of a robust adaptive immune response. CD4 T cells enhance the ability of macrophages to clear Mtb, although exactly how they contribute to host control of Mtb, and why they often fail to generate sterilizing immunity, is not well understood. We will investigate mechanisms of protection conferred by macrophage-T cell interactions, elucidate the dynamics of macrophage-T cell interactions in vivo, and study how these can be enhanced. These findings could lead to novel therapies and vaccines for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Artificial light at night (ALAN) is an emerging environmental hazard with important public health implications, however, there is a contentious debate about how well satellite data commonly used in epidemiological studies can serve as a measure of ALAN exposure at the individual level. Our study will be the first large-scale validation effort of satellite-based ALAN measures in a nationally representative and diverse dataset with relevant health outcomes. We expect our study to provide crucial information for better interpreting existing epidemiological evidence, guiding the design of future studies, and enhancing the translational value of ALAN research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This research addresses a critical barrier to immune thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (iTTP) clinical trial readiness – the absence of validity evidence for clinical outcome assessments (COAs) measuring cognitive function. Without validity evidence for COAs, iTTP clinical trials cannot follow FDA patient-focused drug development guidance to evaluate the effect of candidate therapies on cognitive function – the health-related quality of life outcome most important to patients. By developing a measurement strategy for cognitive function in patients with iTTP, this research will facilitate the design and conduct of future studies using COAs as clinical trial endpoints.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A detailed understanding of B cell and antibody responses to placental versus foreign antigen will illuminate how dysregulated responses contribute to pregnancy complications and inform the design of vaccine programs which best protect mothers and children from infection. We propose to study B cell and antibody responses to placental versus foreign antigen. Results will identify molecular mechanisms suppressing B cell activation; map tolerance pathways that protect the conceptus from antibody-mediated damage; and identify a pregnancy factor capable of boosting humoral immunity, which will be clinically useful to boost responses to vaccines and fight infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Over one million people each year lose the ability to breathe on their own and are treated by placing a breathing tube in their throat. After regaining their ability to breathe, as many as 44% of patients may have trouble swallowing their food and liquids, and these swallowing problems are especially common in the elderly. For those patients with documented airway swelling after the breathing tube is removed, we propose to conduct a clinical trial to determine whether corticosteroids improve their ability to swallow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying effective strategies to control myopia (nearsightedness) is a global priority to prevent the growing global public health burden of visual impairment and blindness due to myopia and myopia-related complications. Exposure to different wavelengths of light produces powerful effects on the refractive state of the eyes in animals, suggesting a critical role of wavelength cues in guiding eye growth and refractive development. This pilot, “proof of concept” project aims to determine if brief daily periods of amber light exposure can be translated from animal studies as a potential anti-myopia strategy leading to an entirely new avenue for controlling childhood myopia, in addition to providing a strong foundation for designing future, more effective myopia control technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is a genetic, neuromuscular disease that causes early onset, severe muscle weakness. While SMA patient outcomes have significantly improved since the development of SMN- increasing therapeutics, neuromuscular deficits are still present in most patients. The objective of this project is to identify mechanisms of SMA motor neuron maldevelopment and degeneration in mouse models with differing disease severity to guide future therapeutic development and improve patient quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) are highly stable and toxic chemicals that can cause adverse human health effects (e.g. increased risk of Type 2 diabetes and liver cancer). The goal of this proposal is to develop a treatment system that combines nanotechnology with microbial degradation to achieve complete destruction of PFASs without the production of toxic byproducts. The fundamental knowledge obtained from this study will provide critical information needed in developing efficient strategies to eliminate deleterious effects of PFAS in the environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Marginal zone lymphomas are the second most common subtype of indolent non-hodgkin’s lymphomas, that are strongly dependent on the tumor microenvironment in order to grow, and lack adequate preclinical models. Recently, the impressive clinical activity of inhibitors of the phosphoinositide-3-kinase (PI3K), protein kinase B (Akt), mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway have brought to the spotlight the role of this pathway in the pathogenesis of this disease. We propose to characterize novel mouse models, and study the effect of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR alone and in combination with the anti-apoptotic protein B-cell lymphoma 2 (Bcl-2) in the pathogenesis of this incurable lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory infections are a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children <5 years of age, but there is a gap in understanding of the biological determinants of inter-individual variability in infection risk. This proposal applies an innovative approach to derive proteomic-driven subtypes (i.e., “inflamma-types) correlated to respiratory infection risk, then biochemically characterize these inflamma-types to identify key ‘omic features contributing to risk variability and the development of subsequent diseases in high risk individuals. These findings will pave the way towards targeted therapeutics and personalized medicine approaches, ultimately to improve quality of life for children suffering from recurrent respiratory infections in early life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthcare-associated infections in neonatal intensive care units lead to significant morbidity and mortality, and are often caused by antimicrobial resistant pathogens. This proposal will use metagenomic next-generation sequencing in novel ways to track pathogen transmission, identify environmental reservoirs of infection, and understand acquisition of antimicrobial resistant microbes in hospitalized neonates. Together this work leverages innovative metagenomic sequencing tools and analyses to advance infection control approaches and curb the spread of drug-resistant infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Without addressing problems in outcome-focused quality measures, policymakers, researchers, and clinicians are limited in their ability to detect the impact of mental health on society and the efficacy of interventions intended to ameliorate this impact. To address these problems, we propose a creative new approach to measuring quality of life that can serve as a more accurate and generalizable outcome-focused quality measure. As a result, the proposed research is relevant to public health because it eliminates a critical bottleneck to efforts by policy makers, researchers, and clinicians who are looking to improve mental health outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of the 106th Annual CASA Educational and Training Seminar is to provide a venue where field inspectors, food program managers, industry leaders and academia from across the region can personally interact and share ideas while receiving information on current and emerging food topics impacting health and safety. The conference will contribute to a more educated, informed, and integrated food regulatory community and this in turn will contribute to a safer food supply.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We are requesting funds to purchase the TissueVision TissueCyte 1600FC serial two-photon tomography microscope to enable high-throughput, high resolution automated imaging of whole rodent brains or spinal cord segments by NIMH/NIH supported investigators at UT Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, TX. The instrument will be housed in and maintained by the Whole Brain Microscopy Facility, and will be accessible to all investigators on campus as well as external users. Health related research that will benefit from the requested instrument includes: characterization of neocortical development and cerebellar circuitry and their relationships to autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders, creation of a detailed multimodal developmental reference atlas of mouse spinal cord, evaluation of mouse models of metabolic epilepsies, mapping oligodendrocyte subpopulations during development, determination of how hippocampal hyperactivity drives circuit changes in schizophrenia, and supporting basic and disease focused characterization of the hippocampal-entorhinal memory system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The highly elaborate morphology of astrocytes is evolutionarily conserved and tied to their many functions in the CNS, though our understanding of how this morphology is regulated is incomplete. Here, we propose to investigate how astrocyte morphology is regulated by the Sarm1-WNK-NAD+-Axed signaling axis, a canonical molecular pathway most known for its involvement in axon degeneration. By using pharmacology, genetics, and in vivo imaging in the larval zebrafish, our work will uncover new molecules crucial for astrocyte morphogenesis and provide new insights into the Sarm1 signaling pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will examine five existing human subjects’ datasets for a focused secondary analysis of breathing asynchrony in persons with Parkinson’s disease. Examining thoraco-abdominal asynchrony and paradoxical motion is a novel scientific approach for better elucidating the underlying respiratory changes associated with Parkinson’s disease. The study results will identify potential therapeutic targets leading to improved communication and quality of life for persons with Parkinson’s disease.
