IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) is a neurologic catastrophe resulting in varying degrees of motor, sensory, and sympathetic impairment, and a robust inflammatory response is a hallmark of this disease process. CSF is able to communicate with the CNS-adjacent bone marrow to stimulate hematopoiesis and myeloid cell egress back to the CNS border meninges and perivascular spaces, but the exact mechanism underlying this signaling remains unknown. In this proposal, we will determine if CSF flow rate is able to regulate myeloid egress, whether SCI disrupts this CSF flow leading to increased myeloid cells in the CNS after injury, and if manipulation of CSF flow to the bone marrow can ultimately improve recovery after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible vision loss and blindness, and current glaucoma treatments do not always work, leading many glaucoma patients to continue losing their vision. We will target a new molecular pathway that we have recently discovered that damages the eye in glaucoma. If successful, our discovery will provide a novel approach for treating glaucoma to prevent the progressive damage to the eye that leads to vision loss and blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Craniofacial abnormalities are among the most common birth defects, and these conditions often hinder the physical and mental development of affected children. My project investigates the dynamic cell behaviors required for normal lip upper morphogenesis. These findings will better reveal the cellular and molecular bases of non-syndromic cleft lip and cleft lip seen in Blepharocheilodontic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research proposal addresses patient-, provider, and system- level barriers in accruing adolescent and young adult (AYA) patients (ages 15-39y) to cancer clinical trials (CCTs).The major goals of this project are to further develop and implement an AYA (Alert, Young Adult Navigation, Alliance) toolkit to streamline operations, bridge the gap between pediatric and adult consortium clinical trials, and improve AYA enrollment and retention. Protected effort for the duration of the award will provide Dr. Symons with the necessary time to develop and implement the metrics and meet regularly with all of the stakeholders involved in these endeavors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy behavior requires the integration of many signals, such as body signals that report to the brain our current needs (e.g., hunger, thirst) as well as Circadian Cycles that help us meet needs on a longer time scale (e.g., sleep) and the activity of pathways such as the Ventral Tegmental Area (VTA) so current choices and longer-term learning reflect what brain systems view as important or rewarding. A new discovery described in my Preliminary Data shows a new connection between these signals. VTA activity can open the blood-brain barrier, allowing greater access of body molecules to the brain, but only at times when high-quality body-state information is most important. I will systematically test the closely-related hypotheses that VTA dynamics (Aim I) and their impact on both the BBB (Aim II) and behavior output (Aim III) peak early in the active (dark) phase and then diminish, fitting their putative behavioral role.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on generating novel patient-derived models of primary and metastatic hormone receptor positive (HR+) breast cancer. HR+ breast cancer is the most common subtype of breast cancer (~70%), and despite available treatments, 30% of patients’ tumors recur, at which point the tumors are often metastatic and treatment resistant. Our proposal focuses on generating more ethnically diverse models of HR+ disease, and will use these models to target drivers of treatment resistance in metastatic and relapsed HR+ tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scientific basis underlying yoga’s therapeutic benefits for chronic pain is not well understood. Persistent post-surgical pain (PPSP) is a widespread chronic pain condition with few effective treatments. This study will begin to evaluate the potential for yoga to manage the constellation of symptoms associated with PPSP and explore the role of inflammation and other processes in PPSP’s resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Alcohol abusers are susceptible to infectious diseases, particularly septicemia, which causes enormous health and economic burdens in the United States. Many alcoholic patients with severe bacterial infection are present with leukopenia, which is frequently fatal. This project investigates the mechanisms underlying alcohol-induced impairment of immune defense function, which will help identify therapeutic targets for effective treatment of alcoholic patients with severe bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to their tremendous human and financial burden, Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) have risen to the forefront of the United States public health agenda. Diversification of ADRD researchers can lead to an increase in the participation of racially and ethnically diverse and other underrepresented populations in aging and ADRD research and improve the efficacy of programs and services. This award will provide necessary support and time to deepen understanding for how to meaningfully integrate community engagement, health communication, and dissemination and implementation science into a holistic, equity- driven, and interdisciplinary training for underrepresented researchers advancing the science of ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health as it will lead to better understanding of the etiology and drug resistance of Ras-driven cancers (a third of all cancers). By developing tools to profile, track, and perturb specific Ras isoforms in physiologically relevant cancer models, I propose to use these tools to understand how cancer cells re-organize Ras signaling during Ras inhibitor treatment to reactive oncogenic cellular programs. This work will provide critically needed tools and address how compartmentalized oncogenic signaling can dynamically adapt during drug treatment, thus is well-suited to meet the priorities outlined by NCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: This is a multi-level mixed methods study to analyze the implications for racial health equity of policies that perpetuate structural racism in the domains of mass incarceration and housing and the potential for policy reforms in these domains to reduce race inequities in health. It will develop quantitative indices of structural racism in state policies in these domains, and measures of individuals’ exposures to these domains in the state of Connecticut (CT), and analyze their impacts on population and individual health outcomes, respectively. Through an in-depth qualitative analysis of the rollout of Clean Slate and Right to Council policies in CT, it will explore how policy reforms in these domains may represent interventions to promote racial health equity.

PHR: The VHL tumor suppressor protein (pVHL) is often inactivated in clear cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC), leading to continuous activation of the hypoxia-inducible-factor (HIF) pathway. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure affects about 5.7 million adults in the United States and continues to be the leading cause of death globally, partly due to the limited therapeutic options. Direct cardiac reprogramming, which converts non- myocytes in the heart to induced cardiomyocytes, offers a promising alternative strategy for repairing the heart. This proposal will use state-of-art approaches to delineate the post-transcriptional mechanisms of this process for its future clinical implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses a critical gap in survivor-centered approaches aimed at promoting GBV healing engagement while also exposing providers visually to many of the social determinants that influence the health and wellbeing of survivors' daily lives. This study's significance lies in its capacity to transform the landscape of GBV support services by shifting the focus from a deficit- oriented model to one centered on healing and active survivor participation in their recovery journey, particularly among sexual and gender minority (SGM) populations. Relevant to NINR's mission, this project aligns by targeting the prevention of disease and the promotion of wellbeing through its holistic approach, addressing health inequities among GBV survivors, and emphasizing health promotion within women and SGM communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative This project aims to study the interaction between NaVs and ankyrin proteins. These proteins are critical neuronal proteins, dysfunction of which have been implicated in several neurodevelopmental and mental health disorders. Further understanding the interactions between these proteins on a molecular level is essential in the elucidation of the molecular and cellular mechanistic underpinnings of neurodevelopmental and mental health disorders and the future development of therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The placental vasculature is essential for the blood-placenta barrier, but the molecular mechanisms that regulate placental vascular growth and function remain poorly understood. The proposed research investigates how placental endothelial cells grow and function. The findings from this work will contribute to our understanding of the vascular component at the blood- placental barrier and offer new knowledge can be used to develop new treatment strategies for conditions associated with pregnancy-related cardiovascular complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hazardous alcohol use is highly prevalent among the millions of older adults who have chronic pain and contributes to greater pain severity, physical impairments, and the exacerbation of chronic pain over time. Although alcohol reduction/cessation can reduce pain and improve health, no interventions have been developed to identify and intervene upon hazardous drinking in older adults with chronic pain. The goal of this study is to develop, refine, and pilot test an alcohol screening, brief intervention, and referral to treatment protocol that meets the unique needs of older adults with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have generated a novel immunocytokine - anti-CD70-IL-21 fusion antibody for tumor-specific targeting of human IL-21, anti-CD70 mediated ADCC specifically within the RCC tumor microenvironment, and limiting side-effects arising from off-target effects of IL-21 seen with systemic administration. Our anti-CD70-IL-21 fusion antibody significantly enhances NK cells cytotoxicity against ccRCC. We expect that use of anti-CD70- IL-21 fusion antibodies will represent a novel treatment strategy and provide multiple benefits for patients with RCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The emergence of immunotherapy has been practice-changing, however patients with EGFR-mutant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) derive little benefit, as their tumors are typically resistant to checkpoint inhibitor drugs. Preliminary data from our group indicate for the first time that using an aromatase inhibitor (AI) to block the production of estrogen and its metabolites in mice with EGFR-mutant NSCLC can significantly increase immune cell infiltration into lung tumors and promote other anti-tumor effects. Suppressing estrogen species with an AI may be an effective strategy to enhance the efficacy of checkpoint inhibitors and improve long-term survival in patients with EGFR-mutant NSCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a benign breast disease reported by 25% of all breast screens in the US and has the potential to become invasive breast cancer. There are currently no tools that can predict which DCIS lesions will become invasive breast cancer, leading to significant overtreatment. This proposal investigates how changes in protein expression around DCIS lesion can be used to predict which lesions will become invasive breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women have a 20% higher risk experiencing heart failure or mortality within five years following their first acute myocardial infarction compared to men. This proposal aims to address this disparity by determining the role of thyroid hormones, an underexplored sexually dimorphic risk factor for heart failure development in females. Specifically, we will focus on the tissue-level regulatory mechanisms of thyroid hormones that may contribute to sex differences in the development of heart failure, potentially paving the way for the development of new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Cytolethal distending toxin (CDT), which is produced by several pathogens, has three subunits: two cell- binding proteins and a third catalytic protein. In order to function, the catalytic subunit must dissociate from the cell-binding subunits. Understanding the molecular details of this process could assist the design of therapeutic strategies that prevent the disassembly and activity of CDT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to study dietary saturated fats' effects on platelet reactivity in obesity, focusing on their incorporation into platelet membranes, associated changes in platelet reactivity, and effects on platelet lipid rafts and subsequent signaling. These results may inform interventions for obesity-related cardiovascular issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative:  High-resolution structural information is essential for understanding the molecular basis of a number of diseases. Among the important requirements for obtaining such information are (1) the routinely available capability to study the conformation and oligomeric states of biomedically relevant proteins and protein complexes both in crystals and in solution, including methods for handling the poorly-diffracting crystals often generated by membrane-receptors, ion channels, and signaling proteins, and (2) the means to continue to improve on the available techniques, extending our knowledge of complex systems which are currently poorly understood. MacCHESS will provide the necessary facilities and access to technology to help to generate structure- function information of great interest to the biological and biomedical communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The parabrachial nucleus serves as a crucial sensory hub, relaying data from internal and external senses to shape motivated behaviors; in this intricate network, the activation of melanocortin 3 and 4 receptors (MC3R and MC4R) expressing neurons can either stimulate or suppress ingestive behaviors. Of particular importance, the PBN MC3R neurons represent a novel population in the PBN as they contradict the overall role of the PBN in inhibiting feeding. Understanding how these two neuronal populations in the PBN integrate opposing ingestive behaviors is the major goal of this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Zika virus is a mosquito-borne RNA virus that has become a serious global concern due to its ability to cause neurological birth defects. This proposal is an integrated effort that combines identifying natural human genetic differences regulating Zika virus cellular entry, replication, and host gene expression with rigorous experimental validation studies. Successfully carrying out this work will identify specific genetic differences that regulate Zika virus infection and may also reveal new targets for host-directed therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The airway mucosa is the initial site of interaction with Mycobacterium tuberculosis. While the mucosa itself forms a critical barrier to infection, it is also the anatomic location where cells of the mucosal, innate and adaptive immune systems converge to orchestrate protective immediate and long-term responses. We have demonstrated that M. tuberculosis can migrate and enter the mucosa associated lymphoid tissue via a rare, specialized cell type called a microfold cell. Here we propose to better characterize features of the airway M cell, establish how it communicates with other epithelial and immune cells, determine the mechanism by which the bacteria traverse the cell and the immunologic consequences of early microfold cell contact with M. tuberculosis. This approach is novel because it represents the first broad characterization of the role of airway microfold cells to host defense against M. tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D), which is characterized by the loss of insulin-producing beta cells, is a chronic condition that carries significant global morbidity and mortality. While multiple genetic risk factors have been implicated in T1D pathophysiology, T1D genetic risk among non-European populations is less well understood. In this proposal, we will assemble genomic data from diverse ancestral populations to improve prediction of T1D risk, to identify genetic subtypes of T1D, and to refine classification of atypical immune-mediated forms of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal is focused on translational and clinical research in gene therapy to safely address an ultra-rare subset of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients excluded from ongoing dystrophin-based gene therapy trials. The rationale is the avoidance of destructive T cell responses to dystrophin epitopes by substituting the non-immunogenic dystrophin-related protein utrophin, composed entirely of “self” peptide epitopes to take advantage of central immunological tolerance. The project makes appropriate use of preclinical models to address major limitations identified in ongoing clinical studies, focusing on IND-enabling experiments that pertain to both FDA regulations and to the anticipated risks and potential benefits to DMD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intimate partner violence (IPV) is widespread in Alaska, and public health nurses play an important role in prevention, particularly in rural and underserved communities. The proposed study will leverage a practice- based research partnership with Alaska’s statewide Section of Public Health Nursing to advance the use of evidence-informed IPV prevention practices throughout the state by describing IPV practices delivered by public health nurses, identifying barriers to and facilitators of implementing IPV practices by public health nurses, and developing strategies for public health nurses to implement evidence-informed IPV practices. Findings will provide actionable information for local and state public health staff and leaders in Alaska, as well as other state and national organizations engaged in IPV prevention with rural and underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Early events following inhalation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M.tb) in the lung play a critical role in determining whether an individual stays healthy, develops latent infection or goes on to develop active tuberculosis (TB), and HIV co-infection greatly alters these processes. Capitalizing on our discovery that M.tb exposure to lung fluids from people living with HIV greatly impacts bacterial interactions with the host, we propose to systematically evaluate early pathogenic events in the lung by combining use of several innovative models ranging from individual host cell evaluations, to multi-cellular in vitro models, a Lung on Chip model and an in vivo NHP model to dissect the microbial and host immune responses during the earliest steps of M.tb infection. We expect to identify the critical metabolic changes and cellular pathways in airway-mediated M.tb pathogenesis to advance novel approaches for the development of therapies and vaccines active in the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  It would be very helpful to have measures of the quality of mental health services to inform patients’ choice of clinicians and organizations, the training and supervision of clinicians, value-based purchasing and quality improvement efforts. Patient-reported symptoms can be electronically collected and used to study the quality of care for common depressive and anxiety disorders. This project develops and tests a new outcome- focused measure of mental health care quality that can be implemented nationally to improve services and outcomes in the community.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project presents the first opportunity to evaluate the impact of unconditional income supplementation on pregnancy outcomes and infant development among Black birthing people in the United States, a population that experiences stark disparities and that has not seen improvements in perinatal health, despite a host of clinical intervention approaches. Evidence from non-U.S. settings suggests the potential for improvements in birth outcomes and perinatal mental health because of unconditional income supplementation, yet these settings have implemented smaller income supplements in the face of different economic contexts, approaches to health insurance, and legacies of colonialization and ongoing structural racism. The results of this study can support the advancement of income supplementation as health equity strategy to improve pregnancy outcomes and infant development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advancements in studying transcriptional control have shed light on the roles of specific transcription factors (TFs) such as ATOH1, POU4F3, GFI1, INSM1, TBX2, and IKZF2 in inner ear hair cell (HC) development. To further this research, I propose using the newly developed inner ear organoid model to study and manipulate HC development in vitro. This project aims to identify key TFs involved in organoid HC development, create a versatile CRISPR-based toolkit for gene manipulation, and systematically investigate TF roles through CRISPR- mediated techniques and multi-omic analyses, offering key insights into HC development and aiding future regenerative research in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Obstructive sleep apnea is a highly common sleep disorder in type 1 diabetes. Adults with type 1 diabetes and sleep apnea have poorer glycemic control, but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. This research will elucidate biological and behavioral factors that may contribute to suboptimal glycemic control in adults with type 1 diabetes and sleep apnea. The results from this study may lead to novel sleep interventions and improve diabetes management in people with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Transgender men (TGM) taking testosterone as gender-affirming hormone therapy often experience changes affecting their vaginal health such as thinning of the vaginal epithelium, inflammation, and unfavorable shifts in the vaginal microbiota which can lead to bacterial vaginosis. Such changes, in conjunction with sexual behaviors of TGM, are associated with negative sexual health outcomes such as increased risk of HIV and sexually transmitted infection (STI) acquisition and symptoms such as irritation, discharge, and dyspareunia. The proposed research in this K23 proposal aims to utilize community-engaged mixed methods research to develop culturally relevant clinical tools that can be used by healthcare providers to collect both vaginal history data (via a vaginal health survey instrument) and clinical specimen data (via self-collected vaginal swabs) to better assess and manage vaginal symptoms that TGM experience and, ultimately, improve their sexual health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Failure of pancreatic β-cells to secrete sufficient insulin hormone to regulate blood glucose is a hallmark of diabetes. Early during the development of diabetes, prolonged high glucose levels reduce insulin protein synthesis and may also adversely impact the quality of protein produced. By revealing novel mechanisms through which high glucose regulates insulin protein production and affects quality control during protein synthesis, this study has the potential to identify new targets for treating or slowing down the progression of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Problematic alcohol use unfolds dynamically across development with important contributions from impulsive personality traits. This proposal will characterize the longitudinal interplay between impulsive personality traits and alcohol involvement from childhood to middle adulthood and their relation to genetic and neurobiological sources of vulnerability. By informing how genetic and neurobiological influences are associated with distinct impulsive personality trait and alcohol involvement pathways across development, this proposal may provide critical etiological insights that could ultimately improve the prevention and treatment of alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many complex diseases are thought to be related with mutations in the DNA that alter the state of nearby genes. This project will develop a new strategy based on the cutting-edge AI technology to determine the functional impact of the mutations and help us to understand how DNA sequence regulates the expression of genes, and aims to apply this knowledge to investigate how mutations change gene state and contribute to disease. This project will help discover the gene regulation mechanism for complex disease and may eventually lead to the development of precise medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fear of cancer progression (FOP) is the most common concern and unmet need in patients with advanced cancer. The “Day by Day” is a blended e-Health intervention for managing FOP, consisting of group and on-line self-study sessions. The intervention is tailored to patients with advanced cancer. Use of a videoconferencing approach is scalable and can increase access to psychosocial support services, especially in community and underserved settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is present in over 10% of all patients admitted to intensive care units worldwide and is associated with high mortality (30-40%). Despite the absence of effective pharmacotherapies addressing underlying mechanisms of ARDS, findings from the COVID-19 research landscape suggest treatment strategies that merit deeper exploration. CD14-blockade with the monoclonal antibody IC14 demonstrated on target bio-efficacy signals in severe COVID-19, and further study of CD14 blockade in ARDS is warranted to understand the potential of this treatment strategy for mitigating lung and systemic immunopathology and improving patient outcomes in ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is the major clinical problem in the US and worldwide with kidneys playing a central role in regulation of systemic sodium balance and blood pressure control. In this proposal, we identified a novel signaling factors, specifically Epac1 and Epac2, determining how kidneys regulate sodium balance. We further provided initial experimental support that our recently developed blockers of Epacs could be beneficial in reducing blood pressure and promoting sodium excretion in animal models of hypertension.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Patients with respiratory disease are frequently referred for pulmonary consultation, but access to pulmonologists is often insufficient to meet demand. To address this challenge, the VA uses “e-consults” which allow primary care providers to get rapid advice from pulmonologists through the electronic health record. This approach to coordinating patient care can improve timeliness and efficiency, though there are also concerns that it could adversely affect patient and provider relationships and the quality of communication. In the proposed research, I will explore these potential unintended consequences and identify best practices to support high quality e-consult coordination. I will use this information to design, implement, and test an E- consult First intervention, in which all pulmonary consult requests are first entered as e-consults. I will assess the impact of the intervention on diverse outcome measures. This research has the potential to improve the quality of e-consult coordination, which could lead to systems that offer more timely specialty care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Breast cancer is the most diagnosed cancer in the world and imposes a large public health burden, where much of this burden can be attributed to metastasis. The experiments described herein will elucidate the roles of coamplified genes in HER2+ breast cancer metastasis. Results from this proposal will provide a greater mechanistic understanding of the metastatic cascade, prognostic indicators of metastasis, and determination of genes that are necessary or sufficient to increase metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Over 40% of adults in the USA are classified as overweight or obese and there is currently a shortage of effective treatments to reduce the excessive food intake that can lead to obesity. Novel and effective obesity prevention and treatment strategies are aided by basic science research identifying specific brain chemical systems that reduce food intake. A novel approach is taken here; we are investigating the extent to which factors including sex and social context modulate the effects of oxytocin, a neuropeptide with clinical relevance to human obesity treatment, on food intake regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Altered hematopoiesis and myeloid biased skewing promotes the expansion of immune suppressive myeloid populations, a phenomenon that is observed in cancer patients regardless of the tumor type and/or dissemination to bone. Currently, the impact of a primary tumor on bone marrow hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs), as well as the factors involved in changing their frequency and/or functionality, remain unclear. The aims proposed here will broaden our understanding of the effects of tumor progression on hematopoiesis and, importantly, the role of the bone in generating the immune suppressive environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The oral cavity is a complex environment where a diverse array of organisms coexists in dynamic interplay with the human immune system. While bacteria and fungi have traditionally been the focus of research on the human microbiome, recent studies have highlighted the significant role of phages (viruses infecting bacteria) in shaping the oral microenvironment. Our proposal aims to re-examine the large set of existing metagenomic data to comprehensively investigate the role of the oral virome and its interactions with the microbiome which will help us to understand the intricate dynamics of the oral microenvironment; ultimately inspiring new approaches to promote oral health and prevent/manage oral diseases more effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This research will focus on studying the dynamic behavior of the alkyl radical generated via CN bond breaking of a pyridinium salt and using this information to develop new nickel-catalyzed transformations utilizing alkyl radicals in three-component reactions. Multicomponent reactions can rapidly build a complex molecular scaffold with applications in optimizing organic syntheses for drug discovery. The streamlining of organic syntheses from multistep processes to shorter, nickel-catalyzed reactions will lead to lower drug cost and an increase in the accessibility of these compounds for the public.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  It is known that blood-brain barrier function declines with aging, but the effects of aging on the choroid plexus, a key component of the blood-brain barrier that transports molecules between the blood and cerebrospinal fluid, are largely unknown. Measuring the extent to which blood-to-brain protein transport in the choroid plexus is altered in aging would reveal which transporters are best targeted as drivers of brain aging or as drug delivery vehicles. This proposal describes using novel mass spectrometry-based proteomic technologies to measure how the kinetics of translocation of transporters and cargo in the choroid plexus change with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although medications such as buprenorphine and methadone are known to be effective at treating opioid use disorder (OUD), segregation and structural racism are likely to influence treatment outcomes among pregnant people with OUD in the United States. In the proposed study, I will link administrative claims data from pregnant patients prescribed these drugs to individual area-based data and investigate how social structures affect OUD treatment outcomes. Consistent with the NIDA Racial Equity Initiative Action Plan’s goals of advancing understanding of social determinants of health to guide future intervention development, this work has high potential for impact by generating novel data on the influence of structural racism on treatment outcomes and informing policymakers aiming to develop data-driven interventions to reduce overdose in locations of greatest risk.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anthropogenic climate change is expected to have significant consequences for the health and wellbeing of affected populations, especially in lower- and middle-income settings. We use demographic and health surveys from Indonesia and Mexico, combined with high-resolution climate records, to measure the effects of climate exposures during early childhood and adolescence on the fertility, health, migration, and socioeconomic statuses of working-age adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections following the implantation of cardiac implantable electronic devices (CIEDs) are major complications associated with significant morbidity, mortality, rehospitalizations, and increased medical costs. These infections persist despite current antibiotic treatments and preventive measures, primarily due to biofilm formation on CIEDs and the increasing prevalence of multidrug-resistant bacteria. In this application, we aim to investigate the potential of a cutting-edge antimicrobial blue light (aBL) emitting envelope (aBL-ENV) to reduce the risk of CIED infections. aBL-ENV emits aBL uniformly across its entire surface to prevent biofilm formation and eradicate existing biofilm on aBL-ENV/CIED. Successful execution of the studies detailed in this application will provide the preclinical evidence required to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of aBL-ENV, and will showcase the functionality of a prototype system of aBL-ENV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of strong writing skills is critical for early-stage investigators is vital for successful careers in biomedical science, however, evidence-based training and mentoring models to develop these skills are absent in the scientific literature. We propose to conduct randomized controlled trial with120 early-stage investigators from backgrounds underrepresented in biomedical science to test the efficacy of refined, mentored scientific manuscript writing interventions on manuscript submission, publications, and persistence.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Injury to the kidneys due to a short-term loss of blood supply is a common problem affecting hospitalized patients, but it lacks any specific treatment. The goal of this project is to better understand how the genes that determine the ways kidney cells use energy are controlled because these processes make the kidney vulnerable to injury. This understanding may lead to ways to prevent and treat kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Erythritol, an artificial sweetener that is also endogenously produced, has been linked to heart disease. This proposal seeks to determine the association of erythritol and its metabolites to vascular disease and heart failure risk in a multi-ethnic population and assess erythritol and erythronate production in people with and without type 2 diabetes and/or obesity when fasting and in response to oral glucose and erythritol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Neuropsychiatric disorders (NPDs), including autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and schizophrenia, are collectively common conditions in the human population that have a significant genetic component that remains mostly unexplained. Genetic studies to date have focused on the contribution of variant classes in isolation, and therefore hampers our understanding of overall architecture. This study will combine cutting- edge genetic variation detection algorithms, novel statistical methods, and large cross-disorder NPD datasets to jointly evaluate the contribution of the full range of human variation, from common to rare, coding to noncoding, and single-nucleotide to large structural, on NPD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Childhood absence epilepsy (CAE) is the most common pediatric epilepsy syndrome, affecting 10–17% of all children with epilepsy. Those with CAE often experience significant diagnostic delay and limited monitoring due to the difficulty in detecting absence seizures, which also limits clinical studies of new anti-epileptic drugs in this patient population. An in-clinic diagnostic method would reduce the wait times associated with in-clinic VEEG appointments, potentially reducing time-to-diagnosis and improving access, especially in rural and low-income areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertension is a leading risk factor for cardiovascular disease, with disproportionate burden in non-Hispanic Black individuals that is in part due to implicit bias in clinical care (unconscious stereotypes that affect clinician attitudes and behavior towards Black individuals). The proposed research will refine and standardize a racial implicit bias mitigation intervention and pilot test it in primary care, providing all necessary and sufficient information for a full-scale randomized clinical trial. The ultimate goal of this research is to promote racial equity in hypertension treatment and control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it proposes applying human-centered design, an established approach that has been successfully applied to implementation problems in other domains of technology, to the challenge of incorporating patient/user perspectives in the design of novel neurotechnologies. Human-centered design in neurotechnology holds potential to address key neuroethical problems and also to enhance the usability and feasibility of new treatments based on BRAIN Initiative-supported research. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission of applying knowledge to enhance health and to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of novel neurotechnologies has not only expanded the range of treatment options available to patients, but also increased the complexity around ethical decision-making, in particular, when these interventions are considered earlier in the disease progression. This study will provide in-depth new knowledge regarding neuroethical issues around shared-decision making and decisional needs of patients and clinicians associated with the early use of neurotechnology, and address these issues by developing and testing a patient-centered decision aid (PtDA) for advanced neurotechnology. Responding to the BRAIN Initiative imperatives, our resulting PtDA will enhance shared decision-making and guide ethical choices surrounding the early use of neurotechnology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Latinx youth in the United States are at increased risk of poor mental health, sadness, hopelessness, and suicide ideation, and despite need, access to mental health care is limited. Globally, task-shifting (shifting specialized mental health interventions from clinical settings to community settings by training non-mental health providers) is a promising approach to reducing depression symptoms and increasing access to care, yet it has not been fully investigated as a suicide prevention strategy in the United States. This proposal will investigate the feasibility and acceptability of an adapted evidence-based mental health intervention, task- shifted to trusted adults (mentors), to target key risk factors for passive suicide ideation among Latinx youth in community centers as an upstream approach to suicide (before suicide behaviors onset).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PIEZOs are mechanosensitive ion channels that convert force into an electrical signal, and they play critical roles in diverse physiological processes including respiration, touch, proprioception, and vascular development. The goal of this proposal is to determine the fundamental structural mechanics underlying PIEZO ion channel function. This research will advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of PIEZO ion channel activation and provide insights into how channel dysfunction causes disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  HIV evolves to escape the human immune system and drug therapies, but it is constrained by the need to interface with host cell components that allow for infection. This proposal will take an innovative high- throughput approach to comprehensively parse the functional and innate immune-imposed evolutionary constraints on the HIV capsid protein, a critical immune and therapeutic target. These results will reveal how HIV structurally interfaces with and escapes from human innate immunity, and they will allow us to identify viral Achille's heels that can be synergistically constrained by native human immunity and capsid-targeting drugs to limit viral escape, which is a major barrier to effective antiviral therapy.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Harmful algal blooms (HABs) are most commonly known to make animals and people sick through contaminated food and water. We now know that HABs can also can become aerosolized and inhaled but the associated health effects are not well understood. Defining a role for HAB aerosols in the protection of human health by advancing our understanding of inhalation exposures and novel health outcomes is critical to inform management programs and health risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing concern among researchers and clinicians is of frequent and high-intensity cannabis use (e.g., daily/near daily use, use multiple times a day, and use of higher potency THC products). Mobile health (mHealth) technology may help address gaps between clinical need and formal clinical services, particularly for non-collegiate young adults. The proposed R34 application uses a multi-method user-informed approach to develop a novel brief motivational mHealth intervention that incorporates cutting-edge cannabis intervention research and emphasizes YAs’ autonomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE. Novel vaccination strategies are necessary to contain TB, as the currently licensed anti-TB vaccine, Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG), has limited efficacy. We have developed a strain of Mycobacterium tuberculosis which effectively protects against TB prior to granuloma formation with strong early responses. We will study how these very early immune responses generate protection from TB before granulomas are formed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium has become a concerning opportunistic pathogen known to cause recurrent infections in high-risk patients, and few antibiotics are available to treat this organism. We have limited knowledge regarding the bacterial genomic and phenotypic adaptations that arise within the human host during infection that lead to persistent and recurrent disease. This proposal outlines a training program designed to equip Dr. Stellfox with the essential skills in comparative genomics, evolutionary biology, phage biology, and pharmacology that are necessary to discover new bacterial cellular pathways associated with recurrent enterococcal bacteremia and evaluate the potential of bacteriophage-antibiotic combinations to combat challenging enterococcal infections.

PHR: Project Narrative Many patient advocacy groups are working passionately to improve care and outcomes for specific diseases and vulnerable populations, but best methods to achieve these goals are unknown. Equal collaboration between clinicians, researchers, and advocacy groups utilizing implementation science methods is underutilized and promises to increase use of evidence-based interventions in clinical practice to increase quality of life and reduce disability and illness. This K18 training program will educate a successful clinical trialist in implementation science so that he can increase the use of these methods in clinical contexts and teach the methods to other clinician scientists.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing patient advocacy group-driven research via implementation science

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to test our hypothesis that hepatitis C virus NS5A inhibitors Elb and Dac can be developed into cancer therapeutic agents. We will determine the role of HCV NS5A inhibitors in overcoming cancer cell intrinsic resistance to and TME-induced extrinsic protection from chemotherapies and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging associated muscle loss, pathologically called sarcopenia, is related to dysfunctional mitochondria, metabolism, muscle function. Exercise and resistance training have been identified as one of the few viable therapies to slow or possibly reverse sarcopenia. This proposal is designed specifically with the goal of establishing naturally aged three-dimensional engineered muscle tissue differentiated as a model for metabolic testing to investigate and identify molecular mechanisms that contribute to sarcopenia that may be targeted for therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Anti-obesity medications designed to reduce excess body fat or “adiposity” contribute to weight loss and substantially reduce the risk of heart disease. The genetic impact of adiposity on lipid levels—both critical risk factors for heart disease—remains uncertain but holds considerable clinical and therapeutic potential. This proposal will leverage comprehensive clinical and multi-omics data from large-scale cohorts to uncover key biological components at the intersection of adiposity and lipid pathways, potentially advancing heart disease risk assessment and identifying new therapeutic targets for individuals with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Mitochondrial stability and activity support changes in neurons in reward-related areas of the brain in response to exposure to drugs contributing to substance use disorders, including nicotine. The current proposal seeks to determine how nicotine changes mitochondria and chromatin accessibility in specific neuron populations and how this influences the rewarding effects of nicotine that make smoking cessation difficult. This work will contribute to a novel understanding of drug-induced changes in the brain and will link epigenetic processes to mitochondrial signaling pathways, providing new therapeutic targets downstream of epigenetic modifications for substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current best practice guidelines and regulatory mandates for sepsis encourage immediate administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics to any patient with suspected sepsis, contributing to a high rate of overuse of antibiotics directed at methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and multidrug-resistant Gram-negative organisms. The proposed research seeks to quantify the impact of overly broad and overly narrow initial antibiotic coverage in a large multi-hospital cohort of patients with suspected sepsis, and then identify specific phenotypes of sepsis for which overly broad antibiotics can be safely avoided, by combining electronic health record data with information on symptoms and risk factors for multidrug resistant organisms extracted from clinical notes with large language models. This study will have important clinical and public health implications by quantifying the unintended adverse consequences of broad antibiotic use, helping clinicians select safer antibiotic choices for patients with potential sepsis, and enabling new data-driven strategies for antimicrobial stewardship.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Identifying Sepsis Phenotypes Associated with Antibiotic-Resistant Pathogens Using Large Language Models and Machine Learning

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Poor oral health negatively affects vulnerable and underserved populations that disproportionally rely on emergency departments (EDs) for treatment of non-traumatic dental conditions. This research will use advanced health informatics approaches and leverage electronic health record data to better address oral health disparities among underserved adults, including minority racial and ethnic groups, rural populations, and those with lower socioeconomic status, who seek non-traumatic dental treatment in emergency departments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While adults with systemic lupus erythematosus, a chronic autoimmune disease, now live routinely to 50 years of age and beyond, they remain at increased risk for poor health compared to older adults without lupus as they get older. Frailty, a state of decreased physiologic reserve, is a risk factor for poor health outcomes. The objective of this project is to adapt and pilot test a tablet-based physical activity intervention with embedded team-driven social support for frail and pre-frail adults with lupus 50 years of age and above, with the ultimate goal of improving their overall health and wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identification of hereditary pathogenic germline variants in patients with colorectal cancer (CRC) informs treatment, surveillance, and familial cascade testing to reduce cancer incidence, morbidity, and mortality, yet rates of germline genetic testing in CRC are poor. Mainstream genetic testing (MGT) is an effective pathway to increase genetic testing in cancer patients, however it has not been widely adopted. This proposal seeks to increase genetic testing in CRC by tailoring and piloting an implementation strategy to increase the uptake of MGT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is the most common bacterial cause of mortality in the United States and is associated with rates of antibiotic treatment failure in excess of 15% for some types of infections. Depletion of arginine, an essential amino acid, leads to an increase in antibiotic failure in mature S. aureus communities through unclear mechanisms. Using a combination of in vitro experiments, tissue culture, in vivo mouse infection models, and advanced imaging mass spectroscopy, I will test the hypothesis that S. aureus is able to regulate the level of arginine to promote its own survival and persistence in the presence of antibiotics and the innate immune system.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood exposure to violence (CEV) in early childhood is a significant and preventable public health problem in the United States, and pediatric healthcare settings are centrally positioned to identify and intervene upon early CEV. The proposed research aims to (1) understand existing CEV assessment tools and follow-up processes in pediatric primary care settings; (2) identify facilitators of and barriers to routine CEV assessment in these settings; (3) characterize patterns of early CEV assessment across one large medical system; and (4) determine whether these assessments are associated with subsequent healthcare referral, follow-up care receipt, and child health outcomes. Findings will provide translatable information for primary care settings implementing the recent Joint Commission mandate to assess social and environmental risks across health settings, and highlight areas for future measurement and implementation science research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Numerous neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders are driven by aberrant levels of proteins that must remain tightly regulated for brain health, such as tau aggregation in Alzheimer’s disease. Large-scale cell- based screens have been used to discover previously unknown regulators of highly regulated proteins, however these screens require multiple rounds of strenuous validations to eventually identify the candidate that will then need to be tested in vivo. Here, this project will bypass cell-based screens by developing a high-throughput genome-wide in vivo CRISPR/Cas9 screening method, which will provide a powerful and efficient tool to identify new therapeutic targets for several neurological disorders driven by altered protein levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Outcomes in epilepsy surgery are dependent on correctly identifying and mapping the seizure onset zone and epileptic network. Despite recent advance, seizure freedom rates have not improved and have remained stagnant, which can be attributed to poor localization of epileptic tissue. In this study, we translate our recent findings of lactate upregulation in epileptic tissue to develop metabolic imaging of hyperpolarized 13C pyruvate as a novel tool to identify the seizure onset zone. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atypical sensorimotor behaviors are common in autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and they appear to be mechanistically related to clinical and cognitive traits and distinct in autistic individuals with co-occurring intellectual disability (ID). The proposed studies will characterize the motor and neurophysiologic mechanisms of multisensory (visual and somatosensory) feedback processing during sustained fine and gross motor control in school-aged autistic children with and without ID. Theses studies hold promise for identifying physiologic mechanisms contributing to clinical and cognitive challenges in ASD to aid the development of effective interventions and supports.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes and metabolic diseases are a global and national burden for health care with a high death toll. Hormones produced by intestinal endocrine cells exert important regulatory actions in metabolism and glucose homeostasis. The studies proposed by the candidate seek to investigate the modulatory effects of a retinoid- related protein on intestinal endocrine cell homeostasis and insulinotropic hormone production and will provide physiological insights that may help harness these cells’ therapeutic potential.

PHR: FOA PAR-23-072 Regulatory Science Track of the 2024 APHL Annual Conference  Project Narrative The new Regulatory Science Track of the 2024 APHL Annual Conference will enable leaders, scientists, policy makers, regulators, and their partners to share issues, trends and best practices driving public health. Information presented will help scientists in their efforts to submit high-quality data for regulatory action, improve investigations that rely on food testing and human illness data, and reduce foodborne illnesses and deaths overall. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community-based drug checking (CBDC) has the potential to identify emerging substances like xylazine (a dangerous adulterant not approved for use in humans) in the illicit drug market in real time and serve as point of care with actionable responses and referrals to treatment and services; however, there is limited information on the use of CBDC in rural settings. Minnesota legalized all drug paraphernalia in 2023, and the state provided funding to syringe service programs (SSPs) to purchase Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy equipment, xylazine testing strips, and wound care kits. Through collaboration with an SSP that has a delivery area classified as rural and includes two American Indian / Native American tribal reservations, we will examine use of their CBDC program using the Behavioral Model for Vulnerable Populations as a guiding framework. The 24-month mixed-methods study will examine feasibility and acceptability of the CBDC program to detect xylazine through surveys with program participants and interviews with staff—with those whose drugs test positive for xylazine recruited to complete a qualitative interview on use and health effects— and the prevalence of xylazine calculated among the illicit drug samples tested with dissemination to harm reduction and public health stakeholders prioritized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cigarette smoking and nicotine dependence are the major cause of preventable death in the United States. A potent driver of relapse to smoking are places (e.g., bars or coffee shops) where the effects of nicotine were previously experienced. The proposed research aims to understand the neural basis of these drug-place associations by determining how the hippocampus and nicotinic receptors regulate learning in a mouse model, findings that will potentially lead to novel treatments to prevent relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasticity is a key property of the neural system controlling breathing, and is an important compensatory mechanism for disease or injury. Acute intermittent hypoxia triggers respiratory plasticity, and has emerged as a promising neurotherapeutic to preserve/restore breathing in devastating clinical disorders such as spinal cord injury and ALS; thus, understanding how specific factors affect individual responses to this promising treatment is a key ‘next-step’ in finding biomarkers to assure success (or failure) of clinical trials. I propose experiments to investigate the specific roles of the APOE4 gene and inflammation in motor neuron-microglia interactions that regulate respiratory motor plasticity.

PHR: NARRATIVE Large-scale human studies have pinpointed thousands of regions in the human genome that are associated with susceptibility to diseases such as type 2 diabetes, asthma, and cardiovascular disease. The goal of this project is to develop and apply new tools to map out gene regulatory networks and connect their activities to disease-associated genetic variation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is a common blood disorder in which the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells, resulting in anemia, infection and bleeding. Although we know what genetic changes (mutations) cause MDS, the precise mechanisms that cause MDS are still unclear, and this has prevented development of effective therapies. This proposal seeks to improve our understanding of molecular pathways of MDS, especially those affecting processing of ribonucleic acid (RNA); it is hoped that this work will help develop novel therapies and offer a path to cure for patients with MDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) exerts a global impact on public health, causing nearly 10 million new infections and 1.5 million deaths annually. There remains an urgent need for new anti-TB drugs and many genetically validated drug targets remain to be exploited. In this project, we seek to optimize a novel type of cell wall synthesis inhibitor with the goal of developing a new candidate antibiotic for the treatment of TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Loss of muscle mass occurs in various diseases such as sarcopenia, cancer cachexia, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, leading to poor prognosis and increased mortality rate. There is an urgent need to understand the requirements for maintaining muscle mass and to develop therapeutic treatments for muscle disease. Our research explores the role of the transcription factor Maf in repressing muscle atrophy to develop new therapeutic strategies against muscle mass loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Psychological stress is associated with elevated risk for negative mental and physical health outcomes, yet we have a limited understanding of the brain circuits and brain-body pathways that are a) implicated in this risk and b) can be modified by interventions in humans. In this K01 application, the applicant proposes training goals in 1) clinical affective neuroscience, 2) transcranial magnetic stimulation methods, and 3) human experimental study design, which will enable the applicant to complete the proposed research and transition to an independent investigator focused on characterizing and manipulating brain-body interactions in healthy and clinical populations. This study will manipulate brain activity in a circuit implicated in stress processing and test the effect of this manipulation on brain and emotional responses to psychological stress in midlife adults.

PHR: NARRATIVE While genomic data can provide an invaluable source of information to understand pathogen evolution, identify patterns of transmission, and characterize phenotypes such as drug resistance and immune escape, the complex biology and infection dynamics of eukaryotic pathogens have limited the use of these data. Leveraging recent laboratory advances in targeted amplicon sequencing that are changing the landscape of data availability, we propose to develop an ecosystem of integrated analysis tools to facilitate research using these data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Title: Building a Harmonized Village Network Data Resource for Realistic Disease Transmission Models PROJECT NARRATIVE To understand how policy, behavior and disease interact to generate outbreaks, social scientists need models that can accurately capture the myriad factors driving real-life epidemics, but current data and modeling practices perform poorly and fail to meet this need, largely due to insufficient data support and heterogenous modeling practices. Collective science – pooling data and tools from multiple investigators – is a proven method to amplify scientific investment for public good, allowing researchers greater insights across larger and more diverse domains. This project will (1) develop a secure-but-shareable repository of village and rural networks to serve as a test-bed for disease simulation modeling; (2) expand tools for network simulation to allow modeling of multiple types of pathogens, disease responsiveness, information flow, and policy interventions; and (3) compare disease-responsive behavior models across multiple contexts to identify how network structure moderates behavioral effects on epidemic size.

PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will increase access to evidence-based mental health resources for hundreds of Latino families who need intervention but for whom myriad barriers impede their access. Furthermore, a significant step will have been taken toward providing much-needed mental health resources to Latino parents following the largest global health crisis of the modern era. The project aligns with NIMH's strategic plan to develop innovative service delivery models to improve the outcomes of mental health services received in underserved communities through technology-mediated services that have the potential to improve access to and effectiveness of evidence-based interventions for adolescent mental health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a deadly under-recognized disease characterized by high blood pressure in the lungs and right heart failure. While several medicines are used to treat PAH, none can cure this disease and none are aimed at helping right heart function. We propose to serve as the Data Coordinating Center for a randomized clinical trial testing whether the drug empagliflozin, classified as a sodium glucose co- transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, will improve right heart function and other outcomes in patients with PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative High-throughput Adaptive Immune Receptor Repertoire sequencing (AIRR-seq) has become a fundamental method for investigating B cell and T cell adaptive immune responses. We developed nf-core/airrflow (AIRRflow), a high-throughput, scalable analysis workflow using the Immcantation Framework that facilitate AIRR-seq data processing in high-performance clusters and cloud infrastructure. Through novel features that enable the integrated analysis of large-scale AIRR-seq datasets and improve interoperability with public databases and downstream analysis tools, we aim to make AIRRflow an even more useful tool for the infectious and immune- mediated disease community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Some patients with mycosis fungoides (MF), a skin cancer, will progress to late-stage disease with involvement beyond the skin and a higher mortality risk. This study will investigate the subtypes and the location of cancer- associated fibroblasts (CAFs) responsible for immune evasion of MF tumor cells in the skin of diverse patient populations. Results obtained here will provide insights into the role of the tumor microenvironment in the progression of MF and identify potential targets for more direct personalized therapies to improve overall survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research team has shown a link between poor sleep health and late circadian timing with cardiometabolic dysfunction in adolescents with type 1 diabetes (T1D). Our central hypothesis is that that cardiometabolic dysfunction associated with T1D can be reduced by improving sleep health and circadian timing. The overall objective of the current proposal is to use a 1-month intervention with known chronobiotic tools, PM melatonin and AM bright light, in conjunction with extended sleep opportunity, as a mechanistic probe to understand changes in cardiometabolic outcomes (insulin sensitivity, glycemic control, and aortic stiffness) and physiologic mechanisms in adolescents with T1D using a combined free-living and in-laboratory paradigm.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: In this study, we propose a new imaging tool to assess human uteroplacental vascularization in early pregnancy based on the pressure estimation using subharmonic aided pressure estimation (SHAPE) technique. We suggest using the mean pressure gradients between the uterine artery, placental bed (arteries in decidua and myometrium), and intervillous space as well as the standard deviation of SHAPE pressure estimates in the placental bed as functional indices of placental development. We hypothesize that these indices will correlate with the degree of uteroplacental vascularization, i.e., with gestational age in normal pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Injuries to the tendon-bone attachment, or enthesis, are frequent amongst the general population and existing treatments are limited with variable efficacy, leaving patients with high re-rupture rates, impacted quality of life, and increased likelihood of developing joint degenerative diseases. Unlike the mammalian enthesis which scars after injury, the zebrafish tendon-bone attachment can fully regenerate through mechanisms yet to be discovered. By employing cross-species comparative genetics and genomics approaches in zebrafish and mice after injury, this proposal will elucidate divergent signaling mechanisms driving successful enthesis regeneration versus fibrosis which may be leveraged to inspire new treatment strategies in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative G protein–coupled receptors (GPCRs) are common drug targets and include chemokine receptors, which help immune cells respond to infections and cancer. However, chemokine signaling is often dysregulated in many inflammatory skin and other diseases. My project will biochemically define a new GPCR chemokine signaling pathway in immune cells, which may provide new avenues to treat inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genes, which contain instructions for making all proteins in the body, are regulated by sequence-specific DNA interactions by transcription factors (TF). Current methods to detect TF-DNA interactions are biased for only the highest affinity interactions when medium-low affinity interactions are very important and more common. I have developed PADIT-seq, an improved technology to detect TF-DNA interactions across the entire spectrum of affinities. The overall goal of this proposal is to utilize and further develop PADIT-seq to uncover fundamental TF-DNA binding principles, which will significantly advance our mechanistic understanding of the principles governing gene regulation and genetic risk factors for complex diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The WHO currently recommends annual mass azithromycin distribution in trachoma-endemic areas until the district-level prevalence of trachomatous inflammation-follicular (TF) drops below 5%. Since there is no true gold standard test to assess the prevalence of active disease, we will use a model which assumes a true, but latent or hidden state of infection. We anticipate that the results of this study will provide will show modestly improved precision of detecting the true state of trachomatis infection in a hypoendemic and hyperendemic communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults – particularly older women – are at increased risk of prolonged inflammation and inflammatory- related diseases; one way through which older adults may be at higher risk for prolonged inflammation and inflammatory disease is through daily stress processes. The proposed research will examine how aspects of daily stressors (i.e., frequency, severity, immediate and prolonged affective reactions to daily stressors) are linked with inflammatory biomarkers in a racially and socioeconomically diverse sample of older adults, and how gender may differentially inform these associations. Study findings will determine the contexts in which intervention efforts may be particularly advantageous and may inform future studies using complex, repeated methodology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance People with type 1 diabetes are disproportionately affected by cardiovascular disease (CVD). Short and irregular sleep have been associated with cardiovascular risk in this population. Improving sleep regularity has been associated with improved glycemic markers however mechanisms by which improving sleep regularity improves metabolic and cardiovascular health is not known. We propose to conduct a mechanistic study using a sleep stability manipulation. This proposal will advance the understanding of mechanisms by which improving sleep regularity influences glycemic control and cardiovascular risk in T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use in the early postpartum period is an urgent public health problem that can interfere with a mother’s ability to care for her baby, and is associated with increased risk for child abuse and neglect and poor long-term child health and developmental outcomes. Systems that serve postpartum mothers often fail to identify and adequately address substance use, missing prime opportunities for preventing negative outcomes. The proposed R34 will further refine an innovative digital screening and brief intervention for postpartum substance use designed for use in evidence-based home visiting programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Understanding the impact that RNA motifs have, on its structure and function, is of importance to assess their biological roles; this information can be leveraged to control/regulate the biological outcome of different RNA- derived mechanisms. This proposal will establish the 5'-GUAC- palindromic sequence as a motif, while understanding the nature of its unique structural behavior. This will aid in understanding how the presence of this sequence in various types of RNA impacts interactions with other biopolymers and metabolites, thus making it a potential target for drugs or proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment (CI), including Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), are prevalent in later life with limited treatment options. Sleep disturbance (SD) is a significant risk factor for the development of CI/ADRD in older adults. This project seeks to examine how specific types of SD may be associated with poorer cognitive function and worse health outcomes earlier - among younger, middle-aged adults. We will develop and pilot test an efficient, scalable, primary care strategy for the routine detection of SD to mitigate CI/ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Later sleep timing has been identified as a risk factor for youth-onset type 2 diabetes, yet adolescents adopt later sleep patterns (chronotype) as part of normal development. Current literature on sleep timing and its relationship to glucose metabolism may not apply to older adolescents and young adults with later chronotype, as morning testing may be mis-aligned with the schedule of these youth, leading to the potential for misleading results and/or misdiagnoses. This project will assess whether delaying the timing of testing for diabetes risk in youth with late chronotype improves testing results both in our research lab and in a real-world setting, to gain a better understanding of the diabetes risk for this understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Signaling proteins like bacterial histidine kinases act as switches, sensing environmental stimuli and initiating a cellular response through a series of conformational changes and enzymatic steps. For these predominant receptors, we still lack significant understanding of how signals are propagated through the protein scaffold to induce switch-like behavior. By design signaling components from scratch and engineering them into signaling proteins, we can interrogate signaling mechanisms from first principles, bringing us closer to a molecular level understanding how nature has evolved dynamic yet specific signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Maintaining mineral and bone metabolism in homeostasis is critical, and disruption of hormonal regulators of mineral metabolism can have significant consequences. Both chronic kidney disease mineral and bone metabolism (CKD-MBD) and hypoparathyroidism show insufficient 1,25-vitamin D levels, which affect mineral metabolism, kidney and bone health. Here, we hypothesize that inhibition of salt-inducible kinases, downstream mediators of PTH actions in kidney and bone, will result in desirable PTH-like effects by stimulating 1,25-vitamin D and bone formation.
