IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-income populations have a disproportionately higher prevalence of type 2 diabetes and experience poorer health outcomes. This proposal will use the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities research framework to develop a digital intervention tailored to the unique needs of low-income adults newly diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. We will also examine the feasibility and acceptability of implementing the intervention within a federally qualified health center and examine the effect on self-management behaviors and diabetes-related health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Precisely maintaining gene expression levels is essential to define cellular identity and to prevent a wide range of diseases, including developmental disorders and cancers. In mammalian cells, activation or repression of genes is accomplished in part by multiprotein complexes that affect local or higher-order chromatin structure. By understanding the molecular mechanism of the competition of activating and repressive complexes to determine gene expression levels this study will provide insights that may help guide the development of future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Project Narrative There are currently no validated measures of cognition that are sensitive to the range of functioning in individuals with profound intellectual disability (PID); however, these tools are critical for clinical care, person-centered services, and research contexts. This proposal seeks to develop novel performance (PerfO) and observer-report (ObsRO) measures of cognition that provide meaningful information about current functioning and have the potential to capture meaningful change in individuals with PID. The intent is that these measures will not only facilitate improved clinical care and services for individuals with PID but also support the development of novel treatments that will improve quality of life in this underserved group.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Many laboratory tests are unnecessary and contribute to reduced care quality. Using multisite data from the PICU Data Collaborative (PDC), we will develop machine learning models that forecast future laboratory values in children with critical illness, and identify processes to use these forecasts to reduce laboratory overutilization. We will use user-centered design principles to develop clinical decision support tool(s), deploy the tool(s) at a pilot site, and establish the groundwork for a future effectiveness-implementation trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Molecular diagnostics (MDx) can provide personalized care and improve patient outcomes; however, disparities in payment for MDx create barriers that delay or prevent patients from accessing these diagnostic tests. The proposed project uses innovative mixed methods to address key gaps in our understanding of MDx payment disparities and identify strategies to promote access to MDx payment pathways. Results will lay the groundwork for developing policy and practice interventions that guide equitable MDx implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection causes approximately 10 million new cases of tuberculosis (TB) and 1.5 million TB-related deaths each year, in addition to being the leading cause of death in HIV-infected individuals. In order to develop new and more effective therapies, better understanding of Mtb pathogenesis and HIV-TB co-infection is required. The proposed studies will provide critical insight into the pathogenesis of TB, the immune requirements for successful control of Mtb infection, and how HIV infection affects this control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to examine and understand the transition to home after initial hospital discharge for Black preterm infants with chronic lung disease and to pilot a novel parent engagement intervention in pediatric primary care to reduce respiratory morbidity. Black preterm infants with chronic lung disease face a lifetime of disparities in lung health compared to White preterm infants, yet studies to date have primarily focused on infants' initial hospital stay and do not account for families' lived experiences at home that meaningfully shape child health and wellbeing. The K23 award will prepare the applicant for an independent research career with expertise in parent engagement interventions in primary care to advance health equity, while providing insights into early lung health for Black preterm infants with chronic lung disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will study mechanisms of heart failure by analyzing images of the heart and proteins form the blood together. We will investigate two heart diseases with mechanisms of infiltration and toxicity: light-chain amyloid heart disease, and cancer-therapy-related heart disease. We aim to deepen our understanding of the mechanisms of these diseases, improve evaluation and prevention strategies for future patients, and identify new targets for drug development to improve outcomes of patients with heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The nasal mucosa is the first site of contact of the inhaled air and its particulate matter including allergens and the respiratory tract. The olfactory neuroepithelium, embedded in the nasal mucosa, is a unique neuronal organ comprised of olfactory sensory neurons surrounded by specialized epithelial cells, two distinct populations of progenitor cells and interspersed immune cells. TRPM5+ microvillous cells are epithelial cells lining the surface of the olfactory epithelium. They are directly activated by allergens to generate potent pro- inflammatory mediators (lipid mediators, acetylcholine and IL-25) and orchestrate olfactory remodeling. The proposal here seeks to define how the TRPM5+ microvillous cells detect allergens and how these cells direct the spread of allergen-elicited activation signals in the olfactory epithelium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Upon successful completion of the proposed research, we expect our contribution to address the critical unmet need for longitudinal data from clinical outcome assessments and plasma biomarkers for clinical trial readiness for the rare disorder of Posterior Cortical Atrophy (PCA). This contribution will be significant because it will establish the essential foundation necessary to successfully design and recruit participants with PCA for future clinical trials with currently available candidate therapeutics. Longitudinal investigations of PCA will also allow us to broaden our understanding of the heterogeneous nature and pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease, which is especially relevant to the development of new approaches to treatments for a major public health issue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 2.7 million people suffer from opioid use disorder in the United States, resulting in more than 80,000 opioid overdose deaths in 2021. Medications for opioid use disorder are underused disproportionately in patients living in poverty, whose unmet food, housing, and transportation needs impede access to medications and routine healthcare. This proposal—which is aligned with the patient-centered models of care priority of the Services Research Branch at the National Institute of Drug Abuse—will leverage clinical decision support technology to incorporate social care into opioid use disorder medication treatment, with the goal of improving treatment adherence and follow up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-traumatic stress and alcohol use disorder (PTSD/AUD) are frequently comorbid and are a major public health problem. The proposed multidisciplinary research is relevant to the mission of NIAAA and addresses important gaps in the literature on examining the role of antistress neurocircuitry (somatostatin) underlying PTSD/AUD comorbidity and novel mechanistic strategies for their prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breakthroughs in cancer immunotherapy have paved the way in leveraging the immune system to combat highly aggressive malignancies. The overall goal of this proposal is to develop microbial-based agents that increase immune density within immunologically “cold” tumors as a means to enhance efficacy and response rates to current immunotherapies. If successful, these microbial-based agents, termed “bio-beacons,” will significantly impact patient outcomes and overall survival worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Social deficits in autism spectrum disorder may partially reflect blunted reward response to social stimuli. Although neuroimaging research suggests this blunting may generalize beyond the social domain, most studies fail to directly compare neural response to social and non-social outcomes and no study models the experience of actually being liked by peers (i.e., direct social reward). We propose to overcome these shortcomings by isolating differences in neurotypical and autistic adolescents’ neural response to social (being liked) and non- social (winning money) reward using fMRI, and for the first time, midbrain dopamine system function, with neuromelanin-sensitive MRI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Chemical imaging holds tremendous promise in intraoperative cancer diagnosis and personalized drug screening. However, the inherent tradeoff between resolution and field of view is a major challenge to its various biomedical applications. We will develop new deep-learning algorithms to break the tradeoff and enable large- area, high-resolution chemical imaging of any biological samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal exposure to the environmental contaminant trichloroethylene (TCE) is associated with elevated risk of small-for-gestational-age (SGA), an adverse birth outcome that increases the risk for morbidity and mortality in infancy and chronic metabolic diseases in adulthood. This Transition to Independent Environmental Health Research (TIEHR) Career Award will provide training and research support to investigate the biological plausibility of TCE contributing to elevated risk of SGA by identifying molecular mechanisms underpinning disruption of placental cellular function at the maternal-fetal interface. The results of this research will offer valuable insights for policymakers and clinicians, helping enhance protective measures and therapeutic strategies to improve maternal and fetal health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapies have revolutionized treatment options for patients with hematologic malignancies and hold promise for other types of cancer. However, limited CAR T cell expansion, persistence, and immune suppression from T regulatory (Treg) cells limit efficacy of CAR T cell therapies for large B cell lymphoma (LBCL). This proposal will: (1) employ fate mapping to identify drivers of desirable T cell states in pre-manufacture apheresis and infusion products with optimal expansion and persistence properties, and (2) mechanistically dissect and evaluate methods to overcome Treg suppression, providing a platform to improve CAR T cell therapy treatment options for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of patients with nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL) receive treatment with intensive chemotherapy with or without radiotherapy yet are at very low risk of lymphoma-specific death and are subsequently at risk for potentially fatal cardiotoxicity. We propose to identify cell state ecosystems predictive of clinical outcome, establish novel methods to genotype NLPHL, and quantify inherited risk of cardiovascular disease with the goal to inform a risk-adapted approach to management. This project will fuel the development of prospective clinical trials evaluating rational selection of patients suitable for de-escalation of therapy to optimize treatment for NLPHL and reduce therapy associated deaths.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Veteran suicides, suicide attempts and suicidal ideation continue to be major public health concerns. This research addresses two critical unmet needs related to suicidal behavior among veterans: 1) The unmet need for a rapid-acting treatment for veterans who are experiencing suicidal thoughts; and 2) The unmet need for valid objective measurements, or biomarkers of veteran suicidality, to improve diagnosis and guide treatment development. Through pilot testing the novel anti-suicidal treatment uridine, while pairing it with brain scans performed before-and-after treatment, the goal of this study is to improve our understanding of suicidal ideation in the veteran population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotic resistance is a pressing, multifaceted challenge, and understanding it requires combining molecular, evolutionary, and structural frameworks. We will investigate how important but understudied types of mutations, specifically insertions and deletions, can radically change the properties of proteins responsible for resistance. Integrating our results will produce a deeper understanding of how microbes evolve, how proteins change, and what resistance might occur in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Defects in development that effect the migration of neural progenitor cells in the intestine can result in patient phenotypes, including Hirschsprung’s disease. Because the biological mechanisms behind this process are still not fully understood, we propose studying a key upstream regulatory gene Sox10 in the context of chromatin alterations, since it has been previously described as affecting chromatin in other neural crest derived cell populations. The findings from these proposed aims will advance knowledge of the molecular mechanisms of the development of the enteric nervous system which may be targets for study in human enteric nervous system- related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to reveal (I) the dynamics of intermuscular adipose (IMAT) pro-inflammatory secretome across the BMI and insulin sensitivity spectrum and (II) the relative contribution of MAPK signaling to IMAT-induced muscle insulin resistance. This is relevant to public health because IMAT is physically positioned to exert profound metabolic consequences on skeletal muscle. Our findings will align with the NIH mission by enabling targeted IMAT therapies to robustly sensitize muscle to insulin, thus enhancing health, lengthening life, and reducing disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) are associated with gut dysbiosis and high dietary cholesterol intake and they affect a quarter of the world population, yet there are no FDA-approved treatments. This proposal aims to determine the mechanistic contribution of dietary cholesterol to NAFLD/NASH through actions of gut microbiota. Uncovering this aspect of NAFLD/NASH pathophysiology may lead to implementation of dietary and/or probiotic treatments to alleviate the burden of NAFLD/NASH worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While ADAM17 loss of function mutations result in a highly fatal pediatric enteropathy presenting with chronic diarrhea and altered intestinal architecture, exceedingly little is known about the disease. This project aims to characterize the human intestinal phenotype caused by ADAM17 loss of function, determine if ADAM17 proteolytic activity mediates cell signaling crosstalk, and define all ADAM17 substrates in the developing human intestine. This work will provide insight on the role of ADAM17 in the developing human intestine by characterizing cellular and molecular changes caused by ADAM17 loss of function in a patient specific iPSC- derived human intestinal organoid model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE High-frequency repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (HF-rTMS) is a non-invasive method for clinical brain stimulation that can treat psychiatric disorders. HF-rTMS is thought to restore excitability in hypoactive circuits, but the mechanisms underlying the therapeutic effects of rTMS remain poorly understood. This project will determine how focal HF-rTMS induces plasticity in cortical circuits and whether particular classes of neurons underlie the behavioral effects of rTMS, leading to improved design of clinical treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several lines of research indicate that adolescent alcohol misuse is associated with increased pain sensitivity in adults. The biological basis for this increase is presently not fully understood. This project seeks to determine the role of adolescent alcohol exposure induced changes within an amygdala to prefrontal cortex to periaqueductal gray circuit involved in pain processing on pain sensitivity in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spontaneous preterm birth is a highly significant but understudied perinatal outcome that comprises the majority of premature births and has been linked to prenatal exposure to environmental chemicals, including phthalates. This study will investigate the mechanistic link between prenatal phthalate exposure, placental dysfunction, and spontaneous preterm birth using multi-omics data generated in the placenta. Findings from this study will inform chemical toxicological risk assessment and policy, as well as aid in the development of potential biomarkers of spontaneous preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the need for improved HIV therapies, particularly for patients who are ART non-compliant or ART naïve, the proposed studies will build on Marpam Pharma’s novel treatment strategy of using patients’ own T cells to target “hidden” HIV reservoirs containing actively replicating virus within lymphoid tissues. This project aims to develop a product for durable remission of HIV in patients who are not ART suppressed by generating a DNA construct optimized for this indication, developing a GMP-scalable method to produce CAR-T cells with the new construct, and to conduct an IND-enabling study that will assess the safety and efficacy of this product in an animal model of chronic HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Viral respiratory infections, such as influenza and coronaviruses, frequently lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), a condition with a mortality up to 46% where up to half of survivors continue to suffer from chronic respiratory disability due to persistent pulmonary fibrosis. Endothelial injury and dysfunction contribute to the severity of ARDS, persistence of lung injury, and dysregulated repair. The proposed studies will elucidate how the pulmonary endothelium promotes repair of the closely associated alveolar epithelial layer after viral infection-induced lung injury and identify novel translational targets to prevent morbid post-viral fibrotic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Diffusion magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI) plays a crucial role in routine clinical neuroimaging and has shown potential in new applications ranging from detecting microstructural lesions to guiding neurosurgery. This project addresses the need to improve the performance of dMRI by enabling high-resolution microstructure imaging with fast acquisition times, allowing clinical translation of impactful research applications. Ultimately, the proposed approach has the potential to enhance the quality of care for individuals with neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a recalcitrant cancer that causes 250,000 deaths worldwide each year. When diagnosed, many patients have metastasis in distant organs, most often in the liver, which represents a major impediment to successful therapy. Through decrypting the reciprocal interactions between cancer cells and endothelial cells in SCLC liver metastasis, I aim to identify novel aspects of SCLC metastasis and nominate candidate avenues for target therapies for SCLC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic retinopathy is one of the leading causes of irreversible blindness in the United States and decreasing this public health burden relies on timely screening and early intervention when needed. This project aims to understand the relationship between area deprivation index (ADI), as well as other measures of the local healthcare environment, and screening, follow up, and complication rates of diabetic retinopathy. Analyses will be conducted using 100% Medicare claims data, ADI and its components, and local healthcare environment information.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dramatic increase in early onset breast cancer (BC) incidence in the U.S., which has been most pronounced in non-Hispanic Black (NHB) women, underscores the need for an investment in cancer prevention research that is focused on risk modification beginning early in life. Increasing adolescent physical activity through community and family-based interventions may be one key factor in reducing early onset BC risk and racial disparities, but there is currently limited epidemiologic data, especially from racially diverse cohorts, to support this. This study will address this major gap by using data from racially diverse family-based cohorts that are enriched for BC susceptibility to elucidate the role of adolescent physical activity in early onset BC risk and outcomes after diagnosis in young women across the BC risk continuum and provide mechanistic insight that is needed to move this promising avenue for BC prevention and health equity forward.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most breast cancer-related deaths are the result of metastatic disease, and yet, some deadly metastatic sites, such as the liver, remain understudied. The project proposed in this application will improve the understanding of breast cancer liver metastasis by assessing the impact of tumor cell heme metabolism on immune suppression within the liver metastatic microenvironment. The goal of this research is to reveal novel therapeutic approaches to enhance anti-tumor immune responses against breast cancer liver metastasis and improve the survival and quality of life of breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate the mechanism by which production of GTP by GTP biosynthetic enzymes promotes activity of the tumor-promoting protein Rac1 in melanoma, and seek to exploit this mechanism for potential Rac1-suppressing therapy. Evaluating this approach could have an impact on aggressive melanoma cases which contain a prevalent Rac1 mutation, while also providing a basis for pursing novel treatments in other Rac1-dependent cancers. This work will also expand our understanding of the regulation of Rac1 by GTP metabolism by using state-of-the-art technology, providing new insights into the functionality of this critical protein in both normal and malignant cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on the development of a novel surface enhanced spatially offset resonance Raman spectroscopy (SESORRS) endoscope for the imaging and evaluation of colorectal cancer (CRC). Current clinical practices for the endoscopic imaging of CRC provide only morphological information, often failing to efficiently evaluate the required circumferential resection margin, or extent of tumor invasion into the wall of the colon. We aim to show that it is possible to use SESORRS endoscopy to determine the true extent of tumor invasion in real time, and use SESORRS endoscopy to support the image guided resection of lesions of interest by detecting residual tumor cells on, and beneath, the surface of the resection bed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it represents a novel way to combine cognitive science research techniques with radiological imaging to determine from neural and oculomotor analyses the extent to which the detection of one cancer impacts the detection of an additional cancer. It will also assess the impact that tomosynthesis, compared to mammography, and expertise has on multiple-abnormality miss rates in breast cancer detection. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that aims to reduce illness and lengthening life by improving early cancer detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many anti-cancer drugs are ineffective in solid tumors, but the underlying mechanism is not fully understood. This proposal aims to identify the factors in the tumor microenvironment that drive drug resistance in pancreatic cancer by integrating single-cell drug imaging and spatial multi-omics. This project will result in computational tools to chart the spatial landscape of the cell-cell and drug-cell interactions within the tumor microenvironment, revolutionize our understanding of the drug resistance mechanisms in pancreatic cancer, and facilitate the development of new treatment strategies to improve patient outcomes with this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aspergillus is a common environmental fungus that can cause invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, a dangerous infection in patients with weakened immunity. We seek to understand the components of the immune system that help the body fend off this infection. This knowledge has the potential to lead to new treatments to protect patients from this devastating infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common type of renal cell carcinoma which is characterized by a highly vascular tumor microenvironment and initially responds well to anti-angiogenic therapies. Despite this, almost all patients develop resistance to these therapies and thus improved therapies are urgently needed to treating patients affected by this disease. In this study, we propose utilizing a novel small molecule inhibitor and vaccine to target Profilin1 as a putative target for vascular normalization and treatment for renal cell carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic relapse can occur 20 years or more after diagnosis in patients with breast cancer. Developing therapies to prevent late recurrence and predict patients that will eventually relapse remains an enormous clinical challenge due to the lack of basic understanding of breast cancer cell dormancy in the bone marrow, the putative source of relapse. This proposal seeks to investigate the contribution of the bone marrow microenvironment to the induction and maintenance of dormancy via development of a novel mouse and biomaterial models and analysis of patient bone marrow biopsies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed project aims to identify specific compositional and functional features of gut microbiome that are directly involved in benign breast disease (BBD), and reveal the possible role of gut microbiome in mediating the hormonal risk factors-BBD risk association. This project will identify novel gut microbial and metabolomic markers that can advance future risk prediction of BBD, inform more effective microbiome-based interventions aimed at BBD risk reduction among high-risk women defined by their hormonal profiles, which ultimately will help reducing the growing burden of BBD and breast cancer-associated morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC), the most aggressive breast cancer subtype, affects about 20% of breast cancer patients and is disproportionately diagnosed in young, Black women. Researching how socio-structural determinants of health “above the skin” influence biological mechanisms “under the skin” could help to understand potential drivers of racial disparities in TNBC. This study focuses on how neighborhood-level redlining contributes to disparities in TNBC incidence through epigenetic changes and activation of oncogenic signaling pathways, leading to tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following changes in physical function and social roles and responsibilities after a cancer diagnosis, Asian Americans may self-perceive that they are a burden on family members, which is related to a lower quality of life and more distress and depression. Despite this, Asian American cancer patients utilize mental health services at lower rates than other groups and this may be due to a dearth of culturally-competent services. The goal of the project is to design and test the feasibility of two positive activity interventions, household contribution and outside contribution, intended to increase health-related quality of life in Asian American cancer patients by increasing a sense of relatedness, autonomy, and competence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer and its treatment during adolescence or early young adulthood potentially disrupts normal frontal neurodevelopment leading to cognitive dysfunction; however, sparse research on cognition in this vulnerable population has relied primarily on self-report, with limited data on objective cognitive deficits. In this innovative study, we propose to implement objective cognitive assessment in real-time in survivors’ daily life and measure situational, behavioral, and contextual risk factors. By tailoring the assessment methodology to young adult survivors, collecting pilot feasibility and acceptability data, then conducting a large, case-controlled study of cognition in young adult survivors and matched non-cancer controls, we will provide much-needed data on the prevalence of long-term cancer-related cognitive impairment and how to alleviate this problem in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Assessment of active pulmonary fibrosis, a progressive, fatal disease characterized by unrelenting scarring and stiffening of the lungs, is critical for appropriate therapeutic treatment. This project is relevant to public health as it aims to determine the capacity of a novel positron emission tomography (PET) probe to accurately detect pulmonary fibrosis disease activity in mice and chemically optimize it to enable future clinical translation. These studies will serve as a foundation for future clinical applications of this PET-based probe as a non-invasive method for assessment of activity for this deadly disease, in order to determine best treatment for patients, reduce their illness, and lengthen their lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer metastasis is a deadly, elusive, and heterogeneous disease which lacks effective targeted therapeutics, and understanding the mechanisms underlying cancer metastasis remains to be fully elucidated. RNA splicing lends to cellular complexity and heterogeneity by producing distinct RNA and protein isoforms from a single gene, and the dysregulation of RNA splicing has been implicated in cancer development and progression. This research proposal seeks to identify novel mechanisms in which dysregulated alternative splicing contributes to metastatic seeding and outgrowth in breast and other aggressive cancers, with the ultimate goal of identifying potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets of cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Metastasis is responsible for about 2/3 of cancer deaths. This proposal aims to improve the treatment outcome of metastatic cancer by enhancing the antitumor effect of radiation therapy through combination with agents that stimulate the host’s innate immunity. Completion of this project will open new possibilities of cancer immunotherapy to treat metastatic cancers.

ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed K01 application seeks to compare different dietary patterns and determine which ones may be better suited for diabetes prevention among high-risk acute pancreatitis (AP) patients in the NIH-funded Diabetes RElated to Acute Pancreatitis and its Mechanisms (DREAM) study. This study will provide a novel understanding of the critical role of different dietary patterns in preventing new-onset diabetes following AP. It also opens new potential avenues for research into the pathophysiological mechanisms by which dietary patterns affect this risk, as currently being investigated in the DREAM study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Although there is a high prevalence of substance use disorders (SUDs), including opioid use disorder (OUD), among people incarcerated in the US, only a small portion receive evidence-based treatment for SUDs, as well as screening and medication for OUD. This proposed K23 application involves career development training and a complementary research project incorporating implementation science methods to gain a comprehensive understanding of how an evidence-based digital therapeutic for substance use—Computer Based Training for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT4CBT)—could be effectively implemented as a treatment for incarcerated people with current OUD (primary), as well as other SUD(s).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K99/R00 Pathway to Independence Award seeks to provide training in parent-infant ECG/EEG, qualitative interviews of subjective experiences, multi-modal data integration (qualitative-quantitative, neuro-bio-behavior, longitudinal), advanced biostatistics, psychology and neuroscience to support the applicant’s transition to research independence. Through the training plan, the applicant will develop the skills and expertise necessary to establish a trans-disciplinary translational research program that integrates multiple novel subjective and biobehavioral measures into the study of human dyadic interactions, to uncover mechanisms of parent-child dyadic relational health – with a primary focus on emotional synchrony – that yield long-term health and wellbeing through optimized socioemotional functioning. This approach may lead to the development of precision interventions that improve socioemotional functioning based on deeply characterized emotional and biobehavioral processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Current targeted therapies for metastatic CRC patients show limited positive outcome, especially in KRAS*-driven metastatic CRC patients where KRAS* bypasses targeted therapies to activate downstream survival, proliferation and cell cycle progression signaling. Understanding the molecular and cellular biological mechanisms of CRC progression will ultimately lead to new targets to prevent or treat advanced disease and prolong survival of metastatic CRC patients. This proposal seeks to investigate 1) the interplay between KRAS*- driven cancer cells and carcinoma-associated stroma, and 2) the impact of telomere dynamics and associated genomic events that promote metastatic CRC, in order to precisely design new targeted therapies and further advance public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer continues to be a leading cause of death worldwide and the poor efficacy and toxicity of the available treatments are exemplified by the low survival rates and the severity of the side effects. The long-term goal of both the F99 and K00 phases of this work will be to reveal new strategies that lead to novel anti-cancer therapies. The F99 phase will be focused on a cell-intrinsic aspect of cancer biology, while the K00 phase will focus on an immune cell with great potential to directly inhibit tumor growth and to modulate the efficacy of already approved cancer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in key immune regulatory molecules are associated with autoimmunity; accordingly, targeting of these molecules pharmacologically have resulted in revolutionized cancer treatment in the shape of immune checkpoint immunotherapies. Thus, through the F99 phase I will characterize how loss of the autoimmune-related molecule PTPN22 in myeloid cells drives an augmented immune response against tumors. Subsequently, through the K00 phase I will identify novel autoimmune related SNPs correlating with tumor immune infiltration and characterize them in engineered conditional knockout mice to understand their contribution to tumor progression and immunotherapy efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative: Rare, recurrent genetic variants occur with enough frequency in the population and confers significant risk for neuropsychiatric disorders but these genetic variant’s don’t lead to the same disorders or the severity of the disorders in the people that have them. We need a better way to predict what the effect of these recurrent genetic changes will be on a particular individual. We will study one such change, the 15q13.3 deletion syndrome by looking at the lifetime health records of 200 individuals with this deletion, recruit 75 individuals for deeper characterization using well-validated tools, combine these data into a big dataset to train a predictive algorithm to correctly identify individuals with this deletion syndrome, and predict risk for psychiatric and other disorder presentation in these individuals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Black, Indigenous, People of Color (BIPOC) and Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer (LGBTQ+) communities experience disparities in the quality of mental health care. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunctional lipid accumulation is characteristic of numerous metabolic diseases and pathologies including insulin resistance, heart failure, and hepatic steatosis. Enhanced understanding of the molecular mechanisms controlling all aspects of lipid metabolism, such as phospholipid metabolism, holds great promise for the treatment of these diseases. This proposal seeks to understand the importance of FLVCR1 mediated phospholipid metabolism in organismal physiology and test the therapeutic potential of targeting FLVCR1 in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with comorbidity of diabetes mellitus and breast cancer have been shown to be at a greater risk of poor prognosis and death than non-diabetic patients. However, the interplay between tumor progression and diabetes is still mechanistically unclear. Noting that glycation stiffens tumor ECM and ECM stiffening promotes tumor progression, here, I will investigate the mechanism by which diabetic hyperglycemia-mediated glycation promotes breast tumor progression via ECM stiffening to uncover potential adjuvant therapy for diabetic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The study of neural-tumor cell interactions and how they contribute to glioma progression represents an emerging research paradigm in brain tumor biology. In my predoctoral studies, I will examine the contributions of synaptogenic genes towards disease progression via tumor-extrinsic synaptic dysregulation and hyperexcitability. In my postdoctoral studies, I will examine differences in tumor-intrinsic electrophysiological properties of glioma cells and investigate the functional contributions of those cells to the progression and evolution of malignant gliomas over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Highly aggressive forms of breast cancer cells produce and release exosomes, a major class of extracellular vesicles (EVs), as a mechanism for intercellular communication that promotes cell growth, therapy resistance, as well as invasive activity and metastasis. I have recently discovered a novel mechanism by which the downregulation of the NAD-dependent deacetylase Sirtuin 1 (SIRT1) in aggressive breast cancer cells regulates RNA stability, leading to the increased production of exosomes enriched in proteins that strongly promote cancer cell invasion. I plan to further examine the broader consequences of this mechanism, as well as investigate the importance of EVs in mediating the interplay between aging and cancer progression, with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets and strategies for treating cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Many pathogens live in the environment prior to encountering a mammalian host. As a result, human interactions with the environment can alter the population of pathogens we are likely to encounter and thus with which we are infected. This proposal aims to understand how heat tolerance and drug resistance are controlled by genetic variation at two different time scales (across a genus and within a species) of opportunistic environmental fungal pathogens in order to better predict how pathogens are likely to be altered by human activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project aims at identifying and characterizing human T cell genes/molecules that contribute to suppressing effective antitumor T cell responses by utilizing culturable human T cells and cancer cell lines. In the short term, the study will help identify novel and potentially druggable immunological molecules and pathways for improving current cancer immunotherapy. In the long term, the study will lay the groundwork for systematically dissecting the human genetic and immunological basis of exceptionally beneficial antitumor immunity evoked in a minority of cancer patients by current checkpoint blockade immunotherapy, which will in turn continuously benefit patients with a broad spectrum of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Despite the importance of intestinal neuroimmunity, little is known about the role of cholinergic innervation in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). In the proposed study, we will determine the mechanisms underlying the anti-inflammatory effect of enteric cholinergic signaling and will test the role of enteric cholinergic signaling using selective optogenetics in a model of chronic colitis that closely mirrors the pathophysiology of human IBD. To achieve these objectives, we will employ a variety of in vitro methodologies and in vivo models to elucidate the effects of cholinergic neuronal signaling on muscularis macrophages, inflammatory indices, transcriptomic changes, and smooth muscle contractility and motility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This K24 application aims to bolster my dual roles in advancing patient-oriented cardiovascular research and mentorship at Washington University in St. Louis. The research leverages the NHLBI-funded Hypertension Treatment in Nigeria Program, one of Africa's largest hypertension control programs, by focusing on mediation of team-based care and patient retention and re-engagement using advanced implementation science methods. This application also includes a comprehensive, integrated mentorship training approach designed to elevate my capacity, skills, and leadership to support US and international early-stage investigators who will become the next generation’s leaders in global cardiovascular patient-oriented research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Eosinophils are a key type of white blood cell in allergic disease that were historically characterized as only promoting inflammation, but compelling evidence is emerging that eosinophils have a variety of functions in distinct tissue environments. This proposal will research the range of eosinophil functions during allergic disease, which may improve the understanding of how eosinophil-depleting drugs affect human health. This work may substantially expand the role of eosinophils to include resolving allergic inflammation and may inform strategies to bring personalized and predictive medicine to the treatment of allergic, inflammatory, and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Climate change is the largest public health threats in the 21st century, with rising global temperatures particularly harming the kidneys of individuals in high-heat environments. Bridging data science insights on the link between heatwaves and kidney disease hospitalization with community engagement is crucial for preparing communities to effectively respond to escalating temperatures. By employing the knowledge-to-action framework, this work aims to unite data science and community wisdom, laying the foundation for community-level interventions that mitigate morbidity and mortality stemming from heat-induced kidney issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Once cognitive impairment occurs in an individual with Alzheimer’s disease, it is difficult to modify the devastating disease process. The long-term goal of this project is to develop a non-invasive tool that can visualize and quantify microstructural brain changes during the preclinical stage of Alzheimer’s disease. To this end, Dr. Yuto Uchida will conduct a proof-of-concept study to investigate the feasibility of ultra-high-field quantitative magnetic resonance imaging as a sensitive biomarker for neurodegeneration in preclinical Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioids are important pain medications, but chronic opioid use in a particular environment can produce tolerance that is associated with that environment. However, when opioids are consumed in a different place, tolerance can be reversed rapidly, which can lead to fatal overdose. This proposal will explore the contributions of brain and spinal circuits to this environmental control of analgesic tolerance to help inform the development of new treatments aimed at decreasing pain and opioid overdose.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with lupus nephritis (LN) frequently suffer from life-threatening clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) events, that can lead to devastating health consequences, such as stroke, lifelong paralysis, heart failure, and premature mortality; yet ASCVD preventive strategies are underutilized in LN. Therefore, the proposed work will develop two ASCVD preventive interventions: 1) an implementation guide to help clinicians tailor and start ASCVD preventive strategies by individual patient’s risk; 2) a shared decision-making tool to support patients and clinicians in decisions to start lifesaving ASCVD preventive strategies in LN. Finally, a pilot test will be done to examine the effectiveness and adoption of these ASCVD interventions during LN visits to inform a future multisite clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The new therapies for dementia come with trade-offs, this project aims to develop a decision aid (DA) regarding dementia care to support shared decision making. A DA could facilitate higher quality discussions to assure that patients wanting this therapy are fully informed regarding the potential benefits and harms. Using an iterative, user-centered approach with multilevel partner input, we will conduct a needs assessment among patients and clinicians while simultaneously developing and piloting a DA to support patients and families making decisions about medications for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative. Late talking bilingual children have atypically small vocabularies in both their languages, and it is unclear how they leverage the words they know to build their vocabularies from dual language input. Therefore, the primary objective of this proposal is to examine interactions between dual language input, semantic structure, and word learning in typically developing and late talking bilingual toddlers. Elucidating relationships between these factors is critical to identifying sources of variability in language outcomes and to developing language interventions for bilingual children with language disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE. Our proposal addresses a large longitudinal data base on young patients with juvenile-onset depression (JOD), which reflects JOD’s course and outcome from childhood until young adulthood, followed under the auspices of 4 NIMH-funded projects, all of which are in the process of being archived in NIMH’s National Data Archives (NDA). Our aim is to develop prototype machine learning algorithms (which can be customized as needed) to facilitate the analyses of these longitudinal data, with a focus on predictors of clinical and functional outcomes of JOD. Our project will yield developmentally based findings about outcome predictors that can inform the prevention and treatment of JOD, a. particularly severe depression phenotype, and may also shift current analytic practices in developmental psychopathology research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to create a series of new statistical methods to help us better utilize genetic scores in the study of the causes behind intricate human diseases. It will incorporate multi-omics data to facilitate molecularly- informed disease pathways and assess the impact of each pathway on the disease, and also use family-based studies to provide unbiased investigations of how multiple correlated environmental factors or biomarkers influence diseases. It will further provide easy-to-use software tools and a summary statistics database for researchers to analyze large-scale multi-modal data to accelerate future research, enabling a more comprehensive and unbiased understanding of how molecular changes contribute to human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Disorders in inferring and acting according to context as well as in learning how to behave in new contexts are implicated in numerous neurological disorders, including post-traumatic stress disorder, schizophrenia, and addictive behavior. The neural representations that support reliable contextual behavior are not well-understood, which complicates the development of specific behavioral and pharmacological interventions. This proposal will reveal the neural representations that underlie the learning and performance of contextual behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The lymphatic system is essential for regulating fluid and maintaining tissue water balance, and its dysfunction can result in significant edema. Commonly used anesthetics may impact the lymphatic system and contribute to dangerous edema in critical illness, but this remains largely unexplored. The goal of this research project is to understand how anesthetic medications interact with the lymphatic system, with the potential to guide safer medication choices and improve patient outcomes in surgeries and intensive care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The skin is our body’s first line of defense from external stressors, such as pathogens or physical injuries. Under normal condition, a tight equilibrium between different cells composing the skin is necessary to avoid inflammatory diseases. This proposal employs a multidisciplinary and innovative approach to elucidate how cooperation between different cells maximizes the ability of the skin to protect us against environmental stressors and tumor formation. These studies may reveal novel and specific targets for treatment of wound healing, inflammatory disorders or cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autistic sexual and gender minority adults are at high risk for co-occurring mental health conditions including depression, anxiety, and suicide attempts and require a psychosocial intervention tailored for their unique needs. This research involves developing and piloting a novel community-based minority stress intervention for autistic sexual and gender minority individuals. The emphasis on preparing for future adaptive interventions and on safe, ethical research with a population at heightened risk for suicide will make significant contributions to the autism research field and will promote the ultimate goal of improved psychosocial functioning and mental health in the autistic community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to identify broad-specificity phage-recombination systems that can facilitate straightforward and efficient genome editing across a diverse spectrum of human pathogens. This approach offers an innovative means of pinpointing the genetic determinants of bacterial pathogenicity. By comprehending how a bacterium's genetic makeup determines its capacity to cause disease, we can uncover novel strategies to counteract bacterial threats to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Adoptive T cell therapy (ACT) has had limited success against pancreatic cancer, because of the T-cell intrinsic epigenomic programs and the tumor microenvironment (TME) suppressive factors that limit their anti-tumor functional status. Using single-cell and spatial omics, the proposed research will identify strategies that improve the anti-tumor activities of ACT T cells in TME. The proposed project will clarify the fundamental knowledge of the ACT for pancreatic cancer and will ultimately lead to more effective therapy for pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Problem substance use is a significant issue for many contemporary Indigenous communities, both reservation-based and urban, and opioid misuse is especially disproportionate among Indigenous young adults (ages 18-29) throughout the state of Montana, despite the fact that Indigenous communities hold traditional knowledge and tools, including traditional ceremonial practices (TCPs), that could be wielded to stem the tide of problem substance use. By obtaining community guidance on the rigorous adaptation of an existing evidence-based substance abuse prevention intervention to incorporate TCPs we can develop an effective, sustainable, and culturally centered approach aimed at reducing opioid misuse among urban Indigenous young adults. Once obtained, evidence of effectiveness of this approach can be used to more broadly inform public policy and, especially, expand reimbursement for these services by public and private payors to enhance their sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Violation of our predictions about the world impact our affective state and when this happens repeatedly this may lead to increased or decreased moods. By changing the context of prediction violations, I aim to establish the neural mechanisms of mood-like states and to then non-invasively modulate these mechanisms to alter mood- like states. Specifically, by combining neurophysiology with computational modelling and focused ultrasound, this proposal has the unique potential to causally establish single-neuron and population activity associated with mood-like states in primate brain circuits that can be directly translated into novel treatments in the clinics for patients with depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amblyopia is the leading cause of preventable vision loss among children in the United States and is disproportionately more prevalent among children from historically marginalized communities. This project aims to identify vision screening policy characteristics that increase the receipt of screening among socioeconomically disadvantaged children, determine how household- and neighborhood-level factors influence access to eye specialty care, and develop prediction models that can identify children at risk of preventable vision loss. Results from these investigations will increase domain knowledge in the social determinants of vision health in children and enable the design of novel interventions to improve vision health equity in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain unduly burdens Black adults across the lifespan, yet a dearth of studies focus on the pain characteristics, treatment experiences, and support needs of young Black adults. Supporting young Black adults with managing their own pain is key for reducing the impact of pain, but self-management education programs are criticized for cultural incongruence, inattention to the social determinants of health that increase pain in Black adults, and they commonly exclude mind-body therapies that reduce pain and improve psychological comorbidities. The proposed project will culturally and structurally adapt the evidence-based Chronic Pain Self-Management Program (CPSMP) for young Black adults to improve their self-management competency and improve pain outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood pressure control and physical activity in the first months after a stroke are known to reduce the risk of a second stroke and improve recovery, but effective interventions and strategies to promote these factors are lacking, particularly for ethno-racial minorities. We hypothesize that repetitive learning through self-monitoring and motivational feedback with patient-tailored infographics can improve these preventive health behaviors through enhanced self-regulation. Therefore, in alignment with the NINDS mission to reduce the burden of neurological disease for all people, we will develop and test a scalable patient-centered telehealth-delivered behavioral intervention for secondary stroke prevention in our underserved urban population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Signaling pathways are reused in multiple contexts from disease states, to development, to tissue homeostasis. Using a multidisciplinary approach, this proposal will establish how the context and dynamics of BMP signaling lead to the correct cellular outputs at the level of gene expression. The quantitative input- output signaling relationships identified in this study may provide useful information for the use of BMPs as therapeutics or in the use of BMP molecules to promote robust cellular differentiation for regenerative biology applications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) experienced during pregnancy and the postpartum period can have a profound effect on an individual’s mental and physical health. There is a critical need to engage Black women and rural-dwelling women in perinatal PTSD treatment as they are often the most likely to experience trauma exposure and subsequent PTSD symptoms, yet rarely receive targeted PTSD treatment; engaging perinatal individuals in PTSD treatment is critical as there are serious risks associated with untreated perinatal PTSD that often extend into the next generation. The proposed study (the New Empowerment after eXposure to Trauma (NEXT) Study) will evaluate the acceptability and feasibility of a brief perinatal PTSD intervention specifically targeting engagement and retention of Black women and rural-dwelling women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the World Health Organization's projections, by the year 2050, approximately 2.5 billion individuals are expected to experience varying degrees of hearing impairment, rendering sensorineural hearing loss and associated suprathreshold hearing disorders such as hyperacusis a significant healthcare problem. Recent research of neurodegenerative disorders and hearing loss suggests that in addition to neuronal factors, non-neuronal entities, particularly perineuronal nets (PNNs) and microglia, could play crucial roles in the pathogenesis of these disorders. PNN degradation and activated microglia are proposed as key contributors to central auditory neuron dysfunction after hearing loss, offering potential targets for therapeutic interventions to alleviate hearing loss and central gain disorders in the auditory cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Elder mistreatment among ADRD caregivers remains understudied, in part because no measures of mistreatment exist which are tailored to this unique population. The proposed project seeks to iteratively develop a new measure of elder mistreatment among ADRD caregiver, grounded in user-centered design, soliciting feedback from caregivers and geriatric professionals at all stages of development and validation. The ultimate goals of this project are to create a measure which will advance the understanding of the rates of mistreatment among dementia family caregivers and identify factors related to rates of mistreatment among ADRD caregivers to inform future intervention development to reduce EM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Depression and anxiety are common among patients with cardiovascular disease (CVD) or diabetes mellitus (DM), having detrimental impact on these chronic conditions. This project will identify symptomatic issues, care needs, and at-risk subgroups of depression and anxiety in CVD and DM patients by analyzing patient portal messages and electronic health records using large language models and machine learning algorithms, approaches that can overcome the current multilayer barriers to timely detection. The findings will contribute to the preparation of targeted and tailored interventions, ultimately improving mental health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is no publicly available health economic model of therapeutic strategies in hemophilia A. Published models are limited by study heterogeneity, industry sponsorship, and lack of public availability. Using microsimulation, equity impact, value of information, and pharmacoepidemiologic analyses, the applicant will quantify the risks, benefits, and costs of time-variant prophylactic strategies in hemophilia A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite extensive characterization, we struggle to understand and control the progression of human-associated microbial communities, including bacterial vaginosis (BV), a condition that is directly impactful to women’s health and the acquisition of sexually transmitted infections. This proposal investigates single-cell genomic and transcriptomic heterogeneity as two underexplored areas that impact the progression of BV. This intellectually and methodologically innovative research will transform our understanding of the development, treatment, and recurrence of BV and will provide broad-reaching insights into new strategies to prevent and treat polymicrobial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Human-induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have enormous potential for generating a variety of cell types for cell therapy but are impeded by the tumorigenic risk of residual iPSCs in cell mixtures during differentiation. The proposed study aims to develop new peptide assemblies to selectively eliminate unwanted human iPSCs in cell mixtures for cell therapy. The success of this project will ensure the safety of cell therapy, thereby enhancing the treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is a leading cause of human skin infections and colonizes up to 90% of itchy skin lesions in patients with Atopic Dermatitis. This proposal will investigate the role of S. aureus itch and neuro-immune signaling in driving skin damage and immune responses. These studies will reveal novel mechanisms of itch, inflammation, and neuron signaling and further our understanding of how microbes contribute to Atopic Dermatitis pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Peter Abadir, MD is a Geriatrician at Johns Hopkins University whose research and clinical focus for the past 15 years has been on the molecular mechanisms underlying age-related physical and cognitive decline. This career development award will provide him with additional training and protected time to identify, recruit, and mentor young, motivated scholars, and to undertake rigorous training. His development plans include educa- tion and mentorship in patient-oriented research, with a focus on using various sensors and artificial intelli- gence tools to identify and predict outcomes in frail older individuals, as well as linking these outcomes to mo- lecular biomarkers that underlie Frailty and Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging-associated somatic mutational spectra are a record of an organism’s lifelong attempts to maintain cellular homeostasis. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Kleefstra Syndrome is a rare genetic neurodevelopmental syndrome resulting from EHMT1 gene haploinsufficiency, presenting with intellectual disability, developmental delay, facial features, and childhood hypotonia, often co-occurring with autism spectrum disorders. Studying the impact of EHMT1 genomic variants on its protein structure and function is crucial for advancing our understanding of Kleefstra Syndrome and potentially improving therapies to benefit affected patients. Ultimately, these findings may have broader relevance for addressing neurodevelopmental disorders, enhancing public health efforts in this field.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction (MD) is common to several human diseases including non-alcoholic liver disease and diabetes as well as aging and age-related diseases. Currently, the role of MD in the etiology of such diseases has not been clearly determined. The purpose of this proposal is to characterize a new mouse model where we can finely tune MD in single tissues at specific developmental stages to more accurately investigate how single tissues react and cope with MD in health and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The spatial and temporal coordination of gene transcription is crucial to ensure that fundamental biological processes, such as embryonic development, are successfully orchestrated, thereby allowing for the normal functioning of an organism. By leveraging an endemic group of pupfishes from the Bahamas, which exhibit extremely divergent craniofacial morphologies, I propose a multi-omics approach to unravel and functionally test the gene networks and regulatory regions of the genome controlling changes in gene expression underlying their naturally divergent craniofacial development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children born very preterm are at increased risk for poor neurodevelopmental outcomes including specific deficits in attention and executive function that may limit their long-term health and potential. This proposal aims to understand whether variations in caregiving quality (e.g., caregiver sensitivity and structuring) are associated with attention and executive function outcomes in very preterm children at school age, a critical yet understudied developmental period. The knowledge to be gained from this proposal has direct public health benefits as it could improve identification of preterm children at highest risk for cognitive deficits and provide information regarding modifiable caregiver behaviors that could serve as future intervention targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Polyploid cancer cells have emerged as a dangerous subpopulation of tumor cells but remain poorly characterized. This proposal seeks to identify genes that allow this subpopulation to arise and form daughter cells and to use archived, de-identified samples from ovarian cancer will be analyzed for putative markers of polyploid cancer cells. Results from this project serve as a foundation for detection of polyploid cancer cells in cancer specimen and to develop novel therapies aimed at eliminating this population or the formation of daughter cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Patients who develop sepsis-associated acute kidney injury have high rates of morbidity and mortality and there are no effective treatment options for this disease. We will prospectively enroll critically ill children and leverage multiple clinical trials of critically ill adults and children to further investigate a potential mechanism (complement activation) that causes this disease and gain mechanistic insight into site and extent of complement activation. This proposal will inform future clinical trials in critically ill children and adults with sepsis by identifying treatment windows and stratification levels for predictive enrichment for a future interventional trial testing a therapeutic complement inhibitor.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Career Development Award proposal centers around examination of how thermal stress affects arbovirus- vector-host interactions, with a focus on antiviral immunity and inflammation in the host. The objectives of this study are to (1) develop a Chiropteran model for assessing innate immunity and inflammasome activation in bats exposed to thermal stress; (2) characterize host-vector interactions and host immune response following intradermal inoculation of bats with mosquito salivary gland extract (3) quantify ZIKV infection dynamics at different temperatures in bat cell lines. The anticipated results will contribute to ecoimmunology and arbovirology studies by expanding our understanding of how heat stress impacts bat immunology and the dynamics of arbovirus- vector-host interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: ImmunoPET is an emerging non-invasive imaging technique that can fulfill the promise of in vivo pathology assessment. This proposal leverages advances in lipid nanoparticle technology to synthesize immunoPET probes with optimized pharmacokinetics and to identify the ideal LNP administration strategy in patients. Successful execution of this project will lead to a revolutionary, streamlined and modular platform for immunoPET molecular imaging/therapy that is immediately testable in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research addresses a significant health inequity among children (asthma morbidity) with innovative approaches and will result in a sophisticated machine learning model to identify children at highest risk of morbidity, an engaged community advisory board of caregivers of children with asthma, and critical pilot data on the feasibility and acceptability of an integrated social and asthma care intervention. This work aligns with the NHLBI’s Objective 3 (understanding causes of and identifying strategies to effectively address population health disparities) and 7 (leveraging emerging opportunities in data science to open new frontiers in heart, lung, blood, and sleep disorders). The results of this proposal may enable early identification of children with asthma at risk for hospitalization and a family-centered and caregiver-endorsed integrated social and asthma care intervention which, when paired together, has the potential to improve health equity and reduce morbidity among children with asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Associations between malaria-transmitting Anopheles mosquitoes and Wolbachia bacteria are both rare in nature and challenging to establish in laboratory settings, precluding the utility of Wolbachia in malaria control. It is not understood why Anopheles seem to be largely incompatible with Wolbachia infections, despite these bacteria infecting an estimated 60% of insect species, including many other mosquitoes. In this proposal, I outline a plan to investigate the basis of this incompatibility and overcome it, while simultaneously pursuing an alternate use of Wolbachia-induced Cytoplasmic Incompatibility in a gene drive approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions globally are at risk of nutritional stress and these external signals serve as a potent regulator of human physiology and pathophysiology. It is largely unknown why sickle cell disease (SCD) presents with variable severity between patients. As much of the pathology in SCD is driven by neutrophils, we aim to evaluate how nutritional stress regulates neutrophils development, function, and contribution to SCD severity, with applications to other neutrophil-driven diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disorders are common, affecting 3% of the global population; these conditions include global developmental delay/intellectual disability, epilepsy, and autism spectrum disorder and are collectively associated with significant healthcare costs for the many children and families affected. Interneuronopathies are becoming more widely recognized as an important cause of neurodevelopmental disorders, with Fragile X and autism both associated with interneuron impairment. This K08 proposal will elucidate both the mechanism and the timeline during which EIF4A2, a DEAD-box encoding gene and novel regulator of interneurons, alters interneuron development, providing direction for future investigations of interneuron-targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Remote patient monitoring (RPM) data provides an opportunity to evaluate disease activity and progression and inform management, however the volume of data exceeds clinicians’ cognitive capacity. Clinical decision support (CDS) tools can address this issue by automating data processing and making the information available and actionable at the point of care. The proposed studies align with NHLBI priorities to leverage data science and optimize implementation research, and further aim to improve interstitial lung disease (ILD) care delivery and outcomes by: (1) identifying provider and health-system level barriers to a CDS tool informed by RPM data, (2) evaluating the performance of ILD-risk classification algorithms using RPM data (3) piloting an RPM-informed CDS tool to evaluate its implementation and effectiveness potential in ILD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative Liver fibrosis, as a result of many chronic liver diseases, leads to liver decompensation and liver-related mortality. During liver injury, the hepatic stellate cells (HSCs), also known as perisinusoidal cells, transdifferentiate into proliferative, fibrogenic myoﬁbroblasts which are the primary source of liver fibrosis. The role of autophagy, a highly conserved cell degradation pathway, in HSC activation is ambiguous. We propose to revisit the role of autophagy in HSC activation and fibrogenesis using novel autophagy and metabolic assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Cannabis use is on the rise, yet pregnant people and parents may not be aware of the potential risks to their children. Our study will examine when and how early-life exposure to cannabis impacts childhood adiposity and cardiometabolic health. It is hoped that our study will add to the limited data on this topic and help to spur widespread public health messaging about the potential risks of using cannabis while pregnant.

PHR: Systemic inequities permeate all aspects of society and negatively impacts the work environment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibody and antibody fusion protein therapies may halt loss of endogenous insulin production in recently- diagnosed Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) through Fc gamma receptor (FcγR)-associated mechanisms. The goals of this proposal are: 1) to identify genetic variants in FcγR loci that associate with therapeutic efficacy in completed T1D immunotherapy trials and 2) to evaluate the impact of associated loci on FcγR protein expression and function. These studies are expected to aid in generation of a precision medicine strategy to target subjects with or at-risk for T1D who may benefit from immunotherapies with FcγR-associated mechanisms of action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The discordance between pain presentation and structural damage in knee osteoarthritis is a crucial issue that hampers both effective clinical management and the development of disease-modifying therapies. This is in part related to different pain phenotypes (nociceptive, nociplastic and neuropathic-like) underlying the chronic pain experience. This proposal investigates the relationship between pain phenotypes and structural damage in knee osteoarthritis.
