IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintaining clarity of vision is one of the most important tasks performed by the visual system. This is achieved through the oculomotor process of accommodation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The offspring of parents with major depression have a very high risk of developing mood disorders and other psychopathology themselves. The neurobiological and genetic mechanisms that lead to their vulnerability or resilience remain unclear. Leveraging a unique translational approach with hypotheses generated from rodent studies applied to highly characterized clinical studies and then extended to large diverse population samples, this proposal will investigate hippocampal, genetic and childhood environmental factors that predict onset of depression in children at high risk for mood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  During development, each olfactory sensory neuron needs to choose a single odorant receptor (Or) out of a large family of similar genes, and previous research in mice (which have >1,000 Ors) and flies (which have 60 Ors) produced an idea that large Or families employ stochastic gene choice, while small Or families follow deterministic specification. The jumping ant Harpegnathos saltator lies in between these extremes, possessing 376 Or genes, most of which are not interspersed throughout the genome, but located within tandem genomic arrays that contain up to tens of genes. In this proposal, I will test a model where each olfactory neuron in ants expresses a single locus, either a single gene or an array, using the same deterministic mechanism as Drosophila, followed by a novel mechanism of stochastic promoter choice within the arrays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. Petruzzi is a clinical social worker and health equity researcher who focuses on healthcare access disparities and social work intervention efficacy. The overall purpose of this Career Development Award is to provide Dr. Petruzzi with the training, career development, and mentorship necessary to become an independent, intervention researcher that develops, measures, and implements culturally adapted interventions that simultaneously address the mental health and social needs of underserved Latina women. The specific aims of this proposal are to 1) conduct a community assessment to identify the mental health and social needs of Latina women and inform the development of a culturally adapted intervention; 2) to combine and culturally adapt two, evidence based interventions (problem-solving therapy and patient navigation) for Latinas to improve perinatal mental health; and 3) conduct a feasibility study to assess the acceptability and feasibility of the culturally adapted intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States has one of the highest incarceration rates and releases over 7 million individuals from jails and prisons annually. This project aims to develop a robust methodology for identifying incarcerated individuals within large healthcare databases, enabling a comprehensive examination of their surgical care. Despite their constitutional right to healthcare, minimal data on the disparities in the surgical care of incarcerated individuals is available, and ultimately, this endeavor holds the potential to catalyze broader healthcare improvements, reducing illness and disability within this marginalized community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Inflammation is thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of major depressive disorder (MDD), but the exact immunoregulatory mechanisms are not well understood. This proposal will leverage an ongoing experimental medicine study using lipopolysaccharide to compare immune mechanisms and regulation of the toll-like receptor 4 inflammatory pathway in MDD and healthy participants in both the blood and the brain. The results may provide a roadmap for understanding how the immune system is dysregulated in MDD and for the identification of novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Innate lymphoid cells reside on the mucosal surface and orchestrate tissue homeostasis; however, their regulatory mechanisms and clinical significance in intestinal inflammation remain unclear. Here, we intend to unravel the mechanistic role of IRE1α-XBP1-mediated endoplasmic reticulum stress in innate lymphoid cells and their implications in inflammatory bowel disease, using a comprehensive approach involving multicellular organoid culture, mouse models, and human samples. After completion of these studies, I anticipate I will be well-prepared to establish an independent research program and be highly competitive for R-series grants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative. While alcohol misuse remains a leading cause of preventable death and disability, non-alcoholic beverages that seek to mimic alcohol (e.g., non-alcoholic beers, non-alcoholic wines, non-alcoholic liquor, and “mocktails”) are drastically increasing in popularity, especially among people who consume alcohol. This project will examine whether non-alcoholic beverage consumption helps to reduce alcohol use or paradoxically stimulate it. Clarifying the potential utility of non-alcoholic beverages and whether their effects differ based on alcohol use history will ultimately inform clinical recommendations for people with alcohol use disorder and public health messaging at large.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cardiovascular (CV) toxicities from common cancer therapies (trastuzumab, anthracyclines, or left chest radiation) can lead to cardiovascular disease (heart failure, myocardial infarction, and stroke) and are more common among marginalized racial and ethnic groups, and those with adverse social determinants of health (SDOH) such as lower levels of socioeconomic status and living in disadvantaged neighborhoods or rural areas. Yet, the role of complex SDOH in CV toxicity disparities among breast cancer survivors is unknown, and few studies have considered the intersections among race, ethnicity, and other SDOH. This K01 aims to: 1) identify the extent of disparities in incident CV toxicity among breast cancer survivors in Arkansas based on race, ethnicity, neighborhood socioeconomic status, and geography; and 2) develop a predictive algorithm for risk stratification in breast cancer survivors at high risk for CV toxicity using machine-learning approaches that incorporate race, ethnicity, and SDOH to move beyond describing disparities in CV toxicities to informing targeted interventions to improve the CV health of breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will provide insight into how the potent sex-steroid hormone 17-estradiol (E2) controls gene expression programs in a cell-type specific manner in the hippocampus, a brain region important for learning and memory whose function is compromised during aging and in certain mental health disorders. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will improve our understanding of the neurobiological underpinnings that support healthy cognitive function, and inform the development of sex-specific therapeutic intervention strategies to treat neuropsychiatric disorders influenced by the hormonal milieu. Moreover, this work is particularly relevant to the NIMH’s first Strategic Objective (Strategy 1.1) which seeks to define cellular and molecular gene regulatory mechanisms relevant to cognitive function and mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: This project will develop new statistical methods for evaluating the causal effects of bundled (multi- component) treatment. The methods will help in understanding the mechanisms by which complex interventions affect dental outcomes, including behaviors such as taking children to the dentist. The methods may also help in formulating new treatments and predicting their effects. The statistical methods will be applied to real data from a recently completed randomized clinical trial of a multi- component intervention to improve dental care usage and dental caries outcomes. This research will thus yield new statistical methods and knowledge that may lead to improved study designs and predictions of new treatment effects, and ultimately, better health care and dental outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Severe trauma followed by hemorrhagic shock (T/HS) through cell priming mechanisms predisposes patients to infection with sepsis being a prominent contributor to late death in these patients. Few specific targets linking T/HS to elevated risk of sepsis have been identified since the mechanisms of T/HS-primed infection remain unclear. This proposal is to investigate a novel mechanism underlying T/HS-predisposed sepsis, in which T/HS-induced arachidonic acid (AA) metabolite-lipoxygenase feedback loop causes macrophage death and dysfunction, and therefore, subsequent augmented infection and organ injury. Furthermore, this study will test new therapeutic potential to improve the outcomes of post-T/HS infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE High blood pressure is estimated to cost the United States 131 to 198 billion dollars annually. High blood pressure is one of the most influential risk factors for cardiovascular disease, which is a leading cause of death in the United States. Despite increased knowledge, awareness and uptake in hypertensive medications, racial/ethnic disparities in hypertension persist. Physical activity (PA) is a key, modifiable lifestyle modification that can improve BP outcomes and reduce hypertension risk. Yet, uptake of PA remains low among Black women. We propose to test the proof-of-concept of a technology-delivered mindful walking intervention among Black women with hypertension to increase PA and reduce BP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  One of the devastating, yet understudied outcomes of stroke is a persistent deterioration of cognitive abilities in stroke survivors. Previous studies and my preliminary data suggest that transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) indicate that this non-invasive brain stimulation methodology may provide an important therapeutic approach to combat post-stroke cognitive impairment. Further, my research proposal will explore understudied mechanisms by which tDCS exerts its effect on cognitive function in stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with suspected breast cancer in low- and middle-income countries often face delayed diagnosis due to systemic barriers, leading to worse outcomes compared to developed countries. To fill this gap, we will determine whether a portable diagnostic kit for breast cancer that merges point-of-care technologies in both ultrasound imaging and molecular/cellular pathology can mitigate these barriers to timely diagnosis. The portable diagnostic kit will be deployed in clinical settings for women with breast cancer —first in U.S.-based settings, then in the intended population in Uganda— and evaluated against gold standard methods for the ability to visualize breast tumors and characterize their cellular/molecular pathology to guide treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Investigating predictors of smoking cessation and relapse in socioeconomically disadvantaged young adults (SDYA) who smoke is of critical public health importance due to the disproportionately higher rates of smoking and tobacco-related disease and illness among SDYA in the U.S. The goal of this MOSAIC K99/R00 application is to understand the impact of social-contextual stressors on psychopharmacological mechanisms of smoking cessation and relapse experienced in real-time among 100 SDYA who smoke and are willing to make a serious quit attempt in the next 30 days. Identifying event-level predictors that lead to smoking relapse in SDYA can inform the development of tailored smoking cessation interventions that address and ameliorate these barriers to cessation for SDYA, which may contribute to reducing tobacco-related health disparities in this high-risk group.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Access to gender affirming medical care in adolescence is considered standard of care by all major national medical associations in the United States. Despite evidence of improved mental health outcomes and medical consensus that gender affirming care is medically necessary, many state level policies restrict or ban medical care for transgender youth. We propose to determine the feasibility of a longitudinal, mixed methods study that explores the psychosocial, mental health, and physical health outcomes of these policies for transgender and gender diverse youth in preparation for a future R01.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to identify novel modifiable behavioral targets to improve treatment outcomes in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), as only 40% of those treated with a first-line treatment remit, and 59% of those who remit subsequently relapse. Based on accumulating evidence implicating delayed circadian rhythms in OCD, the proposed project will test the efficacy of light therapy (including morning bright light and evening dim light) for OCD in adults with OCD+delayed bedtimes and examine photic sensitivity and habitual light exposure patterns in adults with OCD+delayed bedtimes compared to healthy controls. This project will provide me with training in the necessary clinical translational sleep and circadian medicine skills for a long- term research program in understanding the role of delayed circadian rhythms in OCD etiology and developing a novel, scalable treatment that can be easily incorporated into existing first-line treatments to improve treatment outcomes in OCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Classically, the role that the homeostatic baroreflex plays in the development of cardiovascular disease has been questionable, due to the lack of tools that selectively target arterial baroreceptors. We have developed a novel approach to selectively target arterial baroreceptors that innervate the aortic arch. Our goal is to utilize this approach to revisit the role that the baroreflex plays in the development of hypertension.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is the leading global cause of maternal death, leading to more than 200 deaths per day. Uterine atony, weak and insufficient uterine contraction after delivery, causes about 80% of PPH. This project will provide important insights into how the uterus normally contracts after delivery and what goes wrong in cases of uterine atony, knowledge that may facilitate development of new treatments for uterine atony and PPH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric brain MRI is essential to accurately diagnose, monitor, and treat pediatric brain tumors. However, the current practice carries risks, including a long-term detrimental risk to a child's cognitive development posed by repeated sedation and neurotoxic properties from gadolinium-based contrast agent (GBCA) injections. This proposal aims to develop a versatile motion-robust quantitative magnetic resonance imaging (qMRI) protocol, eliminate redundancies in MRI exams, generate full-dose post-contrast images from low-dose qMRI acquisition, evaluate the diagnostic equivalency and image quality of standardized contrast-weighted images generated from biophysical tissue parameter maps, and clinically deploy the developed technology for pediatric patients with brain tumors. The new qMRI protocol will reduce the scan time, mitigate the sensitivity to motion degradation, and allow us to establish the feasibility of mitigating long-term cognitive effects and gadolinium deposition in the brain and body by reducing the need for sedation and the amount of GBCAs, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Prostate cancer (PCa) is the most common non-cutaneous cancer in U.S. men and causes significant short- and long-term sexual side effects (i.e., sexual dysfunction) in up to 90% of patients. Although multiple evidence-based therapies for sexual dysfunction (e.g., psychotherapy, medications, surgery) exist, many PCa patients face significant barriers to communicating with their providers about sexual dysfunction, which impairs sexual recovery. We propose to rigorously adapt and pilot test an evidence-based sexual health communication skills training intervention for PCa patients to improve patient-provider communication about sexual health in PCa care and, thereby, facilitate improved sexual recovery and sexual health outcomes among PCa patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Body positivity, the promotion and acceptance of diverse body sizes and appearances, is one approach to mitigating weight stigma, which is associated with depression, anxiety, disordered eating, reduced physical activity, and weight gain. Latinx adolescents have higher rates obesity than their white counterparts and are at risk of experiencing multiple forms of stigmatization. This study will assess the impact of a social media campaign that promotes body positivity on weight stigma and mental health among Latinx youth, compared to a control campaign.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mutation of the ATP2C1 gene has been linked to Hailey-Hailey disease, an incurable dermatologic condition that causes recurrent, painful skin blisters but lacks any approved therapies. This disorder primarily affects keratinocytes, disrupting adhesion between these cells within the epidermis, which compromises skin tissue integrity and permits cutaneous infections. In this project, we leveraged gene editing to generate human keratinocytes having the ATP2C1 gene deleted to establish a laboratory model of Hailey-Hailey disease that we will use to identify new treatment strategies for this rare disorder.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It remains unclear whether controlling blood glucose levels among individuals with gestational diabetes can mitigate the risk of obesity in their children and how the neighborhood environment may contribute to this relation. The proposed research applies a unique multilevel lens to understand the interrelationships between neighborhood- and individual-level factors and blood glucose levels during pregnancy and their role in childhood obesity development. This project will better inform clinical and public health recommendations and interventions with an ultimate goal to improve the health of pregnant individuals and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Co-morbid Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) increases risk for Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) and unique genetic factors may contribute to AUD risk depending on MDD status. Furthermore, men and women display disparate patterns of temporal development of AUD with co-morbid MDD and their genetic liabilities for the disorders may be different. This project therefore proposes a plan of research considering innovative models to analyze sex-specific genetic and environmental effects on AUD at the item level to contribute to filling the current gap in scientific understanding of the mechanisms by which MDD and sex effects interact with common variants genetic signal to predispose to AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune-based therapies have transformed the treatment of many hematologic malignancies, but such approaches have had limited success for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), an aggressive hematologic malignancy that remains fatal in nearly half of diagnosed cases. However, there is great potential for T cell- based immunotherapeutic approaches for treating AML given (1) studies demonstrating impaired T cell immunity in AML patients, (2) clinical data illustrating correlation between the bone marrow immune landscape and treatment responses to both chemotherapy and immunotherapy, and (3) the curative potential of allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation for AML arising from the immune-mediated graft-versus-leukemia activity of donor T cells. The goal of this study is to perform deep analysis of T cells in parallel with surrounding populations in the bone marrow, the site where AML emerges, to elucidate key mechanisms driving T cell functional responses to AML longitudinally, and to identify immunologic targets for potential therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent meta-analyses have shown that women with sickle cell disease (SCD) are at 26x greater risk for maternal mortality than their healthy counterparts; a figure which, despite the adoption of improved care plans, has shown little to no significant improvement over the last two decades. It is our belief that hemolysis-induced overstimulation of the complement system is at the forefront of the placental insufficiency and poor pregnancy outcomes seen in SCD. We now aim to investigate this hypothesis using a well-established pre-clinical mouse model of SCD and various therapeutic interventions to improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Less than 50% of adolescents with mental illness receive care after accounting for insurance/economic factors and data also suggests stigma is a significant additional barrier to care; challenges to care are particularly severe for race/ethnic minority and lower socioeconomic youth. As untreated mental illness has long-term negative consequences on health and well-being, a public health approach using efficacious education-based anti-stigma programs in school settings is a priority to address stigma head-on and promote help-seeking among youth; yet these proven interventions are rarely integrated in typical school mental health programs. To promote mental health help-seeking and reduce mental health disparities among youth, this project will identify real-world implementation targets and strategies for school principals and health educators to increase the use of proven anti-stigma programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Polycystic kidney disease, in which the kidney accumulates fluid-filled sacs, is the leading genetic cause of renal failure, yet the primary driver of this disease remains unknown. We used a unique mouse model as an entry point to dissect disease-driving mechanisms uncovering a protein, ARL13B, as a main driver of renal cysts. Expanding upon this foundational knowledge, we propose to further examine ARL13B interacting proteins and unravel the pathways leading to kidney cysts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a severe and often fatal intestinal disease of prematurity that culminates in irreversible intestinal epithelial cell injury. Effective treatments for this devastating disease are lacking due to an inadequate understanding of protective and pathogenic signaling pathways in the neonatal intestine. This K08 career development proposal investigates the mechanisms involved in attenuating intestinal epithelial cell injury in NEC, which is critical for designing new effective treatment strategies for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Double strand breaks (DSBs) are a type of DNA damage that is relevant to congenital diseases such as Ataxia telangiectasia, Li Fraumeni syndrome, and Bloom syndrome, as well as cancer and infertility. Incorrect repair of DSBs result in a type of mutation called structural variants (SVs). I will study the impact of mutations in DSB repair genes on the types of SVs in human genomes, which will result in better understanding of mechanisms of DSB repair, and how defects in this repair shape the genome and affect human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-related alterations to the microbiota are vastly under studied during adolescence yet may influence normative neural trajectories through the microbiome-brain axis leading to increased risk of alcohol use disorder. The proposed project responds to the need for a multi-modal, comprehensive understanding of the physiological effects of alcohol during adolescence by expanding research into the periphery (i.e., oral microbiome) and investing the connection between the oral microbiome and the brain (i.e., microbiome-brain axis). Findings from this study will help generate a more thorough understanding of the biological consequences of adolescent alcohol use, with the long-term goal of informing novel prevention and intervention efforts that target the microbiota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons with end stage kidney disease (ESKD) depend on reliable transportation to dialysis sessions. This Mentored Patient-Oriented Career Development Award will provide foundational data on the social risks faced by patients with ESKD treated with dialysis and how to best measure the transportation insecurity they face. It will lay the groundwork for future studies on screening and interventions to address health related social risks in the ESKD population with the goal of improving health and advancing equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Computer-aided detection (CAD), which uses artificial intelligence to analyze chest X-rays, is now WHO- recommended for tuberculosis (TB) screening and holds the potential to improve TB detection in high-burden, low-resource communities. This proposed research seeks to evaluate the adaptive application of CAD for community-based TB screening in sub-Saharan Africa, utilizing individualized and context-specific methods, as an alternative to the current standard of a "one-size-fits-all" approach. By assessing diagnostic accuracy, implementation barriers, and cost-effectiveness of each screening strategy, the insights gained from this study could be used to facilitate earlier detection of TB and reduce the high morbidity and mortality caused by tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE About 79% of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) patients develop spinal disorders that significantly impair physical functioning and whose early diagnosis may prevent irreversible neurological damage. The proposed research will examine cervical spinal cord morphology and microstructure in a large cohort of patients with MPS type I, II, and VI and identify structural measurements as candidates for markers of MPS severity and myelopathy risk. The study outcomes will guide the clinical decision process for spine surgery and impact the design of future clinical trials focusing on MPS patients’ overall and spinal cord health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure impacts more than 5 million Americans and is the leading cause of short term hospital readmissions. Current methods to detect cardiac failure decompensation at home rely on patient’s self-report and are lacking, motivating the need to develop non-invasive remote monitoring technology that could be widely disseminated to allow earlier intervention and reducing the rehospitalization rate. We propose to develop a wearable monitor that uses near-infrared light to detect excessive accumulation of water in tissue (edema) as well as impaired peripheral blood circulation and demonstrate its utility in pilot clinical study in patients with cardiac failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will address quality of care issues associated with hearing loss in adults who have perceived mild-to-moderate hearing loss and who have no access to hearing healthcare. This project will identify a new care delivery model for adults living in rural communities of the Southern United States to mitigate the negative effects of hearing loss. This information is important to NIH’s mission because it will lead to options that will increase access and affordability of hearing healthcare for adults with mild-to-moderate hearing loss, a specific goal of NIDCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Considering that many older adults from minoritized populations (e.g., Black/African American and Latinx/a/o, and socioeconomically disadvantaged adults) are disproportionally affected by Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD), it is critical to facilitate their representation in AD/ADRD research. The development and evaluation of efforts to increase the inclusion of minoritized populations in AD/ADRD research needs to be theory-based, informed by the respective community members, and consider intersecting social positions of populations. The training and research proposed by this K01 Mentored Research Scientist Career Development project will facilitate the development of evidence-based, community-engaged digital research inclusion efforts, which consider the intersection of ethnocultural identity and education in Black/African American and Latinx/a/o older adults, which is an important step in improving their representation in AD/ADRD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic alteration of the gut microbiota can worsen the severity of inflammatory arthritis but how this occurs is not well understood. This proposal aims to extend our prior work to define how antibiotic-induced gut dysbiosis affects local responses in the gut epithelium and distal inflammation in the joint. This Mentored Clinical Scientist Research Career Development Award (K08) application proposes a research and career development plan over the next 5 years to allow the PI to study this important research question and develop the skills and training to become a successful, independent physician-scientist investigating the gut microbiome interface and the gut- joint axis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired extravillous trophoblast (EVT) cell development leads to early loss of pregnancy, a suboptimal fetal environment, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Regulatory mechanisms underlying human trophoblast stem cell self-renewal and early events in the differentiation of EVT cells have largely remained elusive. The objective of this proposal is to elucidate the role of CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein beta in early events of EVT cell differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sex differences in mood disorders during cocaine abstinence may be influenced by the interplay between estrogen (E2) and L-type calcium channel (LTCC) interactions. The current study will conduct an extensive mechanistic analysis to investigate whether E2, in conjunction with LTCCs, significantly impacts drug-seeking and mood-related behaviors following cocaine abstinence. Understanding the impact of estrogen on potential L-type calcium channel mechanisms involved in comorbid substance use and mood disorders holds both innovative potential and the promise of reshaping our approach to these co-occurring conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIV SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative B cells have been thought to be absent from the central nervous system, but recently B cells have been shown to be present in cerebral spinal fluid (that bathes the brain) of normal healthy human volunteers, which could be a problem because although B cell produce protective antibodies they can also generate autoreactive antibodies that have the capacity to damage normal tissues. We have shown that in young people B cells in the central nervous system do not overlap with, or come from, the bloodstream, meaning that B cells in the central nervous system are completely separate and distinct from circulating B cells-- work by another group similarly finds that circulating B cells do not enter the central nervous system in young mice; however, the situation in old mice is completely different in that peripheral B cells are, in fact, found within the central nervous system. We will determine whether migration/translocation of peripheral B cells to the central nervous system occurs in old people because, if so, B cells making autoantibodies that cross over to, and end up in, the central nervous system could participate in the pathogenesis and/or progression of age-associated neurodegenerative diseases that involve inflammation and this new understanding might lead to new approaches for disease prevention or treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In animals with internal fertilization, secreted proteins transferred in seminal fluid are required for fertility, and have been canonically thought of as male-specific products. We discovered that many of the seminal fluid genes are also expressed by specialized cell types in the female reproductive tract. This project interrogates the functions and behavior of the male- vs female-contributed protein fractions and the extent to which their actions are cooperative or sexually antagonistic, toward a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms supporting fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Subtle alternations of physical activity patterns at an early stage may act as preclinical indicators of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). This project is designed to explore whether altered accelerometer-derived physical activity rhythms predict brain and cognitive aging and increase risk of ADRD. Identifying such changes before clinical manifestations of dementia may facilitate understanding of common pathophysiological mechanisms connecting motor function and brain aging and may suggest novel directions for tailored interventions to prevent or delay the onset of ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative:  No vaccines are currently licensed to prevent human brucellosis and existing vaccines for livestock are not entirely efficacious. However, mechanisms underlying the ability of Brucella to subvert vaccine-mediated immunity remain unclear. In this proposal, we will investigate both how vaccines alter metabolism to protect the host, and how Brucella is able to evade adaptive immunity, which therefore could improve the future rational design of highly effective vaccines against Brucella.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Timely and accurate clinical decision-making is critical for public health, by aiding in the early detection of outbreaks, improving patient outcomes, and achieving higher-quality health care. Clinicians, especially in time- sensitive settings like emergency departments (EDs), often lack just-in-time access to reliable evidence-based information, leading to suboptimal patient care decisions. This research aims to a develop clinically reliable and transparent large language model (LLM)-based question answering (QA) system, and translate it into a clinical chatbot for timely, precise, evidence-based decision-making, ultimately improving patient outcomes and contributing to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Narrative  Epigenetic age estimators provide a powerful tool in determining epigenetic age, alleviating the necessity of monitoring cohorts of animals throughout their lives in captivity or in the wild. Sex and gender differences in aging and other health outcomes are frequently severely confounded by behavioral and environmental factors, mandating the use of animal models. The present study, by using outbred deer mice (Peromyscus) will explore how genetic relatedness of parents, history of social interactions, and CDK8/19 inhibition impact epigenetic age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Children are disproportionately affected by respiratory viruses and at risk of developing severe viral infections requiring admission to the pediatric intensive care unit. Once a child develops a severe disease, treatment options are currently limited to supportive measures that do not treat the underlying pathology. This proposal will provide insight into how the pediatric immune system promotes recovery from severe viral respiratory infections to inform the design of new treatments aimed at accelerating recovery and reducing the risk of complications from severe viral respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance Statement. Violence is a serious public health problem in the United States that directly or vicariously impacts the lives of millions of Americans. Violence exposure has significant consequences for health and healthcare utilization, yet research overlooks the effects of exposure to community-based violence on dental care utilization. We use data from three national longitudinal datasets to pioneer research on exposure to community violence and dental care utilization over the lifespan: (1) the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health, (2) the Future of Families and Child Wellbeing Study, and (3) Neighborhood Gun Violence and Health in 100 Cities Study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the frequency of athletic knee injuries in children has skyrocketed, delayed surgery due to multilevel barriers can have lifelong consequences. This project will identify barriers to timely surgery in Hispanic high school athletes and design and test an intervention to reduce delayed treatment. In the future, the knowledge and intervention developed in this study will be adapted to address similar disparities in other communities, resulting in more equitable care for all youth athletes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative: This funding application seeks support for the implementation of Wave 2 of the Longitudinal Aging Study in India (LASI). Wave 2 of LASI plays a pivotal role in advancing our understanding of the aging process in India, addressing the unique challenges faced by older adults, and facilitating the formulation of policies and programs to enhance their well-being and quality of life. Furthermore, the data collected during LASI Wave 2 will provide crucial backing for the Longitudinal Aging Study in India- Diagnostic Assessment of Dementia (LASI-DAD). LASI-DAD's data will significantly contribute to our understanding of dementia prevalence, incidence, cognitive changes over time, and the comprehensive evaluation of the economic and caregiving burdens associated with dementia, both at the population level and among diverse demographic groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE New research methods have made it possible to create and characterize dozens of animal models of human cognitive disorders in parallel. By combining high throughput CRISPR technology with state-of-the-art sequencing, imaging, and behavioral assays, this project will generate highly detailed quantitative descriptions of dozens of distinct models of human neurodevelopmental disorders in zebrafish. Computational tools will then be used to interpret, relate, and predict phenotypes, providing insights about the cellular and molecular pathways involved in brain development and cognitive dysfunction.

PHR: Project Narrative  We aim to create an affordable device for imaging calcium transients, using pinhole illumination to create optical sectioning, which will reduce background light (F0) and consequently increasing the optical signal (dF/F0). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project narrative Aging involves a gradual clinical decline in cognitive and physical function and often the development of various comorbidities. However, significant life events, such as a cancer diagnosis, cancer treatment, or other individual-level and societal-level factors can accelerate clinical decline and aging in cancer survivors compared to other older people without a cancer diagnosis. The completion of this study will identify targetable multilevel aging risk factors in the older population with lung cancer, as well as provide a valuable monitoring tool to predict dynamic risk of aging-related clinical decline, allowing for a deeper understanding of drivers of aging acceleration and timely intervention before clinical decline occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Women are twice as likely as men to develop post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a chronic stress disorder that may negate the cardiovascular (CV) protection conferred by female hormones before menopause. The proposed longitudinal study builds on cross-sectional findings from my current K01 to identify low estradiol levels and sleep disturbances as potential mechanisms in the development of CV disease in young women. This follow-up study (two years later) of the vascular and neural alterations in young women with PTSD will help inform the development of strategies to improve CV health in this growing and high-risk population of women.

PHR: Project Narrative Infants born prematurely represent a vulnerable population that has an elevated likelihood of developing social and cognitive impairments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the recovery from work literature, strain refers to effects (e.g., on affect, physiology, fatigue levels, etc.) of exposure to stressors or any other demands which, if allowed to accumulate, can lead to impaired health and performance. The goals of this study are to use digital health data to see if physiological measures, such as heart rate variability, and performance-based measures, such as mobile cognitive testing, can serve as indicators of accrued strain, which is often unobservable and hence easy to ignore. The ability to utilize real- world digital health data for the identification of strain will enable enhancement of existing, and creation of new, worker recovery interventions, which could prevent the negative effects of strain accumulation.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Examining Potential Mobile Measures of Strain, or the Accumulated Effects of Exposure to Demands
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a debilitating chronic disease characterized by an abnormal endometrial immune microenvironment, affecting 10% of reproductive-age women worldwide. The goal of this proposal is to gain a better understanding of the contribution of uterine natural killer cells, the dominant cytolytic lymphocyte in the endometrium, to endometriosis pathobiology and to identify non-invasive, mechanistically-driven diagnostic biomarkers in menstrual blood. Ultimately, completion of this work will contribute to significantly reducing the long diagnostic delay associated with endometriosis by unraveling fundamental immune mechanisms and expanding the pool of potential therapeutic targets, thereby mitigating the burden of illness and disability associated with this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite experiencing disabling chronic pain at similar rates as adolescents and older adults, there is limited research to inform interventions for this underserved age group. This project will define potent treatment targets using ecological momentary assessment and co-design with young adults to develop a personalized, adaptive mobile intervention for pain management. Knowledge gained can lead to a new generation of effective, accessible, and scalable digital health interventions for young adults, halting the escalation of pain, disability, and socioeconomic and health disparities in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is the most common primary malignant brain tumor in adults and remains fatal despite aggressive treatments. One of the main barriers to understanding glioblastoma tumor biology and developing more effective therapies is the dependence on tumor tissue obtained via invasive surgical procedures for diagnosis. This work will evaluate whether cell-free DNA methylation patterns derived from peripheral blood correlate with tumor biology and treatment response, thereby providing a method for longitudinal molecular profiling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Drawing from a national sample of cohabiting and married couples, the proposed project examines how romantic relationship characteristics are associated with alcohol use among sexual and gender minority (SGM) and cisgender straight adults. We also examine if romantic partnership characteristics help buffer against heavy alcohol use in the face of discrimination stressors among SGM couples. Expanding knowledge about how SGM couples thrive in antagonistic contexts will inform intervention programing and help reduce health disparities for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  My recent work led to a discovery of perivascular retinal neurons, termed Fam19a4/Nts-RGCs, that selectively interact with vessels via perivascular endfeet. I further found that Piezo2, a mechanosensitive cation channel, is enriched in these perivascular neurons at the interface of neurovascular interactions. My proposed project will combine electrophysiology, experimental optic neuropathy models, single-cell profiling, and in vivo imaging to investigate Piezo2's role in modulating these newly characterized perivascular neurons' physiological properties and pathological responses.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The consequences of weakness in the extremities, chronic pain, paralysis, and amputation can adversely affect a Veteran’s ability to work, to engage in activities, and to maintain a desired quality of life. Nerve stimulation coupled with advanced prosthetic technologies has shown the capability to restore some sensation in the lost limb and decrease phantom pain. Nerve stimulation is also emerging as a non-opioid treatment for acute and chronic pain. While the baseline technologies exist to provide the patient adequate treatment, optimal implanted devices will require a higher-density of connections from the nerve to the stimulator. Our proposed research will address this need in a manner that will also allow for a minimally invasive procedure and reduce the bulk of implanted material. This work will contribute to improvements in existing implanted nerve stimulation systems and will provide the opportunity for investigating new treatments to enhance Veterans’ lives.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA PACIFIC ISLANDS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: This project will evaluate neurofeedback, a type of biofeedback, training as a low risk, non-invasive, effective treatment for our Veterans who had a concussion(s) while at war serving in the military. Some Veterans, who experienced concussions, may suffer from some long-lasting health issues such as headaches, trouble paying attention, sleep difficulties and negative feelings about their life. These can negatively impact all aspects of life, including work, health, relationships, ability to do daily tasks and quality of life. Since neurofeedback, has been shown to help other people who had concussions, this study will examine whether neurofeedback will help our Veterans. Neurofeedback will be used to assist Veterans to self-regulate brain wave activity and stabilize the underlying physiological disconnections that may stem from concussions. Assisting Veterans to self-regulate brain wave activity through neurofeedback has the potential for significant positive changes in Veterans’ physical and mental health and their perceptions of self-health management and overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates the accuracy and feasibility of using point-of-care, low-field brain magnetic resonance imaging (POC LF-MRI) for diagnosing traumatic brain injury (TBI) in children, a population vulnerable to the harmful ionizing radiation of traditional CT scans. Through a comprehensive, observational cohort study, we aim to compare the accuracy of POC LF-MRI against the current standard of care, assess its capability to track injury progression, and evaluate its practical metrics in emergency and critical care settings. Our goal is to determine if POC LF-MRI can provide accurate, efficient, and more accessible neuroimaging, potentially redefining pediatric trauma care while reducing ionizing radiation risks and enhancing patient safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aligned with NIH's priority of supporting the development of innovative mobile health applications to improve clinical and public health outcomes and strengthen research capacity in low- and middle-income countries, the proposed Suubi-Mhealth study seeks to develop an mhealth intervention for use among Ugandan youth (14-17 years) with comorbid HIV and depression, taking into account their unique contextual, cultural, and developmental needs. This digital therapy intervention delivered via a mobile application, will utilize the core tenets of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) found to improve depression and ART adherence. We expect for Suubi-Mhealth to be an acceptable and feasible mhealth tool to reduce depression, improve ART adherence and overall mental health functioning among youth living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In order to promote an optimal transition into adulthood, innovative solutions to prevent HIV infection and unintended pregnancy are needed among adolescent girls and young women in high HIV prevalence low- and middle-income countries. We propose to co-design and test a novel peer-navigator intervention, facilitated by an mHealth application, to increase pre-exposure prophylaxis and modern contraception use among a high-risk sub-population of young women in Zambia. The mHealth intervention has the potential to provide a model for scale-up across other sub-Saharan African settings and significantly reduce the burden of HIV and unintended pregnancy among adolescent girls and young women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Chronic cough that does not respond to standard cough treatments (known as refractory chronic cough) is highly disruptive and significantly reduces well-being. The proposed studies will lay the groundwork for a larger clinical trial of the use of vibrotactile stimulation to the larynx to reduce refractory chronic cough via dose refinement (Aim 1) and conduct of a pilot randomized clinical trial (Aim 2). This potential treatment is noninvasive, repeatable, independently usable, and portable, making it a promising option for improving the quality of life of people who suffer from refractory chronic cough.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relapse is a leading cause of death in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML), and new therapies are needed for relapsed disease. AML relapse is mediated by leukemia stem cells (LSC), which undergo unique metabolic adaptations in order to survive chemotherapy. Emerging evidence shows that LSC require lipid metabolism to mediate relapse. The purpose of this work is to determine how lipid metabolism supports LSC mitochondria and the process of oxidative phosphorylation. This will be done by studying lipid metabolism in AML cell lines as well as using a high-fat diet to drive AML relapse in mice engrafted with pediatric AML. If successful, this work will improve our understanding of AML biology by providing a mechanistic explanation for the ways in which lipids support LSC during relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Quantitative Team Science (QuanTS) Program will provide training and mentorship in collaborative skills to equip quantitative scientists to work effectively on research teams across all fields of medicine. To accomplish this goal, we will create online didactic training materials that are broadly accessible to the quantitative science community, facilitate an experiential, small-group mentorship program focused on team science skills for early-career quantitative scientists, and provide guidance and training materials for mentors. We will also integrate novel evaluation processes within the program to examine facilitators, barriers and outcomes of the proposed methods for training and mentoring quantitative team scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias (ADRD) are characterized by accumulation of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) and impairment of proteasome-mediated protein degradation. This R36 proposal aims to investigate small molecule 20S proteasome activation as a novel strategy to resolve both pathogenic events. Successful completion of this work will enable the rapid design, development, and identification of 20S proteasome activators, and elucidate the role of 20S proteasome modulation in neurodegenerative diseases as a novel therapeutic strategy for disease treatment.

PHR: Narrative  We propose to investigate the underlying immune pathway of the intergenerational link of adverse cardiometabolic outcomes by integrating state-of-the-art antibody profiles to a broad array of pathogenic and commensal microbes and systemic immunoproteomic profiles in a high-risk U.S. racially and ethnically diverse prospective birth cohort. Findings from this study may lead to a new paradigm to halt or reverse the vicious intergenerational cycle of cardiometabolic risk, and to improve health across the lifespan and generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In older adults, sleep-wake rhythm disruption and recurring depression/suicide ideation are often inter-related, unmet, clinical needs. This project will confirm the efficacy and mechanism-of- action of targeting sleep-wake rhythms with the Transdiagnostic Intervention for Sleep and Circadian Dysfunction (TranS-C), specifically, to improve depression in adults 55+ years of age. This multi-site trial will confirm if and how this approach works, and for whom, thereby advancing evidence-based strategies for controlling depression symptoms in older adults who have depression and high suicide risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic intestinal inflammation is a critical risk factor for the development of colon cancer; however, molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying chronic intestinal inflammation are still being uncovered. The proposed research will allow us to validate the importance of gene related to anergy in lymphocyte (Grail) expression in mucosal T follicular helper cells and its role in regulating the balance between intestinal homeostasis and inflammation. The implication from this work is significant, since it will provide novel insights into the genetic link between inflammation and cancer and project Grail as a potential marker for diagnosis of intestinal inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to the dramatic rise in adolescent e-cigarette use, we face an urgent need to promote e-cigarette cessation among adolescents; unfortunately, although most adolescent e-cigarette users are interested in quitting and have made at least one quit attempt, no empirically validated e-cigarette cessation interventions are available. For such interventions, formative research is needed to develop (1) a motivation-based typology of adolescent e-cigarette users in order to identify the cognitive and behavioral intervention targets specific to each type of user and (2) an understanding of adolescent views to further inform intervention content (e.g., examples of type-specific cues and maladaptive cognitions) and ensure maximal acceptability, engagement, and efficacy of the resulting interventions. The data from this project will inform the creation of subsequent adolescent e-cigarette cessation interventions that are targeted to specific use motivations, developmentally appropriate, grounded in cognitive behavioral principles, and highly engaging and acceptable to users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a common form of severe lung injury that occurred in 10% of pre- pandemic ICU admissions, results in mortality of 30-45%, and has become a leading cause of death from COVID- 19. This multicenter randomized controlled trial evaluates whether a novel ventilation strategy that individualizes support to minimize lung stress, compared to guided usual care, improves survival and pulmonary recovery in ventilator-dependent patients with ARDS. Results from this trial may establish a personalized approach to ARDS management that reduces morbidity and mortality and, by extension, decreases costs and strain on the healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop low-cost, accurate and accessible approaches to improve cervical cancer screening in low- and middle-income countries, which bear the greatest burden of disease. We will adapt advances in nucleic acid amplification technology developed for COVID surveillance to develop the NATFlow HPV assay, a low-cost, fully integrated, sample-to-answer nucleic acid test that meets the needs for cervical cancer screening in low-resource settings. We will use a community- and stakeholder-engaged process to evaluate the technical and clinical performance of the NATFlow HPV test in Mozambique, as well as barriers and facilitators to its future implementation, in Mozambique.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistant bacteria are a growing global threat to human health and wellbeing. I propose to investigate how the spatiotemporal organization and physiology of gut bacteria could be targeted to stop the emergence and spread of antibiotic resistance. This work will inform the design of new strategies for combating antibiotic resistance through the therapeutic manipulation of the intestinal microbiome’s physical architecture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial toxins that target insects could be utilized for developing bio-pesticides to control harmful insects, but a molecular understanding of toxin-host interactions is required. Here, we seek to establish and validate new methods and tools for carrying out unbiased genome-wide screens on insect cell models to uncover key host factors mediating the action of insect- targeting bacterial toxins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Building on social network and mentoring co-regulation theories, we propose to develop a generalizable model of how peer and mentor social networks can be leveraged to promote diverse students’ access to social capital and support for self-regulated learning skills, which in turn facilitate biomedical research career success. We propose to use a longitudinal experimental design to compare short-, medium-, and long-term “Hallmarks of Success” (e.g., well-being, degree conferral) of diverse first-year biomedical engineering students. Participating students will be assigned to one-of-three peer-network intervention groups and one-of-two mentor-network intervention groups, and the differential intervention effects for students from historically over- and under- represented racial/ethnic groups will be assessed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Menopause increases the risks of various diseases like cardiovascular disorders, osteoporosis, depression, and cognitive decline, however current clinical markers are not able to identify when the menopause transition will start nor how long it will last. While identifying menopause transition biomarkers is challenging due to the complex multi-cellular, spatial and temporal heterogeneity of the ovary, systems approaches are ideal frameworks to integrate spatiotemporal multi-omics assessments (e.g., single-cell and spatial transcriptomics, and non-targeted metabolomics) in order to reveal the key signaling and metabolic processes that regulate a phenotype, i.e., menopause transition. Here we prosed to use a Systems Metabolic network-based approach, Genome-scale metabolic models (GMMs), to identify age-regulated ovarian-produced metabolites that can be secreted into circulation and are significantly associated with and predictive of the state of the menopause transition potentially enabling interventions to delay early or premature menopause, and reduce the risk of future menopause-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although antiretroviral therapy (ART) is now widely available, people with HIV continue to have shorter life expectancy compared to the general population. We previously found that gut barrier dysfunction predicted mortality in persons with ART-suppressed HIV and a history of AIDS. Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a common coinfection in HIV, disrupts the gut barrier, and a recent clinical trial showed that a drug active against CMV reduced harmful immune activation in HIV-infected participants. In this project, we will study the role of CMV in gut barrier dysfunction and immune activation. We predict that treatment for CMV infection will help restore gut barrier function and improve outcomes for HIV-infected individuals on ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pre-pregnancy obesity is associated with significant adverse health outcomes for the mother including increased risk of gestational diabetes and hypertension, preeclampsia and infection. Recent studies from our laboratory revealed significant changes in immune cell function in blood samples collected from obese women at week 37 of gestation. Since immune cells play a critical role in anti-microbial defense as well as the development of chronic inflammation, this application will carry out an in-depth investigation of maternal pre-pregnancy obesity- driven changes in the functional, transcriptional, and epigenetic landscape of blood immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pinpointing the putative susceptibility genes that mediate genetic associations in breast cancer has been a challenge, partly due to lack of data on alternative transcript-isoforms and splice sites in available gene expression datasets. We will enhance existing large short-read RNA-sequencing datasets by quantifying isoform and alternative splicing patterns, leveraging tissue-specific long-read RNA-seq datasets as reference. We will build on our previous experience developing cutting-edge machine learning frameworks to not only elucidate breast cancer risk etiology, but also provide open-source computational pipelines and data resources for future research by the human genetics community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional impairment, or reduced ability to carry out day-to-day tasks, is often associated with older populations but may occur in lupus patients of all ages. Our study aims to: estimate the burden of both physical and cognitive functional impairment; identify potential risk factors for this impairment among lupus patients; and compare outcomes among lupus patients with and without signs of impairment. The results of this study will help adapt and target geriatric interventions to support lupus patients with impairment, which will be essential for the maintenance of high-quality, patient-centered, efficient clinical care of the rapidly aging U.S. lupus population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impairments in walking and balance are common after stroke, and current rehabilitation strategies lack specificity due to a limited mechanistic understanding of the early determinants of walking and balance recovery. This study will serially track the development of balance control, walking ability, and fall events in the first six months following a stroke, and use structural imaging to identify key neurological correlates. Knowledge gained from this study will likely improve the precision of rehabilitation by leading to more informed and customized treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular dysfunction contributes to a higher risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) in comparison to individuals without CKD. This study will assess how daily consumption of beetroot juice changes factors in circulation (blood) to improve vascular function in patients with CKD. Overall, this research will provide scientific evidence supporting the use of beetroot juice for improving vascular function in CKD and insight into the biological reasons (mechanisms) by which this occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Object recognition lies at the heart of our ability to make sense of the visual world, engaging a series of hierarchical processing in the ventral temporal cortex (VTC) and medial temporal lobe (MTL) network, which coordinately transforms the visual inputs to semantic representation. This project aims to reveal the underlying neural computations and circuit-level dynamics during this process using human intracranial recordings at both single-neuron and neural-circuit levels, behavioral measurements, and sophisticated computational algorithms. The anticipated outcomes of this proposal will contribute to the mechanistic understanding of object perception, which will shed light on developing new therapeutic interventions for patients affected by object recognition difficulties .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with tuberculosis (TB) can benefit greatly if we could identify signs of poor response earlier and adjust therapy intensity accordingly. Innovations in DNA isolation and sequencing technologies now enable the study of TB pathogen populations in an individual patient with very high resolution. Here, we propose to use these technologies and a highly well-characterized cohort of South African TB patients to investigate how pathogen population genetic changes link to pathogen survival and treatment response, laying the foundation for improvements in clinical treatment monitoring using DNA sequencing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  With increasing recognition that all treatments will not suit all patients, and that no singular treatment is likely to cure, prevent, or stop the onset or progression of Alzheimer’s dementia, it is of critical importance to pursue a precision medicine approach to understand which therapies will be most beneficial and for whom. This project aims to fill an unmet critical need in the Alzheimer’s field to examine Alzheimer’s risk in response to treatment by leveraging existing trial data from major, field-changing studies. This work could inspire new trial designs that sharpen their lens towards phenotypic risk based on factors such as sex/gender, APOE4 status, baseline levels of amyloid and tau, and overall genetic risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-related intimate partner aggression (IPA) is a significant public health concern, especially among couples from low-income communities. The proposed study seeks to examine how social isolation and social norm perceptions in in-person versus virtual social networks are associated with alcohol use and IPA among high-risk, disadvantaged couples. This research has the potential to provide critical knowledge toward the development of interventions that target social networks for reducing alcohol-related IPA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The integration of SIV into the host genome poses a significant barrier to achieving a successful HIV cure. This project seeks to elucidate the host-dependent mechanisms that govern preferences in HIV/SIV integration and the pivotal role SIV integration plays in disrupting host cellular functions; the latter ultimately leads to immune senescence, premature aging of the immune system, and, in some cases, tumorigenesis. By addressing these crucial aspects, my project aims to offer mechanistic insights that can lead to potential therapeutic targets for preventing integration or reversing host-immune dysfunctions triggered by SIV integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through a systematic review, we identified research gaps related to social determinants of health and their relationship with dry eye. Leveraging multi-center electronic health records, our proposal seeks to investigate the association between indicators of social determinants and disparities in access to care and unequal prognosis in dry eye patients. By incorporating this routinely collected information as predictors in the rigorously constructed and externally validated prognostic models, our goal is to provide updated evidence, improve disease management, and enhance outcomes for individuals with dry eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal investigates undefined neuronal mechanisms that orchestrate metabolic shifts during bacterial infections. By employing innovative methodologies, the aim is to elucidate the role of the brain-liver axis in modulating metabolic responses, thereby bolstering host survival during infections. By intertwining neuroscience and immunology, this research can unveil new dimensions in host defense strategies, examining both neuronal and hepatic responses to infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: This research project focuses on developing and optimizing ribozymes for the selective killing of cancer cells carrying specific driver mutations, using the JAK2-V617F driver mutation in myeloproliferative neoplasms as a proof-of-principle. The proposed work uses a combinatorial approach called RABADOCS to identify highly specific and efficient ribozyme variants that can trans-splice and replace target mRNA sequences with a sequence encoding a cytotoxic peptide, inducing cell death in cancer cells while sparing healthy ones. The ultimate goal of this three-year project is to demonstrate the feasibility of using these engineered ribozymes as a novel therapeutic strategy for treating myeloproliferative neoplasms and potentially other cancers with prevalent missense mutations, offering a promising avenue for precision cancer treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myeloperoxidase (MPO), which gives the distinctive green tinge in pus and phlegm, is the key enzyme that generates chlorine bleach in white blood cells for bacterial killing, and patients lacking this enzyme often contract fungal infection and develop inflammatory diseases. Because the existing MPO-deficient mouse model fails to reproduce the human disease, an accurate and faithful animal model is critically needed. The current application has laid out a comprehensive plan to characterize a novel MPO-deficient rabbit model to meet the need for basic research of MPO-related infection and inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Active Viral Hepatitis Diagnostics to Support Prevention/Treatment of HCC Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a highly lethal cancer with over 80% of the cases occurring in low resource settings. Chronic hepatitis C (HCV) infection is major risk factor for HCC development. The goal of this proposal is to develop and validate a diagnostic test for HCV infections for use in low-and-middle-income-countries to identify patients for treatment thus reducing their risk of developing HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The loss of heart cells after heart attack is a major cause of heart failure. The newborn mammalian hearts can regrow back after heart attack while the adult mammalian hearts loss the capacity. The proposed research is investigating the molecular mechanisms underlying the heart regrowth capacity in the newborn hearts. Understanding the mechanisms will provide a mechanistic base for designing new treatment for heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Coronary Microvascular Disease (CMVD) accounts for 30-50% of ischemic heart disease and can lead to angina, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, and cardiovascular death. In prior and preliminary studies, we have identified a single nucleotide polymorphism in the Friend of GATA 2 (FOG2), termed FOG2S657G, which is associated with CMVD and increases expression of β1-adrenergic receptor. In this proposal, we use novel mouse and induced pluripotent stem cell models to determine the link between FOG2S657G, increased β1-adrenergic receptor expression, and increased cardiac work to promote CMVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Direct recording of neural activity from the human brain using implanted electrodes (intracranial EEG, iEEG) is a fast-growing and high-impact technique in human neuroscience. The NIH has mandated data sharing plans for all investigators and funded the creation of open archives for iEEG data, but sharing faces many obstacles. We will remove these obstacles by creating new tools for organizing, sharing and making discoveries from iEEG Data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative As artificial intelligence (AI) becomes an ever increasingly component of biomedical research the need for an inclusive trained workforce is essential. The University of Florida (UF) proposes to develop a nation-wide course to upskill biomedical researchers’ expertise in AI while promoting diversity and inclusive excellence for its participants through career development and mentoring. The AI Passport for Biomedical Research (AIPassportBMR) proposal will provide biomedical researchers the opportunity to augment their skills in a concise and comprehensive course based on innovative learning techniques while being mentored by AI experts from across the nation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancer standard of care regularly includes radiation therapy which is effective but often results in long-lasting pain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Using the research approaches in this project, we will determine the role of Clonal Hematopoiesis of Indeterminate Potential (CHIP) in cardiorespiratory fitness, including the role of CHIP as a predictor of heterogeneity in responsive to exercise training, which will expand our understanding of the impact of CHIP in cardiometabolic disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: In recent years, severe outbreaks and epidemics of Ebola, Lassa, and Zika have illustrated how vulnerable the world is to threats from RNA viral pathogens. To counter the dangers posed by these viruses, we must develop flexible and scalable technologies for diagnostics, surveillance, pathogen discovery and transmission, and deploy them in the most outbreak-prone regions of the world. Here, we will establish the West African Research Network for Infectious Diseases with partners in the United States, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Nigeria, to develop effective strategies, and deploy the necessary tools, for detecting, mitigating, and preventing future outbreaks from emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE . The proposed research serves public health with its novel focus to improve pediatric liver transplant outcomes by assessing and intervening on children’s underlying health-related social risks, e.g., material economic hardship, social isolation, caregiver mental health, health literacy, and neighborhood characteristics. Integrating a Health Advocate as a member of the post-transplant care team will support the delivery of interventions to overcome barriers interposed by these social risks, with clear potential to close disparities and significantly improve long-term outcomes for these children. The proposed research is directly relevant to NIDDK’s vision to seek insights and answers to bridge health disparities.
