IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This IPERT will help educate the biomedical research workforce of the future in the skills necessary to engage in the broad ecosystem for medical device development across the lifespan. The programming includes case- based coursework, experiential learning, and networking and mentoring opportunities to help participants develop and deepen their skills in reviewing and evaluating medical device proposals. Creation of Individual Development Plans and mentoring teams to support growth for two years following a bootcamp will deepen participants’ expertise, and sustained engagement in medical device development will be tracked during and after the programming to measure impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Not only is skeletal muscle a target in sepsis that contributes to worse patient health outcomes, including problems weaning from mechanical ventilation and a greater risk of death, but through release of mtDNA there is strong potential for skeletal muscle to play an amplifying role in driving the systemic inflammation. To address this issue, our project will study a strategy for reducing an event known as mitochondrial permeability transition (mPT) in skeletal muscle on the basis of its potential role in driving muscle dysfunction in sepsis (atrophy, neuromuscular junction impairment) and the fact that mtDNA is released from mitochondria during mPT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Environmental DNA (eDNA) metagenomics is the complex mixture of this genetic material that is found in envi- ronmental samples such as soil, sediment, and water, and thus can be analyzed to create an exact proﬁle of the community of organisms present in that location at certain periods of time, and can provide powerful insights into the invisible diversity of all microbes and other microscopic life that is hidden from the naked eye. eDNA metage- nomics is a powerful tool for monitoring biodiversity and ecosystems that has already provided paradigm shifting revelations into the dynamics of communities and is is quickly transforming many different ﬁelds such as dis- ease monitoring, ecological research, botany, zoology, and even forensics to combat terrorism. In this research proposal, I propose three projects that will leverage eDNA metagenomics to produce results that have better precision and accuracy, and will also leverage the data for new purposes such as distinguishing between differ- ent severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) strains, the virus that causes Coronavirus Infectious Disease-19 (COVID19).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Xylazine-adulterated fentanyl has emerged as a public health threat, particularly in the Northeastern and Mid- Atlantic states, and is contributing to severe injection-related infections and other harms. Amidst this drug supply transition, researchers have begun to document transitions to low-frequency injecting or injection cessation among people otherwise continuing to use fentanyl. This two-year qualitative study seeks to characterize the dynamics shaping these drug use transitions and their implications for public health and overdose prevention through qualitative interviews with a diverse sample of people who use drugs in Connecticut who have transitioned to low-frequency injecting or injection cessation, as well as complementary focus groups with harm reduction workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spatial context can have implications for the cognitive health and well-being of Black men because place can influence interactions between social environment, cumulative stress, and biological responses. No studies to our knowledge have examined the association between place, stress, and cognitive status among this population and we propose to address this gap with a small study analyzing data from the Health and Retirement Study and U. S. Census. Results from the proposed secondary data analysis can provide evidence for a full-scale observational study and inform risk reduction interventions to preserve cognitive function, prevent cognitive impairment, and extend longevity among middle age and older Black men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous monitoring of neonatal brain development is crucial for effective management of brain injury and associated complications, thus reducing healthcare burden and costs. Bioptics Technology is developing, validating, and commercializing a revolutionary time-resolved laser speckle contrast imaging (TR-LSCI) technology that enables noncontact, fast, high-resolution imaging of cerebral blood flow and resting-state functional connectivity across distinct regions of the brain for noninvasive and continuous assessment of neonatal brain development to prevent brain injury. While the proposal tests this imaging technology in perinatal hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy models of neonatal rats and piglets as the first step for preclinical commercialization, the TR-LSCI device is broadly applicable to investigate many neurovascular diseases beyond HIE occurring in human neonates, thereby providing a significant opportunity for future clinical development and commercialization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite the recognized and urgent need for public health interventions that interrupt outdoor malaria transmission, no such proven interventions are available. Transfluthrin-treated hessian fabric strips offer promise, showing more than six months of mosquito bite deterrence in Tanzanian settings. This project seeks to clarify and advance the evidence base on transfluthrin-treated hessian fabric strips through meta-analysis of Tanzanian studies, semi-field and field testing in Thailand and Cambodia, and user acceptability studies in Cambodia to inform future studies and intervention designs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Disrupted signal processing in the principal neurons of basal ganglia is believed to be a key factor in the cause of a number of neurological symptoms including involuntary movements, debilitating tremors, and rigidity. We will study electrical events in two dominant classes of basal ganglia neurons in order to understand how signals that come into neurons are processed, and how best to fix-up the signal processing to correct defects caused by illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is one of the leading causes of mortality in the U.S. and lowering the burden of CVD through prevention and treatment is important to public health. Immigrants of color have lower awareness, screening, monitoring, and treatment of CVD risk factors than U.S.-born populations, which may contribute to the observed decline in their cardiovascular health over longer residence in the U.S. This project will use epidemiologic, system dynamics, and community-engaged methods to understand and quantify how different facets of the sociopolitical environment affect Black and Latinx immigrants’ CVD preventive care utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The limited success in translating studies from mouse models of cystic disease to patients is likely multifactorial and includes the variety of animal models that are used for preclinical studies and the limited bioavailability of candidate drugs in patients. For example, researchers often use cystic models that have different underlying genetic mutations and progress at variable rates interchangeably; however, it is currently unknown how the molecular and cellular pathophysiology of PKD patients translates to mouse models. In this application, we propose to address this gap in knowledge by generating a cross model and species single cell atlas of cystic kidney disease, which can be used to predict mouse models that most closely recapitulate human disease as well as identify evolutionarily conserved, known and novel intra- and inter-cellular signaling networks involved in PKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Residents of Puerto Rico (PR) experience a great burden of cardiometabolic diseases and have been disproportionately exposed to unique social and environmental stressors. The research and training goals of this K01 center around investigating negative affect and dysfunctional eating behaviors as pathways by which chronic and daily stressors may affect the cardiometabolic function of adults in PR. Findings will inform theory, intervention targets, and the understanding of the impact of stress on cardiometabolic health of high-risk and underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an increasing trend (a) for children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) with primary behavioral challenges to be hospitalized in medical facilities because accessible behavioral support resources are not available in local communities and (b) for these hospitalizations to be extremely challenging for children, families, providers, and systems of care (i.e. prolonged hospitalizations; challenges with discharge to step- down facilities; use of restraint, sedation, etc.; high-levels of staffing; un/unreimbursed care for hospitals). Appropriate telehealth and digital health systems that can facilitate tele-mediated behavioral support during hospitalization and through discharge transition may hold great potential for increasing the availability of such care to children, families, and the providers and hospitals responsible for their care. The current project creates and tests the potential clinical value of an innovative telehealth platform to facilitate appropriate, efficacious ABA tele-assessment and intervention for adolescents with ASD displaying challenging behaviors during hospitalizations and post-discharge transition which could powerfully enhance care systems for individuals with ASD and severe challenging behavior that may require intensive support at times in low resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: An ongoing problem in drug development is that many therapeutics have side effects on the brain; for example, certain anti-cancer agents cause impairments in thinking (“chemofog”) which often persist following cessation of the cancer therapy, and medications used to treat AIDs may also impair thinking. Pharmaceutical companies currently test potential therapeutics for toxicity to the nervous system on animals (e.g., mice, and dogs), but harmful effects to the human nervous system are often first revealed in human clinical trials. Our project will develop a novel system to test candidate therapeutics for toxic effects on neurons derived from human adult stem cells (human embyos are not harmed in the preparation of the stem cells) which will be more predictive than animals, improve the efficiency and effectiveness of drug development, and reduce the use of animals in preclinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The US spends more than $635 billion per year on chronic pain, however, the currently available drugs are not effective and often lead to dependence. Neurobiological, genetic, and preclinical studies have suggested that inhibitors of adenylyl cyclase type I (AC1) offer an alternative target. We have discovered a novel scaffold of AC1 inhibitors and propose a molecular pharmacological characterization of these small molecule inhibitors as a logical extension of the parent award.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Population imaging of neural activity in vivo is an important approach to investigate neural coding and circuit function, and to discover how circuit function is compromised in disease. This project focuses on 2-photon imaging of genetically encoded voltage indicators (GEVIs) in cerebral cortex, which records neural activity a fast, physiologically relevant time scales. This project optimizes 2-photon GEVI imaging methods and applies them to study the processing of sensory and cognitive information in mouse sensory cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Recurrent medulloblastoma and high grade glioma are universally fatal, however, targeting human cytomegalovirus antigen pp65 using a peptide vaccine (PEP-CMV) has produced promising preliminary results. This project focuses on elucidating the expression of CMV antigens in ependymoma and combining PEP-CMV with checkpoint blockade to increase immunogenicity. Expanding the eligibility of who may benefit from PEP-CMV and enhancing immune responses has the potential to improve the survival and quality of life of children with high grade glioma, medulloblastoma, and ependymoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A cancer diagnosis is a “teachable moment” – a time when an individual may be open to behavior change – but few studies have considered modifiable lifestyle factors that might improve disease-specific survival in individuals diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). We propose to comprehensively investigate the roles of dietary patterns and physical activity in RCC survival in three large, prospective cohorts with longitudinal food frequency questionnaires, physical activity assessments, and covariable data. Our findings will yield a foundation for developing evidence-based lifestyle recommendations for RCC survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation and scarring of the lung is a leading cause of death among patients with autoimmune disorders, but efforts to reduce the mortality burden of this condition have been limited by a lack of effective anti-fibrotic treatments. The proposed research will define B cell-mediated pathways that contribute to the development of pulmonary fibrosis in patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD), an autoimmune-like condition that occurs in patients who undergo allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Knowledge gained from this study will accelerate the development of targeted immune therapies to improve the lives of patients with cGVHD and autoimmune lung disease while simultaneously fostering the career of a physician investigator committed to an independent research career in immunology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The elicitation of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) against Tier 2 neutralization resistant HIV-1 viruses has proven extremely difficult to achieve by vaccination. Evidence to-date suggests that no individual factor will determine the ultimate success of an HIV-1 vaccine. The goal of this program is to overcome challenges with HIV-1 vaccination through the codelivery of an Env-trimer-modified and mRNA-modified carbon nanotube targeting both humoral and cellular immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The proposed project seeks to develop and validate a software product capable of enhancing an entire brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) study. Brain studies make up approximately 20% of all MRI studies worldwide, and nearly all brain studies acquire multiple image contrasts to obtain complementary information. It has been reported that nearly 60% of all MRI acquisitions contain at least minimal motion artifacts. A successful completion of this project will result in a tool for imaging centers that will improve the consistency and quality of brain MRI studies and allow them to increase their throughput by removing the need to rescan acquisitions with artifacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ataxia telangiectasia (A-T) is a genetic condition causing nerve damage, weakened immunity, and higher cancer risks due to certain protein mutations. Our research explores a new, less harmful treatment method using specially designed toxins in mouse models, aiming to improve immunity, reduce cancer risk, and curb inflammation in A-T patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: This project delves into the realm of Human-Robot Collaboration (HRC) within the construction industry using Virtual Reality (VR) and wearable devices as tools, aiming to determine the impact of levels of involving human-robot collaborations in construction on workers' (both male and female) cognitive risk factors (including mental fatigue, attention, and stress) to enhance occupational safety and health. Neglecting the understanding and analysis of cognitive risk factors in HRC can lead to unforeseen safety hazards and health issues and further hinder the successful adoption and efficiency of HRC in construction. At the completion of the proposed research, the outcomes are expected to not only offer strong evidence to enhance safety measures and worker well-being and promote effective HRC implementations, but also posit that the strategic integration of robotics in construction tasks can foster a broader, more inclusive construction working environment and alleviate workforce shortages, promoting the public well-being.

PROJECT_TITLE: Human-Robot Collaboration in Construction: Assessing Cognitive Factors for Construction Workers Using Virtual Reality-Wearable Devices-Data Analytics Integrated Approach
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity affects nearly half of Americans and is a risk factor for stroke, heart attack, and Type II diabetes. This investigation aims to uncover the signals that promote homeostasis in the visceral adipose tissue, which is intimately related to the adverse health effects of obesity. The findings will enhance our knowledge of the mechanisms promoting obesity and diabetes-related inflammation and inform the development of therapeutics to treat this inflammation and reduce or prevent obesity and diabetes-related adverse health outcomes.

PHR: The premise of this study goals are to determine the patterns of uterine fibroid vascularity pre and post UAE using CEUS resulting in an alternative to gadolinium-enhanced MRI that is less expensive, has less contra-indications and side effects, is real time, and noninvasive helping physicians to evaluate the result of UAE procedures. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Summary/Abstract: One of the keys to reduce the significantly higher prostate cancer mortality of African American (AA) men is effective, minimally invasive early detection of disease. We will determine the sensitivity and specificity of two innovative next generation sequencing (NGS)-based methods, one based on the fragmentomics profiles and one based on methylation profiles of plasma derived cell free DNA, to detect prostate cancer of various disease stages. This will establish a non-invasive method for the early detection of PCa of AA men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electronic cigarettes have exploded in popularity amongst adolescents, renormalizing tobacco use in non- smoking adolescents, and increasing risk for tobacco smoking, other drug use, and direct negative health effects of vapor exposure. Amidst growing demand for adolescent vaping cessation interventions where no proven treatment exists, we have developed QuitVaping, a scalable, fully-remote, young adult lay counselor delivered intervention with digital content that is well accepted and showing promise for vaping cessation in adolescents who vape nicotine daily. This project will determine whether QuitVaping is effective for vaping cessation in mid to late adolescents who vape nicotine at least weekly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the face of increasing resistance to frontline antimalarials, there is a critical need for new drugs that can act against both human and mosquito stages of malaria infection. The highly divergent mitochondrion of the malaria parasite is an attractive drug target, but harnessing its full potential requires in-depth understanding of the organelle’s biology and metabolic pathways. This project aims to identify core functions of the mitochondrion that are likely to be essential across all life stages of the parasite.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Spinal cord injury (SCI) disrupts sensory and motor pathways, resulting in motor impairments of the lower limb that negatively impact mobility. Mild breathing bouts of low oxygen (acute intermittent hypoxia, AIH) is a promising intervention that induces spinal plasticity, leading to improvements in both breathing and locomotion in rats and humans with SCI. However, the neural mechanisms that underlie functional improvements in humans with SCI are poorly understood. This proposal will quantify AIH induced changes in the synthesis of key neural substrates that support plasticity as well as examine predictive biomarkers to identify who optimally responds to AIH. Elucidating factors that facilitate and inhibit AIH responsiveness may significantly impact the lives of persons with paralysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will test the accuracy and reliability of autonomic measurements in bvFTD patients. Measurements will be collected both with established equipment and via at-home devices to assess the validity of the latter. Finally, autonomic measurements will be correlated to socioemotional dysfunction in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NIDA recognizes the need for basic research on the pharmacology of xylazine to unravel the mechanisms that lead to its harmful effects associated with chronic co-intravenous (IV) administration of fentanyl, including necrotic skin lesions. This project will elucidate xylazine’s agonist affinity and its G protein-biased signaling properties at each of the adrenoceptor subtypes and will test the hypothesis that IV xylazine elicits necrotic skin lesions via a peripherally mediated α-adrenoceptor mechanism, laying the foundation for discovering the specific receptor and G protein mechanisms underlying IV xylazine’s toxic skin necrosis-inducing effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative To form the brain circuits that will eventually carry out all neural functions, different types of neurons must precisely wire together. But the specific molecules that are responsible for forming connections between some cells and not others have not yet been identified due to a lack of scalable tools. In this proposal, I will uncover the molecular logic of cell type-specific connectivity by using efficient and state-of-the-art tools for screening the role of individual molecules, and visualizing both neuronal connectivity and cell type identity at scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Rates of cannabis use and disorders are high among young adults experiencing psychosis. Research indicates that continued cannabis use among this population is associated with a range of deleterious outcomes including decreased mental health engagement and medication management, increased rates of hospitalization, relapse and positive and negative psychotic symptoms. Given there are no identified evidence-based interventions to serve cannabis using young adults with psychosis, early intervention efforts with this population becomes an important public health objective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals who have insomnia with short sleep duration (ISS) differ from individuals who have insomnia with normal sleep duration (INS) in terms of health risks and treatment response. This study will examine whether patients with ISS and INS demonstrate a differential response to two common insomnia treatments, cognitive- behavioral treatment of insomnia (CBT-I) and trazodone. Our findings could lead to evidence-based treatment guidelines that help clinicians more effectively match treatments to insomnia patients and reduce associated health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to (1) systematically build the Settlement Abandonment Database, a comprehensive database of population counts for settlements both occupied and abandoned between 1890 and 2020 and (2) to leverage this new database with individuals in the Social Security Administration’s Death File matched to the 1940 Census to estimate the causal effect of settlement abandonment on human longevity. This project will build a new, comprehensive database of the life course of places in the US and leverage NIA- funded datasets within a causal design. The project will directly inform the long-term health consequences of ongoing federal policy concerning managed retreat, a form of managed, settlement abandonment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Muscle stem cells (MuSCs) have cellular projections that are hypothesized to be morphologically dynamic at quiescence, providing a surveillance function for muscle damage. MuSC niche factors which promote projection outgrowth are further hypothesized to promote quiescence but such factors are largely unknown. We have developed an ex vivo, live imaging assay to identify netrin-1 as a candidate factor of this type and propose research that will test its role in MuSC quiescence and the quiescence-activation transition in response to injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The aging of the eyes is a phenomenon that many of us take as a given as we age, but indicators of mitochondrial function and genetics may provide a way to distinguish between individuals along the continuum from normal age-related vision changes to overt pathology. Mitochondrial damage is a major contributor to age-related diseases through cell apoptosis, dysregulated energy production, and inflammation, and is increasingly thought to be an important indicator of systemic aging. This project will evaluate the value of mitochondrial function and genetics as a marker of the biological aging of the eyes and susceptibility to pathologic damage leading to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal develops a new type of x-ray detector with an improved ability to distinguish small features (on the order of 100 µm) compared to the currently available devices. This novel technology will benefit many applications in radiology where very fine organ structures and medical instruments need to be examined – for example small lung airways, bone trabeculae, vascular stents, and brain electrodes. The validation studies in this project will focus on bone imaging to better assess trabecular changes due to osteoporosis and osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT It is well known and accepted that type 2 diabetes significantly increases a person’s risk for cognitive issues including Alzheimer’s Disease and its related dementias. However, very little is known about how to identify individual people with type 2 diabetes who are at the greatest risk of developing cognitive issues and dementia. This study seeks to identify unique proteins from blood where higher or lower levels may indicate greater risk for cognitive issues in people with type 2 diabetes. Identifying unique proteins in blood will help to inform new screening tests for cognitive issues and dementia in people with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although remote trial designs have emerged as an approach for enhancing clinical trial efficiency and inclusiveness, the evidence base regarding the benefits and limitations of remote trials is weak. The proposed translational science project, a collaboration among four CTSA hubs, will evaluate the impact of remote methods on trial efficiency (accrual) and quality (retention, treatment adherence, bio-specimen completion rates), across 3 different use cases (a larger, multi-site demonstration trial and two smaller, single-site dissemination projects) and will explore the specific impact on under-represented patient groups facing health inequities. The proposed work will be widely disseminated, providing a critical foundation for evidence-based disease- and treatment-agnostic best practices in clinical trial methodology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The “Clinical High Risk” (CHR) for psychosis syndrome in young people represents an opportune window for early intervention to prevent the onset of psychosis and other disorders, and to forestall disability; however, clinical heterogeneity and the paucity of biomarkers have hampered the development of effective intervention. To address these challenges, working with NIMH and key stakeholders, we will leverage our experience in the current observational study, the Accelerated Medicines Partnership® Schizophrenia (AMP® SCZ) Project, to validate potential drug development tools including biomarkers, digital measures, clinical outcome measures and predictive algorithms to refine and adapt these tools in the proposed clinical trial data processing, analysis, and coordination center (CT-DPACC), to support the Clinical Trial Network in a 12-16 week Proof of Principle trial(s) that will utilize a phase 2 ready compound.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research team has a unique opportunity to assess the impact of a transformative neighborhood level sanitation improvement intervention – the World Bank-funded Mozambique Urban Sanitation Project – construction on which will be completed in the city of Quelimane, Mozambique by December 2026. The goal of this study is to analyze previously collected baseline data and samples that will serve as critical preliminary data to enable a future evaluation of how the neighborhood wide sanitation improvements impact environmental contamination and acute and long-term child health outcomes. We will analyze current associations between living conditions, exposure risks, and infection rates of the population living in low-income neighborhoods in Quelimane; assess balance between intervention and comparison groups; and analyze samples using state-of- the-art molecular assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal investigates the concept of the human spleen as an evolving and complex archive of antigen- specific memory B cells (MBCs), rather than simply an MBC reservoir. Findings supporting this idea would suggest that the spleen plays an unappreciated role in MBC maintenance and is potentially a key determinant of an individual’s MBC response potential. Results could be important for a full appreciation of the consequences of splenectomy, disease states associated with hyposplenism, B cell depletion therapies, and splenic changes associated with infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project responds to the research need of more rigorous evaluation of unmeasured confounding in epidemiological analyses of environmental mixtures. We will develop advanced models for causal inference based on Bayesian probabilistic sensitivity analyses and negative control exposures approaches along with computationally efficient and user-friendly R packages to evaluate the impact of unmeasured confounding when causal inferences on multiple continuous exposures are sought. The proposed approaches will enable causal inference on joint exposure effects to inform policy for environmental exposures and child development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapies have significantly improved melanoma treatment, but drug resistance has limited their therapeutic efficacy. Emerging evidence suggests a fundamental link between vascular abnormalities and immune evasion in the tumor microenvironment whereby vascular destabilization impairs the tumor infiltration of immune cells. In this project, we propose to study the vascular determinants of immune exclusion from the tumor core and the underlying mechanisms in melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Since there is a lack of evidence for treatment in this population, this proposal will fill an unmet need in managing women with angina with nonobstructive coronary artery disease (ANOCA) and microvascular disease. Our proposal will significantly advance our understanding of SGLT2 inhibitors' potential benefits in coronary microvascular disease. Knowing SGLT2i's effect on inflammation pathways and markers of systemic Inflammation will allow for the discovery of a potential mechanism of SGLT2i's cardioprotective effects and allow us to design more targeted studies, such as those that assess the drug's impact on specific cytokines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with malaria are more susceptible to invasive bacterial infections due to neutrophil dysfunction which can persist for weeks following malaria infection. This project aims to determine the signaling mechanism by which a secreted malaria virulence factor, HRPII, causes neutrophil dysfunction. The pathways identified can help guide the development of new therapies to restore neutrophil function and prevent this severe consequence of malaria infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The core function of immunity is to distinguish self from non-self, yet in the process of sterile immunogenic cell death, our immune system recognizes our own dead cells as foreign. This process can thus lead to autoimmunity, though it can also be useful in cancer treatment if induced in the right time and place. This proposal seeks to apply breakthrough functional genomic technologies to interrogate the molecular basis of immunogenic cell death and potentiate new treatments in autoimmunity, cancer, and other diseases of the immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The resolution of inflammation is a critical mechanism leading to the healing of damaged tissue and a restoration of homeostasis. Failure of resolution is now considered a primary driver of chronic inflammatory disease in many different tissues, yet we understand little about the regulation of resolution mechanisms. In this proposal we will examine the role of reverse transendothelial migration (rTEM) of neutrophils on resolution of Lyme arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal seeks to understand how fatty acid synthesis in immune cells or skin tissues contributes to the development of skin inflammation. We will elucidate the previously unidentified mechanism that is regulated by fatty acid synthesis in the development of inflammatory skin disease using a mouse model of psoriasis. The outcome of this study will guide us to develop novel targeted therapies for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The exploratory studies will benefit the underserved rural areas and pediatric population. We will use the volumetric absorptive microsampling technique for dried blood spot sample collection combined with the highly sensitive ultra-performance liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry for drug quantitation to build a platform for pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic studies of antimalarial drugs including lumefantrine, amodiaquine, and piperaquine in rural areas. The patient-centered, field-friendly dried blood spot method will help to expand clinical studies to underserved rural area in Africa and facilitate studies in the pediatric population.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project studies host defense against tuberculosis. Based on promising early evidence, we will test the role of an immune cell factor called NR4A1 in the response to tuberculosis infection, and the effect of NR4A1 inhibition on tuberculosis outcomes. Results from this study will shed light on protective immunity and could result in the development of new treatments for this important disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The parent application involves secondary analyses of accelerated longitudinal cohort sequential data (collected from 2015–2021) from the Washington State Young Adult Health Study to examine changes in young adult substance use, related risk behaviors, and substance use related risk factors from before to during the COVID-19 pandemic among young adults in a state where alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis sales and use are legal for adults age 21 and over. This supplement will build on the parent grant by adding a new wave of data that was collected from this sample in the summer and fall of 2022, thereby allowing us to examine longer-term changes in these outcomes. Findings from this supplement will bolster the original aims of the parent study and inform tailoring and development of prevention and intervention efforts aimed at reducing problem behaviors and improving public health after situations that pose serious challenges for effective long-term planning of such efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In response to the pressing need for improved vaccination effectiveness, this proposal sets out to unlock the potential of the microbiota-stromal cell axis, a relatively uncharted territory due to stromal cell complexity and research limitations. Recent evidence highlights the critical role of stromal cells in shaping the local immune environment through the release of chemokines and cytokines. Building upon a groundbreaking prior study by the Principal Investigator demonstrating stromal cells' unique ability to recognize bacterial signals and trigger distinct immune responses, this proposal aims to harness this axis to develop microbiota-targeted therapies, promising a transformative approach to enhancing vaccine-induced immunity and ultimately advancing global health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Blepharospasm is a rare but debilitating neurologic disorder that produces involuntary abnormal facial expressions and eye closures. Many patients do not get satisfactory benefit from current treatment options, and the conventional methods for evaluating the impact of new treatments have several limitations. This project will evaluate new methods for measuring treatment impact based on computer analyses of video recordings of patients, thereby optimizing the potential for evaluating the outcome of multi-site clinical trials of future treatments.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Islet transplantation is a promising treatment for patients with type 1 diabetes and late-stage chronic pancreatitis. The goal of the proposed work is to develop a therapeutic to combat inflammation and preserve islet viability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Theoretically informed, culturally grounded, and psychometrically sound access metrics are needed to hold governments and healthcare systems accountable for making mental health services accessible to all people, and to help design and evaluate new programs and policies focused on improving access. This proposed collaboration between investigators at the University of Ibadan in Nigeria and the University of Washington in the United States will develop and evaluate a patient-centered metric of perceived access that is ready to use for policy evaluations, quality improvement, and mental health services research in Nigeria. Investigators will work closely with patient, provider and policy stakeholders in Nigeria to ensure that the access metric is comprehensive, culturally appropriate, and actionable for healthcare systems and local and federal ministries of health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority adolescents are over 4.5 times more likely to report attempting suicide than their heterosexual peers, for which family context (e.g., parental acceptance or rejection) is a major factor. Although parental acceptance vitally impacts adolescents’ healthy development, little is known about how parents of sexual minorities get to acceptance. Using a family systems perspective, the goal of this research is to explore parents’ mental health and their help-seeking behaviors to navigate their child’s coming out and foster supportive, accepting relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project will enhance oral swab (OS) testing as a novel, non-invasive means to diagnose tuberculosis (TB), especially in community settings. OS testing has the potential to simplify TB diagnosis, improve the care of many TB patients, and enable active case-finding strategies that will reduce TB transmission. Thus, this project could transform the global fight against TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative A significant limitation of the current single-molecule assay (SIMOA) technology is its reliance on bulky instrumentation and optics for automated sample preparation and high-sensitivity detection. This project seeks to advance the technology by creating a miniaturized SIMOA platform. This platform will seamlessly integrate thousands of microfluidic channels, sub-µm sized pores, and electrodes with detection readout circuits, all within a millimeter-sized semiconductor chip. This allows for high-throughput counting of all immuno-complexes activated by target molecules. Thanks to its compact design and portability, this device holds promise for near- bedside and Point-of-Care diagnostics in resource-constrained settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have implicated human-specific cerebellar developmental features in the pathogenesis of the most common brain birth defects and pediatric brain tumours. To better appreciate the cellular basis of cerebellar disease a more comprehensive study on the cellular behavior and molecular identity of cells residing in the normal developing human cerebellum needs to be carried out. The experiments proposed in this grant will help improve our understanding of the biology of normal cerebellar development and provide vital clues on the potential mechanisms of cerebellar birth defects and tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R36 dissertation study examines transitions from injecting to smoking drugs (predominantly fentanyl and methamphetamine) among people who inject drugs (PWID) in the San Diego- Tijuana border region. Such transitions may help reduce infectious disease (e.g., HIV, HCV) and overdose morbidity and mortality if sufficient quantities of safer smoking supplies are accessible (e.g., through syringe service programs; SSPs). By examining the multilevel (e.g., individual, organizational, structural) factors driving these transitions in drug consumption patterns and related implementation considerations for distributing safer smoking supplies through SSPs, this project will inform efforts to improve the delivery of prevention services and reduce the high burden of infectious diseases and overdose among people who use drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate the performance of selective whole genome amplification for the genome sequencing of Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of leprosy. Success in this project's stated aims will lead to the development of a rapid, sensitive, and cost-effective method to sequence M. leprae from human and armadillo samples successfully.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to focus on evidence-based interventions (EBIs) that improve mental health services for autism and optimize outcomes for this priority, complex population. We propose a Hybrid Type 2 randomized trial examining the effectiveness and implementation of an autism EBI targeting executive functioning, Unstuck and On Target, in community mental health settings. Findings have the potential to transform implementation and service quality for the high priority population of autistic youth as well as youth generally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed study will test the feasibility and acceptability of combining the Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) program with an open-label placebo treatment that holds significant promise for enhancing analgesic effects for chronic pain. This single-site feasibility trial is designed to furnish essential data and insights that will guide the planning of a larger fully-powered multi-site clinical trial. If subsequent fully-powered clinical trials confirm the efficacy of this combined approach, it has the potential to advance the care of millions of adults suffering from chronic pain, leveraging the accessibility and safety of mindfulness and open-label placebo treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Numerous populations, including Indigenous and those from rural backgrounds, are significantly underrepresented in the biomedical workforces that addresses health concerns of local and global significance. The Research Advising and Mentoring Professionals for Underrepresented Peoples (RAMP UP) program will develop, deliver, and evaluate a customized, holistic mentor training program that focuses on supporting faculty, graduate students, and research staff located at institutions that serve underrepresented undergraduate students in biomedical research. This intensive training will administer a supportive and culturally appropriate approach to create a network of trained mentors who possess the knowledge and skills they require to provide academic advising, research mentoring, and psychosocial support to the students they serve; especially those students who are typically underrepresented in the biomedical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: This project highlights the urgent need to address the multi-level impact of the CLS on OUD treatment and recovery to combat the opioid epidemic among people involved with the CLS. The Substance Use and Mental Health Services Administration defines recovery as a self-directed process, and this project examines ways in which institutions and networks limit an individual’s agency in their recovery efforts. Because substance use recovery is not merely an individual process, it is important to address barriers and facilitators at all levels of impact to best effect change and have a sustained public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy is a highly dynamic time when substance use behaviors change, often dramatically. Initial evidence suggests that co-exposure to alcohol and cannabis in utero may carry additional risks beyond those conferred from either substance alone, and these risks may extend to paternal co-use around the time of conception. The purpose of this developmental proposal is to gather information about preconceptional and prenatal alcohol and cannabis use, for both the pregnant individual and the biologic father, to support the feasibly of a larger cohort in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation and metabolism are tightly linked processes with significant consequences in human disease. We identified a critical inflammatory pathway in the liver that regulates systemic metabolism and weight gain through post-translational processes. Using a suite of novel transgenic mice, the proposed studies will investigate the pivotal role this pathway plays in governing whole body energy balance and identify the factors responsible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even after FDA approval of a drug, it is common for unforeseen adverse drug reactions to arise, and these adverse reactions cause millions of emergency department visits and hundreds of thousands of hospitalizations annually in the U.S. Predicting adverse drug reactions is difficult as doing so requires knowing how a drug may interact with all proteins in the human body. We propose a computational method for adverse drug reaction prediction that leverages recent advances in structural biology and bioinformatics to tackle this challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The most frequent genomic alteration in pediatric low-grade gliomas is a rearrangement that creates a fusion between the oncogene BRAF and the uncharacterized protein KIAA1549. Inhibitors which block the function of this fusion are effective but cause significant toxicity and require continuous dosing throughout childhood. The goal of this project is to define new therapeutic targets in KIAA1549-BRAF mutant pLGGs, with a particular focus on characterizing how the POMT complex regulates KIAA1549-BRAF activity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work in this fellowship proposal will extend our understanding of notochord biology and how this tissue contributes to a healthy spine. Importantly, mutations in INPPL1 cause the rare endochondral bone disorder, Opsismodysplasia (OPS). Therefore, this work in zebrafish may reveal a conserved role for inppl1a/INPPL1 in skeletal development and may also deepen our understanding of human endochondral bone disorders, such as OPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Artificial biomolecular condensates are emerging as a groundbreaking technology to manipulate diverse cellular processes including gene regulation, metabolism, and stress. This project establishes a new class of artificial condensates using computationally-designed RNA as a building block. We will develop methods to customize RNA condensates to recruit a multitude of target molecules and to form at target cellular locations, providing tools for control of gene expression and biosensing that are immediately portable to a variety of organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Depression is a prevalent and burdensome public health issue and widespread problems with antidepressant adherence, especially during the early stage of treatment, undermine the primary care treatment of depression. This study will test whether personalized daily text messages alone or combined with financial incentives improves depression outcomes. Scalable patient-facing intervention strategies that target adherence barriers are needed to support the treatment of depression in primary care to improve medication adherence and reduce depression symptoms.
